- Baby anago with quail egg: Very interesting! For a second, we were a bit creeped out since you could see the eyes but we got over it
- Hon maguro and kanpachi sashimi: The yuzu onion sauce was SO GOOD
- Red miso soup: YUM. The foam on top was such a nice addition, and the lime zest added the perfect hint of citrus. The meatball in the soup was super tender and melted in my mouth.
- Chiayu: The bamboo that came with this was so sweet, in the good way
- Nodoguro: I ordered this a la carte because we don't see it often. Such buttery, fatty goodness. 
- Yuzu sorbet: I LOVE yuzu, and this sorbet was so smooth and tarte. The perfect finish to the meal
- Creme brulee: The bf really enjoyed this as it was super creamy and not too sweet.

I didn't really care too much for the hassun (fancy assorted appetizer-looking dish) too much, but the crab claw was my favorite of the bunch. The fuji sake w/ cherry leaf had a bitterness that I didn't really enjoy, but I think it was intended. The wagyu was seasoned with salt, pepper and lemon juice -- a touch too much lemon juice IMO. 

Service was nothing less than what you'd expect at a high-end omakase restaurant. Our server was super friendly the whole time. I didn't catch our chef's name, but he was super sweet and chatted with us when he could. Like all omakase spots, each nigiri and dish was clearly explained to us. 

I'm glad to be able to check Kusakabe off my list of must-try omakase spots. Writing this review 4 months since our visit, I can't say that anything in particular stood out to me. It was a solid omakase meal in a lovely, intimate environment with great service.

excerpts: The Hassun which included 6 small plates was also very tasty, I love how the food is like art.
hassun.author: Gloria C.
hassun.review:
Since Kusabake is an omakase restaurant, I was hoping we can sit in front of the sushi bar to see how they prepare the sushi and serve it right in front of us. However, it was disappointing to find out party of two or more were not able to sit by the sushi bar and we had 4 people. I feel like that is part of the experience if I was to dish out $200 bucks for a meal. 

We were seated promptly by our reservation time at 8:15 and we chose the Grand Omakase because of the delicacy menu options (Truffle, A5 Wagyu beef, Hokkaido Sea Urchin, Eel from Tsukiji Market and Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly). An important thing to point out is we were NEVER served the Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly like the menu stated. Instead we were served Negitoro, which is minced fatty tuna with micro onion on a roasted seaweed. Those are two very different things, I wanted to ask why we were served the negitoro instead of the fatty tuna belly, but since my friends didn't mention I didn't want to be particular. Now that I think about it, I am quite angry that the manager didn't mention anything at all about switching our menu. 

Anyways, a review on the food that we DID have. It was a 10 course menu (with 2 soups) and it was more than enough. A tip for everyone, if you want to do a la carte towards the end, I suggest you choose the regular Omakase with less courses. Actually with the Grand Omakase, there is a course with non-sashimi/sushi dish. So if you here for the sushi/sashimi definitely choose the regular Omakase then do a la carte at the end. 

One thing to note about the sushi here is that they seasoned all their rice. At first it looked like brown rice, then we realized every piece of rice has soy sauce seasoned so the flavor is even throughout. My favorite sushi would definitely be the Oshinogi with Scallop+Uni sushi, Nata with poached egg on spoon, the uni sushi and surprisingly the Shima Aji (stripe jack) which is the chef's choice of sushi. The Hassun which included 6 small plates was also very tasty, I love how the food is like art. The wagyu beef tartare was one of the most delicious tartare that I ever had. The most disappointing course would definitely be the seared A5 Wagyu sushi, they over-seasoned it with too much pepper and salt overpowering the taste of the wagyu. It felt like they wasted a perfectly fine piece of meat, except the meat itself had a bit too much lines in it. 

Overall, I highly recommend Kusakabe for Omakase on a special occasion or if you are visiting from out of town. It seems like a popular date place, you can impress somebody by bringing them here and eating in front of the sushi bar. It's a shame we didn't get to sit there to watch as the sushi chef prepare our dishes. There might have been 1 or 2 disappointment, nevertheless it was a good experience. And I figured out why they lost their star; it was not perfect like it should be.

excerpts: Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle.
hassun.author: David K.
hassun.review:
Kusakabe is an experience. You go for the chef-led omakase and are presented with course after course of beautifully-formed, high-quality dishes that take your palate on a little tour of Japanese flavors and techniques. The dining room is small and reservations are required, but I got to come with a group of seven friends, and it was a great experience trying and discussing all the different courses together. This is not your typical, run-of-the-mill sushi, so be prepared to splurge (the base menu comes at a hefty $98/head), and come with an appreciation for the quality and cost of purveyance of the ingredients. 

Course #1: a subtly-flavored dashi broth. Nothing unusual (after all, there are only three ingredients in this fish-based broth), but very clean tasting and a nice way to start the meal.

Course #2: The zuku chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna) was seared on one side, giving the fish a great texture to complement its flavors. The hirame halibut with its own liver had a slightly spicy kick, and the cold-smoked bonito (katsuo) resounded with the flavors of the wood smoke.

Course #3: Bluefin sashimi and poached amberjack (a surprising favorite of mine). These pieces were served simply with soy and yuzu onion sauces, and came with little slices of fuji apple and radish. You had some of every flavor here--sweet from the apple, bitter from the radish, salty/umami from the soy, and tart from the yuzu. 

Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle. But my favorite dish was definitely the soft-shell crab, which was so creamy on the inside and delicately crunchy on the inside!

Course 5: Red miso soup with a duck and lotus root meatball, layered with soy cream foam. Delicious, umami soup with layers of flavor that change as you sip, and the lotus root adds an unexpected, pleasant chewiness to the meatball.

Course 6: My favorite sushi of the meal was the shima aji, the stripe jack with daikon radish, which was so buttery in texture and had a scallop-like flavor. The cherry salmon and the kasugodai (red snapper with crystallized egg yolk) both melted in your mouth as well. Unbelievable!

Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

Course by course, everyone is served at the same time, and the staff explain each and every component--the work that goes behind each of these dishes/components is indeed immense! After the omakase meal, we were given an a la carte menu, from which we could order even more sushi or sashimi. I got the aori ika (big fin reef squid), which was extremely creamy in texture, though not particularly vibrant in flavor. 

And then we went for dessert! We ordered one of each item to share, and each of the desserts was so unique. The yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet was nice and refreshing (slightly acidic and herbal flavors), the (unsweetened kome koji) ice cream had sweetness imparted to it from the same fermented flavors that you find in sake, and the Daiginjo sake kasu crème brulee had the same fermented flavors as the ice cream, but was much sweeter and decadent.

Overall, a great meal and definitely something to experience! The restaurant itself is small but homey and authentic (the bathroom even features an automated Japanese toilet). The service is the epitome of Japanese hospitality and the prices are exorbitant, so make sure to come with an appreciation of the work, care, and quality that goes behind each bite of food.

excerpts: However, the Hassun is a showcase of how innovative Kusakabe can be.
hassun.author: Kyle R.
hassun.review:
Came here with my family with a reservation we luckily got day of! 

The interior has a classic clean Japanese look with light wood panels. It's has a classy but relaxed vibe and I didn't feel like you needed to dress up formally. Mostly small tables so good for groups from 2 to 6 at most.

We all had the $100 regular omakase and it was amazing! Definitely the best sushi I've had so far in San Francisco and it was better than many ones that I've had in New York at the same price point. Most importantly, the sushi is very fresh. The seasoning and garnish is just enough that there's a unique taste but it doesn't break from the traditional clean Japanese style of preparing sushi. However, the Hassun is a showcase of how innovative Kusakabe can be.

The staff is also super nice and helpful in making recommendations, accommodating food preferences and explaining the different dishes that come out that you may have never seen before.

Even with the hefty price tag, I thought the experience was 100p worth it. Would definitely come back here again at any opportunity if I was to spend $100 at a restaurant.

excerpts: Other than the Hassun (6 mini platere) I wouldn't call the rest "kaiseki".
If kaiseki is the value customers are paying then Kusakabe needs more creativity on the flavors and efforts on the presentation.
Sequencing is also important.
Avoid soup / noodles in the middle of the menu; it is really filling after all the rice from sushi, difficult to enjoy the rest of the dishes if you get too full...
The taste was good overall, thus the 4 stars.
However, hamo/eel had a small bone that pierced through my gum when I bit into it.
hassun.author: Sonya M.
hassun.review:
$165 for grand omakase

Taste: 4 stars
Creativity: 3 stars
Staff: 3 stars
Environment: 2 stars

Value paid ($500 for 2 people) vs 
Overall Experience: 3 stars 

Likeliness of returning: Low

First time visiting Kusakabe. For a "kaiseki" styled sushi I was expecting much more creativity with the plating, flavor creativities, and texture creativities. Other than the Hassun (6 mini platere) I wouldn't call the rest "kaiseki". If kaiseki is the value customers are paying then Kusakabe needs more creativity on the flavors and efforts on the presentation. Sequencing is also important. Avoid soup / noodles in the middle of the menu; it is really filling after all the rice from sushi, difficult to enjoy the rest of the dishes if you get too full... The taste was good overall, thus the 4 stars. However, hamo/eel had a small bone that pierced through my gum when I bit into it. Restaurant waived my dessert as an apology.

There was a big turn off for me very early on... as soon as I got seated, there was a small fly flying around. Landed on my water cup, on the table, even the cutting board! (the chef turned around to work on other plates - it had since flown off, so he didn't see it landed there, so the next thing I know was pieces of sushi being placed on the same board where fly landed). 

My chef was very friendly, 5 stars for him. I gave the staff overall 3 stars because I kept on having to dodge the server for water refills. Ideally, he could've waited until the water was at least half way down, or find a gap and ask if we'd like the water refilled. I almost hit his arm once or twice because I wasn't expecting an arm to come in between to refill the water when it was at a 60-70% level. Nice/friendly server, though lesser refills would be great. 

Prior to this, we had been to Wakuriya and sushi Kashiba, had really high expectations coming into Kusakabe, maybe bit too high on my end. My fiancee enjoyed it at Kusakabe quite a bit, mine was so so. For fine dining, experience matters. How much attention to detail matters, reaction of customer (case of frequent water refill) and environment (fly) really matter. Food can be good, chef and server can be friendly, it only takes a bit to ruin the 5 star experience. Perhaps my review may be on the harsher end, I definitely had very high expectations after all the good reviews. Customers want to make sure the cost is equals to the value expected. I hope Kusakabe continues to improve. Who knows, maybe I might just come in on a wrong day? Maybe I should give it one more try?

Thank you chefs, staff.

excerpts: Eventually, after a few rounds of sushi and sashimi, they brought out the Hassun, which consisted of 6 tiny dishes, and was the most beautifully plated out of all the courses.
I loved that you got a tiny bite of everything, rather than one entree.
I won't go over everything, but wasn't blown away by the taste of the overall dish.
I'm sure people who love clams would like the cold clam soup.
I felt like it really brought out the flavor of the clams.
I didn't particularly like it, but that's because I'm not a huge fan of clams.
There was a lightly fried shrimp and taro, like shrimp and taro karage.
Tasted like what you would expect.
hassun.author: Christine L.
hassun.review:
Got here about 10-15 minutes before our reservation at 8:15pm on a Friday (made a month in advance). They were able to seat us promptly even though we were early.
We sat at the table right next to the door partition. It was a smallish place, so it was a bit tight for the servers to get past me. I felt bad since I didn't realize this until we left. They were all nice enough not to say anything! 

They had two choices: the regular omakase (8 courses) or the grand omakase (11 courses). We opted for the regular $98 omakase menu. After we ordered, they gave us the dashi broth, along with warm towels and other eating utensils. We had more than one server bring us our food, and each one explained what they had placed on the table. I got too excited when they brought the sushi out so I didn't get to take pictures of the first sushi course. It was a piece of cured bluefin chutoro sushi that had a wonderful smoky flavor, paired with a piece of fresh fish served as is (not cured, marinated, etc.). You have one piece that was heavily flavored with soy sauce contrasting with another that was light and fresh, no frills. It was a very thoughtful pairing that not only didn't overwhelm my palate, but brought out the flavor of each piece of sushi. This theme continued throughout the meal with the sushi plates. 

Eventually, after a few rounds of sushi and sashimi, they brought out the Hassun, which consisted of 6 tiny dishes, and was the most beautifully plated out of all the courses. I loved that you got a tiny bite of everything, rather than one entree. I won't go over everything, but wasn't blown away by the taste of the overall dish. I'm sure people who love clams would like the cold clam soup. I felt like it really brought out the flavor of the clams. I didn't particularly like it, but that's because I'm not a huge fan of clams. There was a lightly fried shrimp and taro, like shrimp and taro karage. Tasted like what you would expect. It also came with something that tasted like wagyu croquette, covered in crispy rice. It was quite small, so it was difficult to taste the wagyu. 

We ended the meal with more fresh and melt-in-your-mouth sushi: a fun and delicious DIY hand roll served with scallop sushi topped with uni. They brought out an add-ons menu if we wanted to order anything a la carte. We were pretty satisfied, so we didn't add get anything else. After that, they came out with what I think was a yuzu sorbet, with a candle, on the house! I had forgot that they called ahead about a week before to ask if we were coming for any special reason. I had mentioned to them on the phone that it was my boyfriend's birthday. It was a nice surprise. The sorbet itself had a nice citrusy flavor, and came in a really cute little tea cup. 

In general, I really liked the quality of the sushi and sashimi, along with the their flavors and the little additions and sauces served with them. This was the main reason fo coming here. There warm dishes and soups weren't bad, but they definitely weren't the stars of the show. The servers were also all really nice and professional.

excerpts: Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef.
hassun.author: Jessica Z.
hassun.review:
My bf and I celebrated our anniversary at Kusakabe! I've had this bookmarked for quite some time, just never had a reason to go.

I was pleasantly surprised as I had no clue where we were going to celebrate! 

We ordered the grand omakase with two hot sakes. The grand omakase consisted of 25 pieces, displayed on 7 "dishes". The entire dining experience was amazing from the start to finish. We first started off with the Ichiban Dashi, a small soup. Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef. 

After the omakase, there's an a la carte menu. My bf and I ordered 2 additional pieces each. One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni. 

Although we were pretty satisfied, we wanted to end the meal with dessert! They over heard that we were celebrating our anniversary so they gave us all three desserts on the house. So sweet! Love it. 

Overall, I was pretty blown away and kudos to the services as well! Can't wait to be back :)

excerpts: Also some items from the Hassun were not for my taste such as the lobster salad with the jelly like thing on top and the persimmon salad with the lotus root chip on top.
Despite the few items that did not meet my expectations, the rest of my meal was delicious.
hassun.author: Joyce C.
hassun.review:
I came to Kusakabe with very high expectations. Im probably one of the biggest sushi lovers that you'll ever meet so I was really excited to try this restaurant. Unfortunately it didn't satisfy what I was hoping for. 

My friend and I came for our end of the semester celebration. We both ordered the 95 dollar Omakase. The raw fish here is honestly really fresh and it just melts in your mouth. The halibut from the Sushi Prelude was killed 3 hours before it was served to us. However the Dashi broth was too salty for my liking. Also some items from the Hassun were not for my taste such as the lobster salad with the jelly like thing on top and the persimmon salad with the lotus root chip on top. Despite the few items that did not meet my expectations, the rest of my meal was delicious. I especially loved the final course where they served us baby sweet white shrimp and toro. 

The service here was wonderful. They brought out our food really quick and was on top of refilling our drinks. Every time they brought out our food, they would give us a very detailed explanation of what it was which is something that many restaurants lack. There were 7 sushi chefs making our meals and 3-4 servers. 

Overall, the experience was great but I don't know if I would come back again. The service and 80 percent of the meal was wonderful but if I am going to pay over 100 dollars for sushi, I expect everything to be delicious. 

Food: 4/5 stars because of the items I disliked 
Service: 5/5 stars 
Environment: 5/5 stars

excerpts:
Fourth
Hassun, oysters served with French caviar and four petit plates (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qyg_iiz7Brq9vioVpmRjcQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -
Like the second, fourth, and fifth plates (from the left) the most.
hassun.author: Mike C.
hassun.review:
The growing trend of Japanese restaurants opening in or near downtown is clearly at a fever pitch.  Last year, a friend presented me with a gift card (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MdG5viokZhOm2Qpn12kRBQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q). Due to scheduling logistics, it's been difficult to find a person and the time to enjoy this experience with me.  On a recent Friday, I was able to make a 5 pm reservation for two at the table near the host stand, basically at the center of the restaurant.  There are only five tables available which explains the difficulty in securing reservations without early notice.  The remainder of the seating is on the L-shaped sushi bar which seats around twelve or fifteen.  After my guest arrived, here's what we enjoyed:

Amuse
Konbu cha - Translates to kelp tea, this is more like a soup to me.  Sorry, I drank this without taking a picture as I thought it was "just tea".  Perfect elixir for foggy SF evenings.

First
Nigiri toro, halibut, bonito (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DmkADPQrPhbu7Ri_PhcvaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - The first and the third were my favorites... how can you go wrong with those two?!

Second
Sashimi scallop and maguro (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rkKjr_pOWEbDC8rDxyMNDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pristine, fresh, and tender.  They were a nice contrast with one being soft (scallop) and the other firm (maguro).

Third
Umami tomato soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KJTATBDka63tOnd0NxlrGw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My eyes widened as I searched for the tomato element.  There is a large meatball at the center of this which reminds me of the chicken meatball at Delica in the Ferry Building.

Fourth
Hassun, oysters served with French caviar and four petit plates (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qyg_iiz7Brq9vioVpmRjcQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Like the second, fourth, and fifth plates (from the left) the most.  The first one was a bit fishy for me.

Fifth
Yuba wrap (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zblfKmWoBNJU3ka25XU1RQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Indulgence!  Probably my best description given that there was foie gras in the center and summer truffles shaved on top.

Sixth
Nigiri Stripe jack, salmon, flounder (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SbCSmsZ56nNn2sCv3h6Tkw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Clean flavors and nice prelude to the highlight.

Seventh
Sushi finale, grade A5 Miyazaki wagyu steak (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oy2eVTsOqhr7JkiXmBY9cQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -  All I can say, is "look at that"!

After completing the tasting menu, our waitress kindly offered us their supplement menu in case we wanted to try something else or weren't full from the original meal.  

I chose the Lobster omelet sushi (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=87ql3El1K0eKkdX_xYd-tw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  It's actually a flavored take on tamago (egg) sushi where the lobster flavor is infused with the egg.  Enjoyed this as it was an interested take, but just don't get caught up on trying to find the lobster.
There were also three desserts on the menu (one being panna cotta), but nothing was attractive to my guest so we passed.
As many described, this is authentic Japanese cuisine served in a fine dining atmosphere without the stuffy dress code.  As I walked to use the loo, I noticed a couple of awards to the proprietor as sushi maker of the year, not something that's commonly seen in these parts.  
Yes, I will be back, but need to make sure my dining companions are as open minded menu wise as me.

excerpts: What disappointed me the most were the hassun, the toro, and the wagyu beef.
The hassun was gorgeously presented, but of all the items on the dish, not a single one stood out to me.
The toro was chewy and nothing near the melt in the mouth quality
I was hoping for.
Same went for the wagyu beef.
It was so chewy that I ended up swallowing the beef whole.
hassun.author: Diana C.
hassun.review:
After hearing so much about this place from friends and family, I finally decided to give this place a try. I booked the place for my birthday dinner and psyched myself up for what I was hoping to be an amazing meal. We walked in on a Friday night at 8pm for our 8:15pm reservation. My friends and I were greeted by the host in the front and promptly led to our seats at the bar. The sushi chef in front of us introduced himself to us and asked us about our preferences for fish. We went with the regular omakase over the grand one. The whole experience itself was fun. You got to watch the chef make all the nigiri in front of you. Fresh from their hands straight onto your plate. Our chef was super friendly and let us try to guess which fish was coming next. 

My favorite item of the night was the sashimi of tuna and scallops that came beautifully arranged atop a bowl of ice. The scallops were amazingly sweet and the tuna just melted in your mouth. This item earned 5/5 stars for me and I wish I could have eaten it all night long. Other honorable mentions were the hamachi+mackerel (forgot what the name of the fish was) and the cherrywood smoked tuna. Both were very unique in flavor and the fish was super fresh and supple. 

What disappointed me the most were the hassun, the toro, and the wagyu beef. The hassun was gorgeously presented, but of all the items on the dish, not a single one stood out to me. The toro was chewy and nothing near the melt in the mouth quality I was hoping for. Same went for the wagyu beef. It was so chewy that I ended up swallowing the beef whole. For $15 extra a piece, I was quite bitter about ordering it after eating it. 

For $100 for an omakase, I would most likely not be coming back here anytime soon. The quality of the fish was decent, but the items themselves were nothing to rave over. I will say that if you want to come here, ask for a reservation at the bar. It is well worth it. I honestly think the whole experience was as good as it was because we sat at the bar instead of at the tables. The food itself gets a 3/5 stars for me, but the service was a 5/5. 

Cons: 
- Pricey (but most people come here knowing they are going to have to dish out a good chunk of money for this meal)
- Hard to find parking (true for a lot of places around SF though)
- A lot of courses were lackluster and left me wanting more 

Pros: 
- Great service 
- Sushi chef was super friendly and accommodating
- Gorgeous interior decor and nice ambiance

excerpts: Hassun:
This was 7 bites served together and you are free to eat it in any order.
I chose to try and eat it in order of lighter to heavier -
-Baby

Eel: This was something new, not too much flavor but the broth it came in was delicious
-DUCK BREAST: refreshing to get a bite of meat

and it was well cooked and served over broccolini
-Salmon wrapped in daikon:

Good salmon flavor, tastes more refreshing with the daikon
-Kusshi oyster: Fresh oyster, yum
-Rice octopus: Good texture and flavor
-Tamago with snapper:

This egg was super fluffy and sweet tasting, not like your usual tamago
-TORO ON BOX RICE:
hassun.author: Christina L.
hassun.review:
This place is OUT OF CONTROL. How much so? My fiance and I are currently trying to buy a house yet Kusakabe let us to a real discussion of whether it would be better to put our money into a mortgage or maybe just eating at Kusakabe a couple times every week. I mean, seriously, I'm sure owning your own home is overrated.

Kusakabe operates under a omakase menu style with a $95 or $150 option. We opted for the $95 option and it is pretty much set although the sushi chef has a little bit of wiggle room with 5 different seasonal sushis of the day. He will also ask you at the beginning what type of fish you usually like! Pro tip: MUST sit at the bar. After your omakase is done you can opt to go a la carte to try other types of fish. Spoiler alert: You will likely feel compelled to continue after your omakase is done, there is just so much good stuff to try!

Here's an overview of our meal. Standouts will be emphasized with CAPITAL LETTERS!
1. First brewed dashi: A light broth with tons of umami, good to kick off your appetite
2. Sushi Prelude: 
-SEARED CHUTORO comes standard and was amazing!
Two kinds of seasonal sushi of the day: 
-Hirame (Halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf) - I'm not usually a fan of halibut but this was really good quality and the shiso leaf added freshness while the liver added creaminess
-Katsuo (Lightly cherry wood smoked bonito) - Smokey flavor added a lot to this one and the smooth tuna texture had a great mouth feel
3. Sashimi course: Maguro and Hokkaido Scallop with fresh wasabe & yuzu onion sauce. Both really good quality, the scallop was sweet and delicious with a good portion and the yuzu onion sauce was intriguing.
4. Hassun: This was 7 bites served together and you are free to eat it in any order. I chose to try and eat it in order of lighter to heavier -
-Baby Eel: This was something new, not too much flavor but the broth it came in was delicious
-DUCK BREAST: refreshing to get a bite of meat and it was well cooked and served over broccolini
-Salmon wrapped in daikon: Good salmon flavor, tastes more refreshing with the daikon
-Kusshi oyster: Fresh oyster, yum
-Rice octopus: Good texture and flavor
-Tamago with snapper: This egg was super fluffy and sweet tasting, not like your usual tamago
-TORO ON BOX RICE: The toro was amazing and the rice perfectly seasoned
5. SOUP: Spring hamaguri soup with fresh bamboo shoot, wakame & shiitake mushrooms - perfect to have something warm. The clams were perfectly cooked, broth filled with umami.
6. Sushi Chic:
-BURI (Wild Yellowtail): Basically the best yellowtail ever. It had more fattiness like chutoro but tons of that delicious yellowtail flavor. See picture for amazing fattiness!
-Kuromutsu (Japanese blue fish): Very light flavor but nice bite and texture
-COPPER RIVER KING (Wild Alaskan king salmon with Oboro Konbu): Best salmon ever, so much flavor and the bit of seaweed on top gives it a touch of earthiness. 
7. Sushi Finale:
-WAGYU (A5 grade Miyazaki Wagyu strip loin): Lightly seared and salted, it's definitely the best wagyu sushi I've had. The sear is key!
-TORO (Bluefin fatty tuna belly): Ridiculous. Watching Chef Kusakabe cut this fish and then watching the chefs gingerly pass the pieces down the line and then watching your chef assemble the sushi is a ridiculous level of anticipation. And it was worth it.

At this point you're essentially devastated that your meal is over and it's time to make some tough decisions. We added:
-KAMASU: Lightly seared Japanese Barracuda - great sear flavor on a slightly fishier taking fish. Definitely a good add.
-TORO: What, again?? We needed to have another bite but this time our sushi chef seared the toro gently and added all sorts of other goodies. It completely changed up the flavor of the toro and was so worth it. MUST do again.

Next time I will add:
-KAISUI UNI (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin): If you're looking for a different type of uni this is an interesting bite. Creamier texture, lighter flavor, more sweet. We watched the guy next to us eat it jealously.
-JI KINMEDAI (Cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper): I didn't over this because I had it at Akiko's before but the guy next to us, again, said it was the best. Dammit. Next time.

All in all it was an amazing dining experience and I can't wait to go again! It is a SAN FRANCISCO MUST.

excerpts: The hassun consisted of 5 different petite plates.
hassun.author: Edward W.
hassun.review:
Best meal experience ever!

I made a reservation for 5:45pm on Saturday night and had requested bar seating ahead of time. We were lucky enough to be seated right in front of Chef Kusakabe! 

The kaiseki began with kelp tea, something I've never had before, but exactly how you would imagine it to taste.

The sushi prelude consisted of zuke chutoro, halibut, and bonito. The halibut was served with bits of halibut liver, adding a nice kick to each bite. 

The sashimi had hokkaido scalop and blue fin tuna nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi and yuzu onion sauce. I found the scallop surprisingly not chewy and delicious. I'd highly recommend using the sauce to give the sashimi lots of flavor.

The "kamo dango" duck and "asari" clam Miso soup with Mitsuba leaf
large clam tasted amazing and overflowing with flavor. The duck meatballs were quite a treat. 

The hassun consisted of 5 different petite plates. Cod egg, black salmon, shigoku oyster with french daurenki caviar, toro with salmon flakes, and wagyu beef. My favorite was the cod egg since it tasted the most unique. I've never had caviar before, but it just tasted salty.

The warm dish was a tofu-chwan-mushi with fresh steamed dungeness crab and nameko mushroom. It tasted so good and I wish I could have had more.

The sushi chic consisted of wild hamachi, japanese barracuda, and alaskan king salmon with sakura leaf.
 
The sushi finale is either the bluefin fatty tuna or miyazaki wagyu beef. My giflfriend and I split one of each. The bluefin fatty tuna just melts in your mouth and so does the wagyu beef because of it's high fat content. The wagyu is seared on one side and raw on the other side.

After the Kaiseki style meal, we were presented with the a la Carte menu. We opted for the shirayaki (fresh bbq white eel) and the hokkaido sea urchin. This sea urchi tasted extremely creamy and is the best I've had. It is shipped from Japan and packed with ocean water to maintain the freshness. The piece of shirayaki was thicker than most unagi, had a crunchy skin, and sauced perfectly.

For dessert we had the yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet. I really enjoyed this dessert and it was not very sweet at all with lots of natural yuzu flavor.

This place really encourages eating sushi the traditional way, aka with your fingers. I thought it greatly added to the experience and having Chef Kusakabe serve us personally was a HUGE plus. In between dishes, we had the pleasure of watching him masterfully prep the sashimi. I'd highly recommend coming here and sitting at the bar.

excerpts: - Hassun - the creativity continues with a box of a random assortment of seafood in all shapes and forms.
But presentation on point for errything.
Honestly some weren't that tasty
(there was a weird seafood cracker that I didn't like) but again, just so unique and such detailed preparation.
- Soup - this was a creamy cauliflower soup with abalone and abalone mushrooms.
Tasted like a lighter version of clam chowder but seriously soo delicious!
hassun.author: Jingxi Z.
hassun.review:
Best omakase by far in SF! My lovely BF surprised me with reservations here for our anniversary and oh my god it was such a beautiful and creative dining experience.

Reservations become available online 2 months in advance and for the true omakase experience you gotta sit at the sushi bar so you can watch your chef can personalize each part of the meal to your liking :) 

They only serve omakase, a $150 grand set or the $95 set, with options for add-ons at the end of the meal. Feeling fancy, we opted for the grand set and if you're looking for a time to splurge, this would be it!

The omakase experience is unique to each restaurant but the creativity and care that goes into each piece is where Kusakabe really shines. Each dish was well-thought out and went beyond just the typical nigiri. Before our meal our sushi chef asked us if there was anything we didn't like or really liked. I really dislike wasabi and usually for omakase they add it to every piece of sushi. However our chef made sure to only put a small amount for all my pieces and I couldn't even taste it!

I believe the menu changes seasonally, but here's what we had:
- Ichiban Dashi - first up was soup, like a fancier version of miso soup, probably the best soup I've had using dashi broth!
- Sushi prelude - next we were served 5 pieces of nigiri sushi, one was the king of all sushi - the toro tuna! So soft and buttery, each and every piece. The other 4 pieces were seasonal and the chef makes sure to tell you where each fish comes from :) I believe we had scallop from Santa Barbara!
- Sashimi - next we were given four different types of sashimi paired with 4 different unique types of sauce/toppings. One included truffle shavings and another was mussels. The flavor combos were so good, although some I liked more than others but definitely all flavors I had never tried before.
- Hassun - the creativity continues with a box of a random assortment of seafood in all shapes and forms. But presentation on point for errything. Honestly some weren't that tasty (there was a weird seafood cracker that I didn't like) but again, just so unique and such detailed preparation.
- Soup - this was a creamy cauliflower soup with abalone and abalone mushrooms. Tasted like a lighter version of clam chowder but seriously soo delicious!
- Sushi Chic - more nigiri sushi including uni (sea urchin) from Santa Barbara! I'm not a big uni fan but oh boy this one was so buttery and creamy and slightly sweet. Definitely can taste the quality and freshness!
- Sushi Finale - ended with Unagi (BBQ eel) and a choice of toro or wagyu beef. I'd recommend the wagyu beef since it is so tender and they sear it right in front of you with a touch of pepper. It just melted in my mouth like butter. How is this possible?! 

On top of the amazing food was amazing service. They surprised us at the end with sorbet at the end to celebrate our anniversary! If you want a perfect dining experience this is it.

excerpts: Hassun (Le Petite Plats)
- I did not enjoy the mushroom or egg plats, but the others were wonderful.
My favorite was the warm truffle croquette and caviar oyster.
Warm Dish - The flavor was too subtle.
It needed a kick like an added spice.
By this dish, I was getting sick of the mushrooms, so I did not eat the mushroom portion.
I'm also not a fan of sweet potato (satsuma-imo), but it was an interesting dish because of the combination.
I wish it had an added crunch to contrast the soft foods.
If you are brave, look up Shirako, which is in the dish.
Three kinds of sushi
- All delicious!
hassun.author: Joanna S.
hassun.review:
Omakase spectacular!

I was fortunate enough to go to Kusakabe for my birthday. It apparently took my boyfriend's boss 6 months to get a call-in reservation. My boyfriend used the app "Reserve" and secured a reservation a month in advance. The app also pays the bill automatically once you are at the restaurant. 

Kusakabe was my first Omasake and Michelin star experience. They offer a $95 prefixe menu and automatically add tip to the bill. If you are still hungry after the prefixe (which is a lot, trust me), they have an optional nigiri selection for added costs, including octopus and sea urchin.

The sushi is incredibly flavorful and they hand-grate their own fresh ginger and wasabi (sweeter and more delicate than ready-made wasabi). Kusakabe uses soy sauce, teriyaki, and lemon to enhance the delicate flavors of fish, so no need to add it yourself. The mushroom dishes were inventive and interesting, but too many for my liking (even though I love mushrooms). You are free to make specific requests in case you don't like a particular food like mushroom or egg, but do this in the beginning; they will ask you.

1/12/15 Prefixe Menu Critique:
1. Ichiban Dashi - Great broth to get the belly ready for the feast ahead.
2. Sushi Prelude: 
     Zuke Chutoro - Bluefin tuna cured in soy sauce sauce and seared with a blowtorch.
     Two seasonal sushi - My favorite was the halibut, which was cut thin enough to see through. My boyfriend loved the tuna with lemon.
3. Sashimi - Perfect dish! The tuber slice was a nice added crunch. 
4. Umami Soup - Personally, though there was too much mushroom for my taste, but overall good, delicate dish. Quintessential umami flavor. Not sure if I liked the rice and lotus root dumpling, but I'm glad I tried it. 
5. Hassun (Le Petite Plats) - I did not enjoy the mushroom or egg plats, but the others were wonderful. My favorite was the warm truffle croquette and caviar oyster.
6. Warm Dish - The flavor was too subtle. It needed a kick like an added spice. By this dish, I was getting sick of the mushrooms, so I did not eat the mushroom portion. I'm also not a fan of sweet potato (satsuma-imo), but it was an interesting dish because of the combination. I wish it had an added crunch to contrast the soft foods. If you are brave, look up Shirako, which is in the dish.  
7. Three kinds of sushi - All delicious!
8. Sushi finale (Your Choice) - I chose A5 Grade wagyu beef, lightly seared. My favorite sushi of the entire meal! A wonderful finale. 

For my birthday, Kusakabe also gave me a complimentary dessert, Chestnut ice cream - a unique dessert, but not something I would crave. They also sang "Happy Birthday," which was absolutely adorable. 

Overall, this was a fantastic experience! I would definitely recommend Kusakabe to any foodie or sushi lover who is willing to spend big bucks. Go ahead and indulge.

excerpts: There were some items from Hassun that was a little strange for my tastebuds.
Also, in the soup, the pumpkin mochi wasn't as chewy as I liked and the soup was a little too salty.
Every time they brought our food, they gave us a detailed explanation of what we were getting.
They also kept tracked of what we enjoyed in case you wanted to order more at the end.
They also kept refilling my tea multiple times (even when it wasn't empty).
Overall, this was a great experience, but I don't think I would come back again.
hassun.author: Tracy Y.
hassun.review:
I came to Kusakabe with high expectations. My friend and I came here to celebrate the end of our semester. We had a 5:15pm reservation and when we got there around 5:24pm, we were seated right away. Right from the beginning, the service was amazing. They quickly brought our placements and drinks right away. We ordered the $95 Omaksae. The raw fish was really fresh and it melts in your mouth. I enjoyed all the raw fish we had. There were some items from Hassun that was a little strange for my tastebuds. Also, in the soup, the pumpkin mochi wasn't as chewy as I liked and the soup was a little too salty. Every time they brought our food, they gave us a detailed explanation of what we were getting. They also kept tracked of what we enjoyed in case you wanted to order more at the end. They also kept refilling my tea multiple times (even when it wasn't empty). Overall, this was a great experience, but I don't think I would come back again. I do think this place is worth a first time try. 

Side notes: There's only one bathroom so sometimes there's a line, you have have a 15 minute grace period before your reservation ends and you'll get charged a fee, and parking is a little hard to find (meter/street parking).

excerpts: Hassun: this was a beautifully arranged platter with lots of flavors and textures

- Oyster with caviar
  - Tempura crab: coated in rice crackers
  - Shrimp cake with sweet corn: best eaten warm; good with dipping salt 
  - Nasu agedashi: served in a little glass bowl with kani and ikura; this dish is very light
- Squid: very thinly sliced, with baby kiwi, toasted pine nuts, and wakame.

The wakame was my favorite part of the dish
  - Box sushi: tuna topped with

bonito flakes
  - Box sushi
hassun.author: Marilyn H.
hassun.review:
I've been back quite a few times since the first review, and I think it's gotten better in the last year as they re-structured and changed up the menu. 

We started with a sake flight - three 4 oz pours that were all quite different ($50.) We ended up getting two more 8 oz sakes, and in the end, the sake and food cost about the same. Sake definitely complements the sushi, though.  I love their glassware (design, thinness). Sadly, it's pretty much all from a special source in Japan and is not easy to get

We did the grand tasting ($150/person) and some add ons.
1. Dashi to start: served warm in a small cup

2. Sushi: I love their rice, and I liked each piece of the sushi to the point that there was no clear cut favorite
  - Seared chutoro: nice and fatty, cured with soy sauce, love the sear 
  - Hirame: wild halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf
  - Katsuo: smoked in cherry wood, topped with garlic, chives, radish, and it tasted almost like bbq  
  - Hotate: super sweet and tender, topped with uni 
  - Baby snapper topped with crystallized egg yolk 

3. Sashimi: the maguro and barracuda were meant to be dipped with either house grated onion with yuzu, chive, and salt or traditional soy sauce + wasabi
  - Thinly sliced salmon wrapped around cucumber with a bamboo charcoal miso: the miso was very unique 
  - Red snapper: wrapped with ankimo, topped with Italian summer truffle and sitting on a ponzu truffle gelee.  I couldn't taste the truffle much, but the gelee was good 
  - Kamazu: barracuda with micro onion
  - Maguro

4. Hassun: this was a beautifully arranged platter with lots of flavors and textures
  - Oyster with caviar
  - Tempura crab: coated in rice crackers
  - Shrimp cake with sweet corn: best eaten warm; good with dipping salt 
  - Nasu agedashi: served in a little glass bowl with kani and ikura; this dish is very light
  - Squid: very thinly sliced, with baby kiwi, toasted pine nuts, and wakame. The wakame was my favorite part of the dish
  - Box sushi: tuna topped with bonito flakes
  - Box sushi: tamago with a layer of crab underneath, topped with a goji berry 
  - Fried fish with red onion and a vinegar dashi

5. Soup: Puree of cauliflower, which was very rich tasting. It came with a sweet potato paste in the center for more sweetness and thickness, abalone, trumpet mushrooms, abalone mushrooms

6. Sushi Chic and Sushi Finale 
  - Shima aji: topped with daikon and yuzu
  - Arctic char: with sea salt and yuzu 
  - Sanma: with grated ginger lime zest, and chives
  - Uni, but I opted for non uni, and it was a torched oily snapper cured in kombu, which was really good 
  - Shirayaki: BBQ white eel, finished with a light drizzle of sauce and sansho pepper. I like that the sauce doesn't obscure the fish
  - Wagyu (you could also choose toro): A5, super smooth and buttery

Extras: prices range from $6-15 per piece (tamago vs uni)
  - Jin kinmedai: golden eye snapper smoked in cherry wood
  - Kisu: whiting cured with bonito and konbu

We were too full for dessert by the end.  It ends up being a lot of food.  My only complaint is that there's only one bathroom, so there can sometimes be a wait. 

Service is always impeccable, and Chef Ngai did a great job of educating us on the dishes. Definitely get a seat at the sushi bar. I've done a table once, and it was NOT the same.  I think it's a party of 3 or so max for the sushi bar; otherwise, you get seated at the table.

excerpts: And the oyster with caviar in the Hassun, flavor explosion.
Delicate simple flavors brought everything together.
hassun.author: Toni Rose M.
hassun.review:
Finally I got a chance to try this place out.

Dined in with James M. (check out her ratings ya'll) on Thursday and we both got the $95 omakase, a few more from the a la carte menu and sake (Yuki no Bosha).
The meal was beautifully presented and it was delicious. Our favorite from the omakase menu are: toro, bonito, buri and Santa Barbara uni. Didn't realize how sweet Santa Barbara uni is, and the bonito, OMG, delicious. Bonito usually have  a fishy after taste, but this was an exception. The cauliflower soup was delicious; the mushroom and the abalone was so meaty, and all the flavors of the soup combined, it was amazing. And the oyster with caviar in the Hassun, flavor explosion. Delicate simple flavors brought everything together. The ankimo from the a la carte menu, delicious. 

Will definitely come back here again to try the grand omakase. I think getting the omakase then order more from the a la carte works better, since that's what we did. We were stuffed after the meal. Do not believe the reviews where they say it's okay sushi, or there's nothing special about it, try it yourself and judge. Because I think this is one of the decent sushi I've had in the Bay Area compared to sushi from the fish market in Japan.

excerpts:
two other seasonal nigiri sushi

Sashimi - Chef's special sashimi nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi and Yuzu onion sauce

Soup - Italian black truffle miso soup with Eringi and Shimeju mushrooms
or...
Kamo-Dango, duck miso soup with Mitsuba leaf

Hassun - Shigoku oyster with French Daurenki Caviar and four kinds of Chef's assorted petite plates
hassun.author: Wanugee N.
hassun.review:
Chef Nori Kusakabe created this new sushi restaurant, across the street form the Transamerica building, based on ancient Japanese dining traditions of "Goshoku, Gomi, Gokan, Gohou" one of the essential tenet in creating Kaiseki menu that is translated to "Five Colors, Five Tastes, Five Senses, Five Methods." 

This is a meld of European Fine dining meets Omakase Sushi from a skilled chef. They have recently received a Michelin Star for their efforts. 

It is essentially a fixed price, set Omakase (Chef's special choice) that everyone eats, in a multi-course fashion, for about $95/person. You can go a la carte and off the menu, but only after your Omakase fixed menu commitment. So it is a little bit Sushi Nazi, but in an elegant way. 

I came some time ago with a sophisticated international dining companion. I was ecstatic with the real Japanese traditions and quality, she enjoyed it, but thought it was a little too controlled theatrics. But that is the nature of Michelin starred, fixed priced Chef's menu dining in most cases anywhere.

Chef Kusakabe does all the knife cutting of fish. His 4 young assistants, 2 on either side, help prepare the other dishes in the Omakase. He personally presents and announces the dishes to you. Seating is limited to a long sushi bar. 

Don't ever come here looking for cheesy mayonnaise rolls and oyster shooters that you like at your local Korean/Chinese owned, Mexican made, "sushi" joint. It would be an insult to everyone here, and a total embarrassment to yourself. You might have to commit Harakiri.   

Highlights from our meal (see pics)

Welcoming Tea: Konbu cha -  kelp tea - very soothing

Sushi prelude -  Zuke Chutoro - lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in a soy sauce, plus two other seasonal nigiri sushi

Sashimi - Chef's special sashimi nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi and Yuzu onion sauce

Soup - Italian black truffle miso soup with Eringi and Shimeju mushrooms
or...
Kamo-Dango, duck miso soup with Mitsuba leaf

Hassun - Shigoku oyster with French Daurenki Caviar and four kinds of Chef's assorted petite plates

Warm Dish - "Kinki" big hand snapper, "Mizoreni" (ice/sleet-like) with Matsutake mushroom

Sushi Chic - 3 kinds of seasonal sushi of the day

Sushi Finale - Toro - bluefin fatty tuna
or....
Grade A5 Miyazaki Wagyu beef

Honto ni oishikatta!

If you want a dining experience of high end elegance, combining thoughtful fresh ingredients with simplicity and harmony, in the Kaiseki tradition, come here.  

If you want a roll dripping with velveeta sauce, go to Safeway.

excerpts: The hassun course was flawless - shigoku oyster with cavier (still drooling now as i reminisce), perfectly cooked tamago and my fave, the warm rice ball.
hassun.author: Joanna L.
hassun.review:
Im not a huge nigiri fan, but when I saw the firat nigiri, I got too excited I didn't even take a picture of the first nigiri! Every nigiri tasted wonderful, from the rice to the fish and the sauce. The hassun course was flawless - shigoku oyster with cavier (still drooling now as i reminisce), perfectly cooked tamago and my fave, the warm rice ball.

To finish, I chose the toro instead of the wagyu for my last nigiri and ordered the wagyu off the a la  carte menu. Truthfully, the Toro was way better, in terms of texture and taste.   We also ordered the kaisui uni and ankimo. Both were creamy and rich in flavor.  Wanted to the sake pairing, but we opted for a bottle of sake instead. 

The one thing I didn't really care for was the soup. The broth was nice, but the yuzu was too strong for me.

excerpts:
Soup 
Tai snapper and somen noodle with fresh yuba - the fish was tender, the soup was clear and simple but refined and delicious, with a small slice of lime really adding the right tartness

Hassun 
Shigoku oyster with French Daurenki caviar and four kinds of chef's assorted petit plats:  the oyster and caviar was small but perfect.
hassun.author: Vivian W.
hassun.review:
Kusakabe did it again.  Another divine meal.  A few of the courses were the same as my earlier visit, which was fine by me since it was delicious both times.   

Welcoming Tea:
Kelp tea -  reminds me of miso soup 

Sushi Prelude:
- Lightly seared chutoro bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce - excellent seared smoky flavor, great start to the meal
- 2 kinds of Seasonal sushi - live halibut with a dab of steamed liver on top and ponzu - was a bit chewy, but still good.  I think the 2nd was a relative of the mackerel that was also good.  

Sashimi: 
scallops and bluefin tuna sashimi - super fresh and served on ice 

Soup 
Tai snapper and somen noodle with fresh yuba - the fish was tender, the soup was clear and simple but refined and delicious, with a small slice of lime really adding the right tartness

Hassun 
Shigoku oyster with French Daurenki caviar and four kinds of chef's assorted petit plats:  the oyster and caviar was small but perfect.  We also enjoyed the mini crab claw, the small tender squid, and a slice of tuna with bonito flakes on a cube of rice.  We were not a fan of the shrimp ball with yellow miso powder.  

Warm dish:
Sansho teriyaki monkfish and its liver with soba buckwheat and nameko mushroom risotto  - another delicious combination.  The liver was perfectly seared and it was a healthy portion. 

Sushi Chic -three kinds of seasonal sushi of the day 
Striped jack - probably my favorite of the night - awesome texture 
I can't remember the other two (I was starting to get really full by this point) except that there was a white fish that was okay.  

Sushi finale:
Choice of toro or wagyu beef.  We chose the toro and it was excellent.  

We also ordered a great sake (in the  8 oz and 5 oz) since we couldn't imagine having all the sakes with the pairing.   All in all, a delicious and exquisite meal.   Great job!

excerpts: The Hassun course, of the chef's selection of petit four for our table, had the Shigoku oyster topped with caviar.
My companion and I strongly felt that the caviar did not really add to the oyster.
One of the other selections from the petit four was an anago dragon maki.
hassun.author: Lisa W.
hassun.review:
Sushi here, needless to say, is amazing in quality. I like the doing away with dipping your sushi in the soy sauce altogether, as the chefs brush the soy on each individual piece of sushi before serving it to you. I also love that it is highly recommended that you eat the sushi using your hands. The quality of the fish was sublime, and it's a little off topic but the ceramics they use for each platter are incredibly beautiful. I came here with a friend for her birthday and we got treated very well, with a delicious complimentary dessert for the birthday girl.

So why no 5 stars? I personally felt that some of the dishes that were in the omakase weren't necessary and brought the standard down a little for me, considering the price tag of $95. The Hassun course, of the chef's selection of petit four for our table, had the Shigoku oyster topped with caviar. My companion and I strongly felt that the caviar did not really add to the oyster. One of the other selections from the petit four was an anago dragon maki. For an establishment like Kusakabe, I was not expecting to have maki that seemed like a slightly upgraded version of any other restaurant's sushi. 

Can I say it was the best sushi I've ever had in my life? No. However, I would still recommend it if you don't mind forking out quite a bit more to satisfy your sushi cravings. You'd probably end up paying more than $95 a person though, that's a given.

excerpts: It might have topped last year's meal because the 'Hassun' was so exquisitely plated and delicious that it was by far one of my favorite dishes I've ever had in a Michelin-star restaurant hands-down!
hassun.author: Aggie Z.
hassun.review:
Back again a year later and to be honest, I was hesitant because my first experience was so amazing! How could it ever be topped?!

I made this reservation 2 months ahead of my birthday for a party of 4 this time. Last year, I sat at the sushi bar because it was just me and my boyfriend. Their sushi bar has 17 seats total so unfortunately, it didn't happen this time. It can only handle parties of 2 or 3. 

The meal last night was still the best sushi of my life. Honestly, if I could, I would refuse to eat sushi anywhere else (in the US... still need to go to Japan!). It might have topped last year's meal because the 'Hassun' was so exquisitely plated and delicious that it was by far one of my favorite dishes I've ever had in a Michelin-star restaurant hands-down! 

Special credit needs to be given to our server Gabriela. She's probably one of the best waitresses I have ever had in a restaurant. She was so apologetic about the sushi bar seating, which was honestly not needed because I was forewarned ahead of time that it might not happen. 
She started me off with a complimentary taste of the Dewazakura Yukimanman "Snow Country" Daiginjo Sake (~$200/bottle). She gave us small tastings of other sakes before we decided on the Masakura. She did not rush us at all throughout our meal even though a colleague of ours was running late from a meeting. My friend mentioned she wanted a glass of wine over the sake, but settled on the sake after tasting GOOD sake! During the meal, I suggested to my friend she should still get her glass of wine if she really wanted one! A few minutes later, Gabriela must have over-heard because she brought over a taste of white wine! She has excellent booze taste buds!! She brought over a very crisp, refreshing glass that went perfectly with the seafood we were having. Her kindness, her attentiveness, and her management of the pace of the meal made it a truly memorable experience for us. Thank you Gabriela! Now will you spend a weekend in wine country with us? :)

Pictures to follow the post. I'll let them speak for themselves for how amazing this place really is.

excerpts:
very satisfying
chef's sashimi (salmon and scallop) nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi & yuzu onion sauce (excellent)
agedashi style tai shinjo with japanese eggplant & shungiku sprout -- tasty flavor profile, like a shrimp ball with corn, dressed perfectly in broth
hassun course with 5 great artistic platings.
shigoku oyster with French Daurenki Caviar & four kinds of Chef's assorted Le petite plates.
mainstream flavors aimed to please.
tuna box oshi sushi.
crab claw with puffed rice cracker.
warm dish with fresh yuba wrapped analog & foie gras Toji Mushi with dashi gravy sauce and summer truffle -- awesome.
pasta like texture with a harmonious blend of flavor and light on foie.
3 nigiri with samekawa karei: shark skin flounder with seared fin, shima aji belly, and sujiko -- perfectly cured.
hassun.author: Rob C.
hassun.review:
pretty much my top favorite restaurant at the moment, deserves its star.  current omakase 1-2 hrs, sushi in kaiseki style.
welcoming tea: konbu cha, more salty an savory like a soup
sushi prelude: zuke chutoro, lightly seared, cured in soy, perfect, followed by hirame with shiso and bonito.  excellent rice--vinegar, temperature, texture, grain size and stickiness, ratio rice/fish etc--also knife work, fish freshness, grated wasabi, etc. very satisfying
chef's sashimi (salmon and scallop) nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi & yuzu onion sauce (excellent)
agedashi style tai shinjo with japanese eggplant & shungiku sprout -- tasty flavor profile, like a shrimp ball with corn, dressed perfectly in broth
hassun course with 5 great artistic platings. shigoku oyster with French Daurenki Caviar & four kinds of Chef's assorted Le petite plates. mainstream flavors aimed to please. tuna box oshi sushi.  crab claw with puffed rice cracker.
warm dish with fresh yuba wrapped analog & foie gras Toji Mushi with dashi gravy sauce and summer truffle -- awesome.  pasta like texture with a harmonious blend of flavor and light on foie.
3 nigiri with samekawa karei: shark skin flounder with seared fin, shima aji belly, and sujiko -- perfectly cured.  finale with toro.  a la carte has great selection including 3 types of uni with Kaisui deep ocean Hokkaido vs. Bafun short spine Hokkaido and Suiro long spine white.  will be back again.

excerpts:
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef.
sushi finale.author: Danny L.
sushi finale.review:
Instead of going to our Company holiday dinner this year, Lily T. & I decided to skip that and go here instead. It took us 1.5 months to find a decent reservation and the wait was so worth it. This restaurant is amazing- definitely worth the Michelin star. Reservations are super competitive though, so don't expect to last minute plan it but keep hopes!

We had the opportunity to seat right in front of Chef Kusakabe which was amazing because he explained every little detail about each fish and we saw all the finishing touch. Lily T. & I opted in for the $150 grand omakase which included 25 items. Each piece of nigiri was a die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and also added with some citrus and wasabi depending on the nigiri. I love for a fact the Chef also asks you if you're allergic to anything and if you had any favorite fish so they can do a little remix. 

Metered street parking was easily found before 6 pm. The nearest garage is 2 blocks away at the Embarcadero Garage ($3/hour after 5 pm).

Some of our highlights were:
Fatty Tuna
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef. (OMG, melt in your mouth....) 

Nice interior, excellent food, and above & beyond customer service. Not once did I need to flag down a waiter down for tea. Everyone had a smile on their face.  Major props! Kusakabe was my first Michelin star restaurant and I definitely felt the "VIP" treatment.

Thanks, Kusakabe! I'll be back.

excerpts: Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef.
sushi finale.author: Jessica Z.
sushi finale.review:
My bf and I celebrated our anniversary at Kusakabe! I've had this bookmarked for quite some time, just never had a reason to go.

I was pleasantly surprised as I had no clue where we were going to celebrate! 

We ordered the grand omakase with two hot sakes. The grand omakase consisted of 25 pieces, displayed on 7 "dishes". The entire dining experience was amazing from the start to finish. We first started off with the Ichiban Dashi, a small soup. Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef. 

After the omakase, there's an a la carte menu. My bf and I ordered 2 additional pieces each. One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni. 

Although we were pretty satisfied, we wanted to end the meal with dessert! They over heard that we were celebrating our anniversary so they gave us all three desserts on the house. So sweet! Love it. 

Overall, I was pretty blown away and kudos to the services as well! Can't wait to be back :)

excerpts: - Sushi finale.. dat toro.
sushi finale.author: Laverne N.
sushi finale.review:
My experience at KUSAKABE was truly unforgettable. I tried shirako for the first time, which I later found out was fish ballsack, but more on that later. 

So for all the wine-ing and dining Shawn C. has been doing, I couldn't have thought of a better way to return the favor than with a reservation here for his birthday. I somehow managed to secure a Friday reservation just two weeks before via OpenTable. Based on other reviews, reservations here seem to come with a hefty wait, but luckily we didn't have to experience that. 

The omakase is $95pp, with the option to order a-la-carte items at the end. It was worth every single penny. Everything was pretty amazing, mind blowing, orgasmic, you get the idea. 

I won't go through everything, but here's the special mentions:

- Every piece of nigiri was to die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and skillfully made one-by-one in front of you (if you're sitting at the bar of course). Jing was our chef for the night, he's pretty awesome. Shout-out to Jing!

- Our soup, the Yaki-Goma Dofu & Kyoto style Saikyo Miso with snow crab, was unlike anything I've ever tasted before. Sweet and savory at the same time, the dofu was textured like mochi with a hint of sesame. SERIOUSLY SO GOOD.

- SHIRAKO AKA FISH BALLSACK, or milt, "the male genitalia of fish when they contain sperm, used as food." Thanks, Wikipedia. The dish was actually called Yuan-marinated Hokkaido cod with its own Shirako & Satsuma Imo. Yes, I ate fish sperm, and yes, it was 9287473 times better than what I thought it was going to be. Perfectly fried on the outside, yet so creamy and oozy on the inside.. Okay, I'll stop now. 

- Sushi finale.. dat toro. Oh my god, it dissolved in my mouth. 

We received a complimentary yuzu sorbet for Shawn's birthday, and all the employees sang happy birthday to him! He turned bright red - mission accomplished! 

Thank you, KUSAKABE! Your food is pretty amazing, but it was your service that was the cherry-on-top of this amazing dining experience.

excerpts:
Seventh
Sushi finale, grade A5
sushi finale.author: Mike C.
sushi finale.review:
The growing trend of Japanese restaurants opening in or near downtown is clearly at a fever pitch.  Last year, a friend presented me with a gift card (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MdG5viokZhOm2Qpn12kRBQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q). Due to scheduling logistics, it's been difficult to find a person and the time to enjoy this experience with me.  On a recent Friday, I was able to make a 5 pm reservation for two at the table near the host stand, basically at the center of the restaurant.  There are only five tables available which explains the difficulty in securing reservations without early notice.  The remainder of the seating is on the L-shaped sushi bar which seats around twelve or fifteen.  After my guest arrived, here's what we enjoyed:

Amuse
Konbu cha - Translates to kelp tea, this is more like a soup to me.  Sorry, I drank this without taking a picture as I thought it was "just tea".  Perfect elixir for foggy SF evenings.

First
Nigiri toro, halibut, bonito (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DmkADPQrPhbu7Ri_PhcvaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - The first and the third were my favorites... how can you go wrong with those two?!

Second
Sashimi scallop and maguro (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rkKjr_pOWEbDC8rDxyMNDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pristine, fresh, and tender.  They were a nice contrast with one being soft (scallop) and the other firm (maguro).

Third
Umami tomato soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KJTATBDka63tOnd0NxlrGw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My eyes widened as I searched for the tomato element.  There is a large meatball at the center of this which reminds me of the chicken meatball at Delica in the Ferry Building.

Fourth
Hassun, oysters served with French caviar and four petit plates (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qyg_iiz7Brq9vioVpmRjcQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Like the second, fourth, and fifth plates (from the left) the most.  The first one was a bit fishy for me.

Fifth
Yuba wrap (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zblfKmWoBNJU3ka25XU1RQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Indulgence!  Probably my best description given that there was foie gras in the center and summer truffles shaved on top.

Sixth
Nigiri Stripe jack, salmon, flounder (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SbCSmsZ56nNn2sCv3h6Tkw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Clean flavors and nice prelude to the highlight.

Seventh
Sushi finale, grade A5 Miyazaki wagyu steak (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oy2eVTsOqhr7JkiXmBY9cQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -  All I can say, is "look at that"!

After completing the tasting menu, our waitress kindly offered us their supplement menu in case we wanted to try something else or weren't full from the original meal.  

I chose the Lobster omelet sushi (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=87ql3El1K0eKkdX_xYd-tw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  It's actually a flavored take on tamago (egg) sushi where the lobster flavor is infused with the egg.  Enjoyed this as it was an interested take, but just don't get caught up on trying to find the lobster.
There were also three desserts on the menu (one being panna cotta), but nothing was attractive to my guest so we passed.
As many described, this is authentic Japanese cuisine served in a fine dining atmosphere without the stuffy dress code.  As I walked to use the loo, I noticed a couple of awards to the proprietor as sushi maker of the year, not something that's commonly seen in these parts.  
Yes, I will be back, but need to make sure my dining companions are as open minded menu wise as me.

excerpts: The sushi finale (kuro) literally melted in my mouth and almost brought tears to my eyes.
I tried to chew slowly to keep the flavor from slipping away.

Additionally, I had mentioned that it was my boyfriend's birthday when I initially made the reservation and the restaurant was kind enough to give us a complimentary yuzu sorbet at the end of our meal!
sushi finale.author: Shannon H.
sushi finale.review:
Wow, where do I even start? I've been to Japan four times already but my experience at Kusakabe helped me remember why I keep flying across the ocean - the culture, etiquette, and of course, food. The servers are so attentive and kind! Be sure to request a seat at the bar if you can. Our sushi chef was very informative and explained exactly what each course was.

My boyfriend and I ordered the Ken (Sword) sake to compliment our omakase, and it was a great pairing. For anyone who likes a lighter, sweet sake, I highly recommend trying that one. I'm not a huge fan of shellfish since I'm mildly allergic but the crab and oysters here were simply amazing - no allergic reaction either, bless. There were so many amazing nigiri that I can't even pick my favorite but the kuro and salmon were definitely the best I've ever had. The sushi finale (kuro) literally melted in my mouth and almost brought tears to my eyes. I tried to chew slowly to keep the flavor from slipping away. Additionally, I had mentioned that it was my boyfriend's birthday when I initially made the reservation and the restaurant was kind enough to give us a complimentary yuzu sorbet at the end of our meal! It was extremely refreshing and left a great taste in our mouths, both literally and figuratively. 

I can't wait to come back!

excerpts: We ordered the chef's tasting menu and after the sushi prelude, sashimi, nigiri and sushi finale
I was still unsatisfied.
I left this place disappointed and wanting more.....
sushi finale.author: Caye Q.
sushi finale.review:
I might just be the one weirdo who didn't fall head over heels with this place. 

It's undeniable that fish is extraordinary: the Toro Bluefin fatty tuna was incredible and the grade 5A Miyazaki Wagyu was "melt in your mouth" good. But I wouldn't go as far to say that this was the BEST SUSHI EVER as most have mentioned in their reviews. For this price point and being sealed with a Michelin Star I expected so much more than what I got. We ordered the chef's tasting menu and after the sushi prelude, sashimi, nigiri and sushi finale I was still unsatisfied. I left this place disappointed and wanting more.....

excerpts: Sushi Finale:
sushi finale.author: Christina L.
sushi finale.review:
This place is OUT OF CONTROL. How much so? My fiance and I are currently trying to buy a house yet Kusakabe let us to a real discussion of whether it would be better to put our money into a mortgage or maybe just eating at Kusakabe a couple times every week. I mean, seriously, I'm sure owning your own home is overrated.

Kusakabe operates under a omakase menu style with a $95 or $150 option. We opted for the $95 option and it is pretty much set although the sushi chef has a little bit of wiggle room with 5 different seasonal sushis of the day. He will also ask you at the beginning what type of fish you usually like! Pro tip: MUST sit at the bar. After your omakase is done you can opt to go a la carte to try other types of fish. Spoiler alert: You will likely feel compelled to continue after your omakase is done, there is just so much good stuff to try!

Here's an overview of our meal. Standouts will be emphasized with CAPITAL LETTERS!
1. First brewed dashi: A light broth with tons of umami, good to kick off your appetite
2. Sushi Prelude: 
-SEARED CHUTORO comes standard and was amazing!
Two kinds of seasonal sushi of the day: 
-Hirame (Halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf) - I'm not usually a fan of halibut but this was really good quality and the shiso leaf added freshness while the liver added creaminess
-Katsuo (Lightly cherry wood smoked bonito) - Smokey flavor added a lot to this one and the smooth tuna texture had a great mouth feel
3. Sashimi course: Maguro and Hokkaido Scallop with fresh wasabe & yuzu onion sauce. Both really good quality, the scallop was sweet and delicious with a good portion and the yuzu onion sauce was intriguing.
4. Hassun: This was 7 bites served together and you are free to eat it in any order. I chose to try and eat it in order of lighter to heavier -
-Baby Eel: This was something new, not too much flavor but the broth it came in was delicious
-DUCK BREAST: refreshing to get a bite of meat and it was well cooked and served over broccolini
-Salmon wrapped in daikon: Good salmon flavor, tastes more refreshing with the daikon
-Kusshi oyster: Fresh oyster, yum
-Rice octopus: Good texture and flavor
-Tamago with snapper: This egg was super fluffy and sweet tasting, not like your usual tamago
-TORO ON BOX RICE: The toro was amazing and the rice perfectly seasoned
5. SOUP: Spring hamaguri soup with fresh bamboo shoot, wakame & shiitake mushrooms - perfect to have something warm. The clams were perfectly cooked, broth filled with umami.
6. Sushi Chic:
-BURI (Wild Yellowtail): Basically the best yellowtail ever. It had more fattiness like chutoro but tons of that delicious yellowtail flavor. See picture for amazing fattiness!
-Kuromutsu (Japanese blue fish): Very light flavor but nice bite and texture
-COPPER RIVER KING (Wild Alaskan king salmon with Oboro Konbu): Best salmon ever, so much flavor and the bit of seaweed on top gives it a touch of earthiness. 
7. Sushi Finale:
-WAGYU (A5 grade Miyazaki Wagyu strip loin): Lightly seared and salted, it's definitely the best wagyu sushi I've had. The sear is key!
-TORO (Bluefin fatty tuna belly): Ridiculous. Watching Chef Kusakabe cut this fish and then watching the chefs gingerly pass the pieces down the line and then watching your chef assemble the sushi is a ridiculous level of anticipation. And it was worth it.

At this point you're essentially devastated that your meal is over and it's time to make some tough decisions. We added:
-KAMASU: Lightly seared Japanese Barracuda - great sear flavor on a slightly fishier taking fish. Definitely a good add.
-TORO: What, again?? We needed to have another bite but this time our sushi chef seared the toro gently and added all sorts of other goodies. It completely changed up the flavor of the toro and was so worth it. MUST do again.

Next time I will add:
-KAISUI UNI (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin): If you're looking for a different type of uni this is an interesting bite. Creamier texture, lighter flavor, more sweet. We watched the guy next to us eat it jealously.
-JI KINMEDAI (Cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper): I didn't over this because I had it at Akiko's before but the guy next to us, again, said it was the best. Dammit. Next time.

All in all it was an amazing dining experience and I can't wait to go again! It is a SAN FRANCISCO MUST.

excerpts: The sushi finale is either the bluefin fatty tuna or miyazaki wagyu beef.
My giflfriend and I split one of each.
The bluefin fatty tuna just melts in your mouth and
sushi finale.author: Edward W.
sushi finale.review:
Best meal experience ever!

I made a reservation for 5:45pm on Saturday night and had requested bar seating ahead of time. We were lucky enough to be seated right in front of Chef Kusakabe! 

The kaiseki began with kelp tea, something I've never had before, but exactly how you would imagine it to taste.

The sushi prelude consisted of zuke chutoro, halibut, and bonito. The halibut was served with bits of halibut liver, adding a nice kick to each bite. 

The sashimi had hokkaido scalop and blue fin tuna nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi and yuzu onion sauce. I found the scallop surprisingly not chewy and delicious. I'd highly recommend using the sauce to give the sashimi lots of flavor.

The "kamo dango" duck and "asari" clam Miso soup with Mitsuba leaf
large clam tasted amazing and overflowing with flavor. The duck meatballs were quite a treat. 

The hassun consisted of 5 different petite plates. Cod egg, black salmon, shigoku oyster with french daurenki caviar, toro with salmon flakes, and wagyu beef. My favorite was the cod egg since it tasted the most unique. I've never had caviar before, but it just tasted salty.

The warm dish was a tofu-chwan-mushi with fresh steamed dungeness crab and nameko mushroom. It tasted so good and I wish I could have had more.

The sushi chic consisted of wild hamachi, japanese barracuda, and alaskan king salmon with sakura leaf.
 
The sushi finale is either the bluefin fatty tuna or miyazaki wagyu beef. My giflfriend and I split one of each. The bluefin fatty tuna just melts in your mouth and so does the wagyu beef because of it's high fat content. The wagyu is seared on one side and raw on the other side.
