Probably less surprised and more embarrassed since I had just seconds earlier expressed my excitement loudly to the chef about how "smooth and creamy" it was. Heeyyyyy. ‍

excerpts: Next came the ultimate in savory fattiness: a piece of toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and an exquisitely heavenly piece of wagyu beef.
toro.author: Vincent L.
toro.review:
I've gotten into the habit of marking every 100th Yelp review of mine with a Michelin-starred establishment, and I'm pleased to bestow whatever honor that's implied by my 2500th review upon Kusakabe. Although it lost its Michelin star for 2017, my experience here was first-rate, and I'm hoping it regains its star when the 2018 ratings for the Bay Area are announced this coming week.

Occupying a prime location directly underneath the Transamerica pyramid, Kusakabe is a sleek, modern venue dominated by a large sushi bar that seats about a dozen people. There are also small tables up front that seat another 10-12 people. Because of the limited amount of seating, reservations are virtually mandatory, although I lucked out by walking in as the first in line 20 minutes ahead of opening time.

Even though pricey omakase menus are a dime a dozen in the West Bay these days, I found the top-tier course to be an impressive value given the quality and quantity of the pieces of fish that came my way. In total, there were about 28 pieces to the omakase experience, including items like the amuse bouche, soup, and dessert.

To start, a modestly fatty series of nigiri that included zuke chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce), hirame (halibut), and katsuo (bonito) helped prime the appetite. Next, the relatively chewy sumi ika (Japanese cuttlefish squid) with uni (sea urchin) and sayori (Japanese half beak cured with ryuhi konbu) provided textural contrast. This was followed by a plate of hon maguro (center loin bluefin tuna), kasugodai (bamboo leaf cured young red snapper), and tairagai (ear shell clam) that offered a variety of contrasting seafood flavors. Next came a multi-course presentation of baby sea eel, wagyu rice cracker croquette, crab cake, Washington oyster with caviar, octopus with octopus roe, tuna cake, and egg cake, all of which offered unique tastes and textures.

This was followed by a palate-cleansing bowl of soup, which opened the way for a course of shima aji (stripe jack), a super-delicious piece of copper river king salmon, and ebodai (Japanese butter fish), followed further by bafun uni (Hokkaido short spine sea urchin) and a deliciously seared piece of shirayaki (fresh BBQ white eel with sansho pepper). Next came the ultimate in savory fattiness: a piece of toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and an exquisitely heavenly piece of wagyu beef. Then, a course of umimasu (lightly poached Tasmanian ocean trout), ji kinmedai (golden eye snapper) and gyoku (fresh lobster omelet with organic egg), followed by dessert, rounded out what was a truly indulgent omakase experience.

Bite after bite, everything was simply amazing. Service was also helpful and professional, and all in all it was fantastic value given the price, quantity, and quality of what I got. Highly recommended!

excerpts: Other favorites were the amazing toro, Hokkaido uni, and A5 Wagu beef.
toro.author: Allen T.
toro.review:
The Grand Omakase dinner was the best sushi meal I've ever had, even better than the Michelin starred sushi I had in Tokyo (seriously)! We had the pleasure of sitting at the bar, served by Chef Kusakabe himself. It was a pleasure watching him skillfully and meticulously prepare his kaiseki-style sushi. The chef was a very gracious host, patiently explaining in detail each beautiful piece of nigiri. 

Highlights of the meal included cod milt with uni. Milt is nearly impossible to find here in the US (I couldn't even find it in Japan). The chef gently explained that milt is "a type of egg." Since I knew what it was, I asked him if it was a "male egg" which he nodded. I've not had milt before, but I must say that it perfectly complemented the uni and it was incredible. Other favorites were the amazing toro, Hokkaido uni, and A5 Wagu beef. 

The service was friendly and efficient - our sommelier helped us choose some pleasant and crisp sake to accompany our meal, along with a nice pinot noir as the dishes got progressively heavier. 

Overall - the meal was very expensive, but also of incredibly high quality and was well worth it. HIghly recommended!

excerpts: Highlights of the meal was definitely the scallop with Santa Barbara Uni, the deep sea Uni and the O-Toro.
I feel like that is standard on what's good in all Omakase spots.
toro.author: Ada H.
toro.review:
Was able to snag reservations for a Wednesday night the morning of. I was pretty surprised since I heard it takes months to get reservations here. The reservations were for 8:15 but that was fine with me. 

My boyfriend and I were lucky enough to snag a parking spot right away and we arrived 15 minutes early. We were promptly seated. I love how kusakabe isn't too compact and cramped. 

The sushi chef asked us if we had any allergies and also asked for our preferences. I told him we liked fish on the buttery side. It's nice to know that the chefs can alter dishes.

We opted for the $98 Omakase. It was very filling but I felt like the selection in fishes lacked. Maybe we came during a season where the fish did not fit our taste buds. I was not fond of the halibut, mackerel nor the fresh water fish we had. Highlights of the meal was definitely the scallop with Santa Barbara Uni, the deep sea Uni and the O-Toro. I feel like that is standard on what's good in all Omakase spots. I was sad to learn that they ran out of akumutsu that night (my favorite white fish).

Service was friendly and we had some small talk with the chef. Overall this place is a 3.5 for me but since there is no in between I will have to give it a three.

excerpts: Chef Kusakabe asked us what we like and we mentioned that we liked Toro and Uni
and he kept that in mind.
Oh my god.
I don't know where to start, but EVERYTHING WAS SO GOOD.
He remembered what we said about the Tori and Uni because we finished our night with those two.
I just wanted to cry eating those two.
T_T Seriously, I can only say everything is good, but if you are reading this, you have to try everything for yourself to know!
toro.author: Gabriel N.
toro.review:
My stomach and my heart are both crying tears of joy, but my wallet...not so much. Still, this place was worth every.single.penny.

Amy T. and I made a reservation for 8:30pm on a Friday. We arrived at ~8:10 and was seated promptly. We were served by none other than the head chef and owner himself, Chef Kusakabe. 

We decided to go with the Grand Omakase because go big and then go home right? The Grand Omakase ($165) comes with 10 courses which ends up being quite a bit. Chef Kusakabe asked us what we like and we mentioned that we liked Toro and Uni and he kept that in mind. Oh my god. I don't know where to start, but EVERYTHING WAS SO GOOD. The starting Zuke Chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce) was absolutely divine. We were like damn if this is the starter nigiri, what the hell can be better than this? The answer was nothing because everything was delicious. We devoured everything so fast that I was sad when he told us we're at the last few dishes. He remembered what we said about the Tori and Uni because we finished our night with those two. I just wanted to cry eating those two. T_T Seriously, I can only say everything is good, but if you are reading this, you have to try everything for yourself to know! We were a good level full by the end of the meal, and they also give you a menu to order a la carte if you want more.

We also got two orders of Sake to go with our food as well. I totally don't remember what it was but they were both good! They offer a wide selection of sake ranging from cheap stuff to things I would never buy unless I was driving a Lambo or something.

Everyone here is a master at what they do. The knife skills, the plating skills, etc. It's really a wonder to watch them do their work so naturally. 

Kusakabe deserves its Michelin star and so much more. This is an insane omakase experience. They serve only the best sushi, sashimi and kaiseki. You will not be disappointed!!

excerpts: And while you are at it, at the end go crazy and get things like toro with uni, gold flakes and caviar (if available).
toro.author: Mario B.
toro.review:
Kusakabe is the place to go for a special occasion! It's some of the best sushi not just in SF but period. I've tried numerous Michelin Star Sushi places in the city and the best Sushi spots in So Cal and this is by far my favorite.  Yes, it's better than even the sushi at the Tokyo fish market (albeit more expensive; but so is a flight to Japan).

Kusakabe blends traditional and modern perfectly. It provides multiple complex flavors with each bite. It's made to please everyone and it's quite different than Omakase's edomae style, for example. It's very San Francisco's and it incorporates things like avocado. That being said it still keeps the tradition of sushi and respectfully modernizes it and elevates the flavor profiles. Nothing quite like it.

Make sure to ask to be seated at the bar so you can converse with your chef and make it a personal experience (bonus points: ask for the main Chef, Mitsunori). Ask them about why they are there and how hard they had to work to get where they are. Trust me, it will change your perspective on sushi and you'll find a new appreciation for the art (oh and if you don't know proper etiquette, they'll teach you that, too). Already experienced at fine dining and sushi? You can have more complex conversations about the specific sushi, techniques, ask for the Wagyu Beef's certificate, etc. 

I've done table seating, too, and it's a completely different experience. That being said, if you want to minimize the interactions with chefs, the staff, and want to just eat your food in peace and privacy, you can go the table route.

The food is amazing, the pairings fit well, and the staff is perfect. 

So what should you get? I'd say if you are going, might as well get the grand omakase! And while you are at it, at the end go crazy and get things like toro with uni, gold flakes and caviar (if available). Their wagyu is also A5 Grade 12! Make sure to enjoy every bite. If you are more of an expert with a developed and specific taste, you can go with the regular omakase and get exactly what you want a la carte after to maximize the customization of your meal and have more of exactly what you want.

excerpts: To end this meal, me and my friends ordered extra wagyu and toro nigiri a la carte.
You will end up leaving satisfied but not overwhelmingly full.
toro.author: Sui N.
toro.review: Best omakase I've had. I can't go back to eating cheap nigiri at regular sushi restaurants anymore! Every piece of fish was buttery smooth. I enjoyed the broth and all the other small dishes of raw delicacies which I can't remember the names of. To end this meal, me and my friends ordered extra wagyu and toro nigiri a la carte. You will end up leaving satisfied but not overwhelmingly full.

excerpts: Eel from Tsukiji Market and Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly).
An important thing to point out is we were NEVER served the Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly like the menu stated.
Instead we were served Negitoro, which is minced fatty tuna with micro onion on a roasted seaweed.
Those are two very different things, I wanted to ask why we were served the negitoro instead of the fatty tuna belly, but since my friends didn't mention I didn't want to be particular.
toro.author: Gloria C.
toro.review:
Since Kusabake is an omakase restaurant, I was hoping we can sit in front of the sushi bar to see how they prepare the sushi and serve it right in front of us. However, it was disappointing to find out party of two or more were not able to sit by the sushi bar and we had 4 people. I feel like that is part of the experience if I was to dish out $200 bucks for a meal. 

We were seated promptly by our reservation time at 8:15 and we chose the Grand Omakase because of the delicacy menu options (Truffle, A5 Wagyu beef, Hokkaido Sea Urchin, Eel from Tsukiji Market and Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly). An important thing to point out is we were NEVER served the Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly like the menu stated. Instead we were served Negitoro, which is minced fatty tuna with micro onion on a roasted seaweed. Those are two very different things, I wanted to ask why we were served the negitoro instead of the fatty tuna belly, but since my friends didn't mention I didn't want to be particular. Now that I think about it, I am quite angry that the manager didn't mention anything at all about switching our menu. 

Anyways, a review on the food that we DID have. It was a 10 course menu (with 2 soups) and it was more than enough. A tip for everyone, if you want to do a la carte towards the end, I suggest you choose the regular Omakase with less courses. Actually with the Grand Omakase, there is a course with non-sashimi/sushi dish. So if you here for the sushi/sashimi definitely choose the regular Omakase then do a la carte at the end. 

One thing to note about the sushi here is that they seasoned all their rice. At first it looked like brown rice, then we realized every piece of rice has soy sauce seasoned so the flavor is even throughout. My favorite sushi would definitely be the Oshinogi with Scallop+Uni sushi, Nata with poached egg on spoon, the uni sushi and surprisingly the Shima Aji (stripe jack) which is the chef's choice of sushi. The Hassun which included 6 small plates was also very tasty, I love how the food is like art. The wagyu beef tartare was one of the most delicious tartare that I ever had. The most disappointing course would definitely be the seared A5 Wagyu sushi, they over-seasoned it with too much pepper and salt overpowering the taste of the wagyu. It felt like they wasted a perfectly fine piece of meat, except the meat itself had a bit too much lines in it. 

Overall, I highly recommend Kusakabe for Omakase on a special occasion or if you are visiting from out of town. It seems like a popular date place, you can impress somebody by bringing them here and eating in front of the sushi bar. It's a shame we didn't get to sit there to watch as the sushi chef prepare our dishes. There might have been 1 or 2 disappointment, nevertheless it was a good experience. And I figured out why they lost their star; it was not perfect like it should be.

excerpts: - Fatty toro was the finale.
toro.author: Joanna C.
toro.review:
This was my third omakase in SF, the one with the middle price range ($95, 7 courses) but I must say it was hands down the best, and I was thoroughly impressed. 

We began with a fish broth - clear but flavourful. Not super light, but not heavy either. 
Next was the sushi starter, brimming with rich, citrusy, and smokey flavours.

--- Chef's assorted "les petit plats" ----
The following act was an assortment of 5 dishes. I loved how each element brought something a little different to the table. 

- Mackerel: I felt like it may have been a touch dry (not sure if that was the intention or not, but I think if I had to say anything about the whole experience, this was the only thing that wasn't super amazing, though it was still tasty). 
- Oyster with caviar is definitely the best oyster I've ever had. Of course, no unwanted particles (no sand whoot), and the oyster was not super briney, but rather smooth and citrusy. 
- Croquette was interesting. Sweet miso on top.
- Baby eel bowl: the flavours was very clean, crisp, and clear. The eel itself was like noodles, and it was kind of cute being able to see the little eyes as I munched away haha. 
- Barracuda sushi was the first (and last) roll sushi of the day. It was good, no complaints here. 

--- Soup and Sushi ---
- Red miso was rich but not heavy, and the duck meatball with foie gras in the centre was interesting. 
- Ika and uni with rice and sandwiches in between some seaweed. 
- Fatty toro was the finale. 

--- Condiments ---
- House made soy sauce: made with shiitake mushrooms!
- Japanese seaweed salt
- Citrus juice: lemon, line, and yuzu.

Everything presented at Kusakabe was such an experience: beautifully presented and exploding with flavours - worth every penny. I would definitely come back again!

excerpts: The toro was probably one of my favorites and of course the uni, which our chef put into at least three of the courses since we told him that was our favorite, and the eel was so good!
They get the eel fresh from the Tsukiji market in Japan which is really awesome.
The whole dining experience probably took close to two hours.
It's expensive but probably worth it.
toro.author: Jeana Y.
toro.review: This was such a great omakase experience and we were lucky to be served by chef Kusakabe himself! It's kaiseki style so some of the courses are actual plates and prepared in the kitchen. Everything was amazing and so fresh. Sitting at the bar is the best way to go if possible, because you can see everything the chef does to create your next course and realize just how many different things go into that one beautiful delicious piece of sushi. The toro was probably one of my favorites and of course the uni, which our chef put into at least three of the courses since we told him that was our favorite, and the eel was so good! They get the eel fresh from the Tsukiji market in Japan which is really awesome. The whole dining experience probably took close to two hours. It's expensive but probably worth it.

excerpts:
Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). 
The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.
toro.author: David K.
toro.review:
Kusakabe is an experience. You go for the chef-led omakase and are presented with course after course of beautifully-formed, high-quality dishes that take your palate on a little tour of Japanese flavors and techniques. The dining room is small and reservations are required, but I got to come with a group of seven friends, and it was a great experience trying and discussing all the different courses together. This is not your typical, run-of-the-mill sushi, so be prepared to splurge (the base menu comes at a hefty $98/head), and come with an appreciation for the quality and cost of purveyance of the ingredients. 

Course #1: a subtly-flavored dashi broth. Nothing unusual (after all, there are only three ingredients in this fish-based broth), but very clean tasting and a nice way to start the meal.

Course #2: The zuku chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna) was seared on one side, giving the fish a great texture to complement its flavors. The hirame halibut with its own liver had a slightly spicy kick, and the cold-smoked bonito (katsuo) resounded with the flavors of the wood smoke.

Course #3: Bluefin sashimi and poached amberjack (a surprising favorite of mine). These pieces were served simply with soy and yuzu onion sauces, and came with little slices of fuji apple and radish. You had some of every flavor here--sweet from the apple, bitter from the radish, salty/umami from the soy, and tart from the yuzu. 

Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle. But my favorite dish was definitely the soft-shell crab, which was so creamy on the inside and delicately crunchy on the inside!

Course 5: Red miso soup with a duck and lotus root meatball, layered with soy cream foam. Delicious, umami soup with layers of flavor that change as you sip, and the lotus root adds an unexpected, pleasant chewiness to the meatball.

Course 6: My favorite sushi of the meal was the shima aji, the stripe jack with daikon radish, which was so buttery in texture and had a scallop-like flavor. The cherry salmon and the kasugodai (red snapper with crystallized egg yolk) both melted in your mouth as well. Unbelievable!

Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

Course by course, everyone is served at the same time, and the staff explain each and every component--the work that goes behind each of these dishes/components is indeed immense! After the omakase meal, we were given an a la carte menu, from which we could order even more sushi or sashimi. I got the aori ika (big fin reef squid), which was extremely creamy in texture, though not particularly vibrant in flavor. 

And then we went for dessert! We ordered one of each item to share, and each of the desserts was so unique. The yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet was nice and refreshing (slightly acidic and herbal flavors), the (unsweetened kome koji) ice cream had sweetness imparted to it from the same fermented flavors that you find in sake, and the Daiginjo sake kasu crème brulee had the same fermented flavors as the ice cream, but was much sweeter and decadent.

Overall, a great meal and definitely something to experience! The restaurant itself is small but homey and authentic (the bathroom even features an automated Japanese toilet). The service is the epitome of Japanese hospitality and the prices are exorbitant, so make sure to come with an appreciation of the work, care, and quality that goes behind each bite of food.

excerpts: My other favorite roll was the Toro.
I didn't know fish
could taste like this (I guess it does at $15 extra per piece).
I also really like the Sashimi.
Oyster set was very creative.
Since it was my birthday, the restaurant gave me a sorbet on the house that I thought was really nice!
Otherwise, desert is extra.
I did still feel hungry after my regular Omakase, so I would recommend maybe upgrading to the Grand.
You're going to want to spend more on extra nigiri at the end
anyway
toro.author: Alice Z.
toro.review:
4.5/5. I came here for my birthday and the experience was great. We were literally the last ones in the restaurant the night before the news broke that Kusakabe lost its Star. Compared to Wako, Kusakabe was probably not as worth the money and the fish at Wako was of slightly higher quality than here, hence the -0.5 stars. However, it is still a reasonable meal at $98 for the quality of the fish and craftsmanship of the nigiri. I would definitely recommend trying to get a reservation if you have a special event to celebrate. 

[Omakase]
A-la-carte menu is always the best part of omakase, in my opinion. I go to experience the A5 wagyu beef nigiri, and it blew my mind. My other favorite roll was the Toro. I didn't know fish could taste like this (I guess it does at $15 extra per piece). I also really like the Sashimi. Oyster set was very creative. Since it was my birthday, the restaurant gave me a sorbet on the house that I thought was really nice! Otherwise, desert is extra. I did still feel hungry after my regular Omakase, so I would recommend maybe upgrading to the Grand.  You're going to want to spend more on extra nigiri at the end anyway so you might as well.

[Service / Decor]
Our chef was great. He explained each piece to us and, sitting at the bar, we were able to watch the nigiri come to life right before our eyes. I really like the decor of the restaurant. It was slightly larger than the overage Omakase, but still cozy and well lit. 

Overall, I think Kusakabe is a great restaurant that offers great Omakase with pricing in line with comparable restaurants. I did like Wako slightly more, but both are still worth trying.

excerpts: I also recommend that you try both the a5 wagyu and the toro...
toro.author: Sherry L.
toro.review:
Kusakabe definitely delivers a fine dining experience. Just the quality of the food and service should automatically give this place more than 5 stars. Reservations must be made in advance and I believe there are 2 seatings - one at 5 and another at 8. I made my reservation months in advance.  This place is very small and a little hidden but has a cute entrance through a curtain. The inside had a very nice ambiance going on and was very intimate. There was bar seating and a few table seating on the side but I suggest you choose the bar seating (or hopefully you get lucky enough to get bar seating) because you get the watch the sushi chefs make your omakase and have them explain each and every piece to you.

Their omakase menu changes from time to time but their dinner is priced at either $95pp or $150 pp for their grand omakase. I say you should get the grand omakase because it's so much more worth it if you're already going to spend $$$$ - might as well go all out! I also recommend that you try both the a5 wagyu and the toro... AND the UNI!! I can tell you that their uni here is to die for!! Specifically their deep sea hokkaido uni - it literally melts in your mouth and taste like heaven for a few seconds. (It is also their most expensive item on their ala carte menu) everything on their menu was just mouthwatering.

The service here is incomparable to other places - they treat you like a king and queen from seating you and even putting your coats on. They are also quick to refill your drinks/clean your tables and all other manners they are quick to address. Please do make some time if you come to the later seating. We sat down at 8pm and probably did not leave the restaurant till 11pm. Also if it's your birthday - tell them in advance!  They will comp you a item from their dessert menu. :)

excerpts: First, we got the chu toro...
It was the best I've had.
One of our boxed presentations had eels that tasted like noodles and toro in croquette form!
I ordered toro to end my meal...
toro.author: Lyra C.
toro.review:
Wow the food here is amazing!! Everything is well thought out and I literally disliked NOTHING. All of the dishes were unique and crafted so nicely.

I celebrated Valentine's day here with my boyfriend and we went all out and ordered the grand omakase. The omakase started out with a bang. First, we got the chu toro... It was the best I've had. Then... A really soft textured jellyfish unlike any I've had before topped with uni. It was delicious. A few seared items came next, the golden eye... We even had our nigiri topped with crystallized egg yolk. One of our boxed presentations had eels that tasted like noodles and toro in croquette form! The bafun uni was one of my favorite uni... We ended the omakase a bit differently, as one of our options. I ordered toro to end my meal... My boyfriend ordered the a5 Miyazaki wagyu beef. Although his last choice was good I preferred the lighter taste of fish. 

The chef's were a lot of fun to talk to as well. I had a great time here. Would definitely recommend :)

excerpts: The Zuke Toro was the most unforgettable one, so much that later on, we ordered another round a la carte.
toro.author: Monica V.
toro.review:
What can I say about Kusakabe that hasn't already been said before? Nonetheless, I want to share my thoughts on my experience on one of the best meals I've had.

With a part of three, we made reservations a couple months in advanced to sit at the bar for the full omakase experience. Doors don't open until exactly 5:00PM. Through the curtains is a narrow hall and doorway. Upon entering, the host will ask for your reservation and you will be seated in your designated spots. The space is narrow, with not very many seats, hence the limited reservations each night and it usually doesn't get too loud. 

You'll get a chance to look over their two menus: the first for omakase ($95 or $150) and the other for drinks. We opted for the $95 and some sake, of course. They started us off with some dashi broth, which was really nice on a cold, rainy evening. Then came the sushi. While there are chopsticks provided, we used our fingers for the most part. There's a bit of cloth for you to wipe your fingers on between pieces and some food items are much easier to handle with chopsticks, so there's no pressure. Each piece of sushi was so special and the taste so unique. The Zuke Toro was the most unforgettable one, so much that later on, we ordered another round a la carte. Super excited that there was some uni involved as well. Chef's assorted Les petit plats was just so pretty to look at and even better to eat.  We finished off with some tea and creme brulee. 

Our Chef Matt was very willing to answer our questions about sushi, the restaurant, his experience as a chef, etc. and interacted with us. Definitely added to our experience and understanding of what we were eating, so I would recommend sitting at the bar. 

If this is what heaven tastes like, just kill me now. Definitely worth every damn dollar and definitely will make a point to come often.

excerpts: My personal favorite was the toro, but honestly every course was amazing.
toro.author: Chloe Z.
toro.review: My boyfriend and I came here to celebrate our two-year anniversary and had the BEST omakase experience. I would say it was just as good as, if not better, than the sushi we had in Japan. Each piece of sushi takes you on a flavor journey that you wish could last longer than just the one bite! My personal favorite was the toro, but honestly every course was amazing. I ordered the Hokkaido scallop and A5 wagyu as a la carte options, and loved them as well. We ordered the yuzu sorbet for dessert which was tasty and super refreshing- I loved it! Also, they were so nice and comped it since it was our anniversary. I can never go back to eating mediocre sushi after dining at Kusakabe! It is quite pricy at $98/person (or $165/person for the grand omakase), so I would recommend coming for a special occasion!

excerpts: At the end, if you choose the Grand Omakase, you get to choose between toro or wagyu.
I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards.
I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards.
I HIGHLY recommend trying the wagyu if you haven't tried it before!
Don't get me wrong
- I love toro
and I always order it where ever I go, but only a few places have wagyu
so I recommend giving it a try!
I can't even describe the incredible taste...
toro.author: Letty H.
toro.review:
I love trying Kaiseki style restaurants because that way, you can have a variety and try a little of everything! :) We made reservations and I recommend making them at the bar so that way, they serve each nigiri to you one at a time and so you can also chat with the chef! There is street parking and some pretty cheap parking garages close by. We sat in front of Chef Ken and had an amazing time. 

For drinks, we started off with the sake flight ($50) and some Koshihikari Echigo beer ($9), which I really enjoyed - I've never tried it before and I've never seen it in any Japanese restaurants I've been to. We decided on the Grand Omakase ($150 per person), it comes with 25 items. They start off by asking if you have any allergies and what your favorite type of sushi is, then you start your dinner! 

You wipe your hands with the towel they provide and the chef explains that you eat the nigiri with your fingers and they seasoned it already so there's no soy sauce. You use chopsticks for everything else. It's really fun because they explain what they're serving you each time and they wait until you're done before they serve the next item.

I won't go into too much depth because their menu changes a little every night depending on what is fresh. I tried so many different things and even though we were served some sushi that I'm not usually a fan of, I decided to try it anyways and it was worth it because everything is so fresh and tasty. 

At the end, if you choose the Grand Omakase, you get to choose between toro or wagyu. I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards. I HIGHLY recommend trying the wagyu if you haven't tried it before! Don't get me wrong - I love toro and I always order it where ever I go, but only a few places have wagyu so I recommend giving it a try! I can't even describe the incredible taste... It was lightly salted, a little sweet, semi- seared...just amazing, trust me and give it a try!!

At the end, we had Daiginjo Sake Kasu creme brulee for dessert paired with some dessert wine, Sauternes Chateau Laribotte, Bordeaux, France 2009, which was so delicious and a great way to finish off the night. 

This restaurant can be pricey depending on what you order (if you choose to order a la carte, drinks, etc.), but the regular Omakase menu is $99 and you can always order a la carte if they don't serve you an item you want to try! Our total for 3 people was about $730, including tax & tip. Overall, I highly recommend because of the fresh food and excellent service. I'll be back!

excerpts: Since the finale is a choice of either Toro or A5 Wagyu, my bf order a la carte the one that we didn't select for our finale.
toro.author: Lena V.
toro.review:
A friend had recommended KUSAKABE to celebrate a special occasion. My bf decided to take me here for my birthday. 

They have 2 omakase menu choices. The regular omakase menu starts at $95pp for 19 items and the grand omakase menu is priced at $150pp for 25 items. We had original opted for the the regular omakase menu since I get full fast but after the first piece we were served, my bf quickly changed his mind an wanted us to upgrade to the grand omakase menu. It was so worth it.

I was full but I wasn't so stuffed that I couldn't keep eating more. The entire dining time was about 2 hours or a bit more. Each course was presented beautifully and timed perfectly. They also offer an a la carte menu for after if you find yourself still hungry. Since the finale is a choice of either Toro or A5 Wagyu, my bf order a la carte the one that we didn't select for our finale. Both are priced at $12.50 each for a piece.

Everything was so delicious. Before you get started, the chef will ask you if there's any type of fish that's your favorite or what you don't like so they can avoid serving you something that you wouldn't want to eat. 

There was just so many pieces that I don't even remember the names of each, sadly. So I can't pinpoint a favorite but each item was to die for.

I highly recommend for anyone who loves sushi and is looking for a place to celebrate a special occasion to make reservations for KUSAKABE.

excerpts:
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef.
toro.author: Danny L.
toro.review:
Instead of going to our Company holiday dinner this year, Lily T. & I decided to skip that and go here instead. It took us 1.5 months to find a decent reservation and the wait was so worth it. This restaurant is amazing- definitely worth the Michelin star. Reservations are super competitive though, so don't expect to last minute plan it but keep hopes!

We had the opportunity to seat right in front of Chef Kusakabe which was amazing because he explained every little detail about each fish and we saw all the finishing touch. Lily T. & I opted in for the $150 grand omakase which included 25 items. Each piece of nigiri was a die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and also added with some citrus and wasabi depending on the nigiri. I love for a fact the Chef also asks you if you're allergic to anything and if you had any favorite fish so they can do a little remix. 

Metered street parking was easily found before 6 pm. The nearest garage is 2 blocks away at the Embarcadero Garage ($3/hour after 5 pm).

Some of our highlights were:
Fatty Tuna
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef. (OMG, melt in your mouth....) 

Nice interior, excellent food, and above & beyond customer service. Not once did I need to flag down a waiter down for tea. Everyone had a smile on their face.  Major props! Kusakabe was my first Michelin star restaurant and I definitely felt the "VIP" treatment.

Thanks, Kusakabe! I'll be back.

excerpts: Some of the highlights of the meal: amberjack sashimi (very meaty), raw oyster and caviar (extremely fresh), akadashi soup with duck and soy cream foam (savory, rich broth and duck flavor), and the toro (phenomenally fatty and fresh).
The servers were friendly and very detailed in describing each of the items in the courses.
After the omakase, they present an a-la-carte menu so that you can order additional pieces of nigiri.
toro.author: Alvin W.
toro.review:
After many months of long wait, had an absolutely phenomenal omakase experience at Kusakabe! Came with a group of seven on a Saturday night with a reservation made a few months in advance. We arrived for the 5pm seating and received a very friendly welcome from the staff as we entered through the door.
 
We ordered the $98 regular omakase, which was a fantastic, well-decorated, seven course meal. Every item was unique and delicious - prepared extremely carefully by the wonderful chefs. Some of the highlights of the meal: amberjack sashimi (very meaty), raw oyster and caviar (extremely fresh), akadashi soup with duck and soy cream foam (savory, rich broth and duck flavor), and the toro (phenomenally fatty and fresh). The servers were friendly and very detailed in describing each of the items in the courses.
 
After the omakase, they present an a-la-carte menu so that you can order additional pieces of nigiri. Hearing very positive reviews about their A5 Miyazaki Wagyu nigiri and after tasting fantastic Kobe beef in Japan, definitely knew I had to try a piece. My expectations were high and the Wagyu nigiri blew past them with ease. The beef was super marbley and tender, and the umami and fatty juices just burst in my mouth with every bite. This is definitely my recommended must-try, extremely worth the $14 for the piece.
 
Afterwards, we ordered a couple desserts to share. We started with the yuzu and shiso leaf sorbet, which was very refreshing and tangy. Next we had their kome koji (ingredient used to make sake) ice cream, which was very unique, although unsweetened. Finally, we tried their daiginjo sake kasu creme brulee - also great, very rich and sweet creme brulee with a bit of sake kick. Very great to share with a group.
 
The bill came out to be about $115 per person pre-tax/tips. For the high quality of the food, and the very attentive and friendly staff, definitely felt the price was worth the unforgettable 3-hour experience I had at Kusakabe. Big 5 stars, highly recommend a try for sushi lovers!

excerpts: The whole menu is pretty set, but for the last item we had a choice between toro bluefin fatty tuna or grade a5
toro.author: Megan K.
toro.review:
Came here for a special celebration dinner and made reservations a month or so in advance. Make sure to request bar seating (I called in closer to the date of the reservation to confirm) for a better experience.

The Omakase menu price is very reasonable - $95 per person - and we (surprisingly) did not leave the restaurant starving (although I could have probably stuffed a couple more pieces of sashimi down my throat if I wanted... but that's what the a la carte menu is for). The menu has 8 line items and our sushi chef asked us what kind of fish we liked and catered some things to us for some of the later dishes. The whole menu is pretty set, but for the last item we had a choice between toro bluefin fatty tuna or grade a5 miyazaki wagyu beef - you really can't go wrong with either. Since there was two of us we got one of each (:

Some of the things on the menu strayed away from a traditional Japanese omakase menu - for example the bone marrow gelatin and a lamb croquette bite. I thought it was creative and added variety to an otherwise standard Japanese tasting menu, but if you're expecting something traditional like you would get in Japan, this might catch you off guard. 

Overall a really great experience, but the meal as a whole didn't really blow my mind. If you want to go all out for a Japanese dinner I would recommend Omakase over Kusakabe, or at least go to Kusakabe first to temper your expectations.

excerpts:
- Toro: my favorite of the night, it was melt-in-my-mouth deliciousness
- Kaisui Uni: deep ocean Hokkaido sea urchin was my 2nd favorite..
so creamy and sweet.
- Bafun Uni:
Hokkaido short spine uni was firmer in texture, not as sweet, more ocean-y taste.
toro.author: Vera N.
toro.review:
4.5 stars because I wasn't able to get bar seating, but rounded up. We were first on waitlist and got the call 2 days before that we had gotten seats, but no guarantees are bar seating. Since we actually came at our reservation time, we were seated at the table. Found out later that a party didn't show up, but those seats were given to a walk-in an hour later. I was pretty butthurt, but it's okay, meal was worth it and I would definitely go again just so I can sit front row.

We settled with the $95 omakase and intended to order some a la carte pieces afterwards. Everything was amazing, the service, the ambience, and especially the food. The atmosphere was warm and inviting, but also exclusive and refined at the same time. The lighting focused on the chefs and the food at our table. The service was amazing, explained each course with detail. Even brought out another beer free of charge because they had brought the wrong drink the first time. 

Highlights of my meal:
- Halibut with its own liver
- Scallop sashimi with the yuzu and garlic sauce: delicate and sweet, counterbalanced with the sauces
- Snap pea soup: different textures, the fried fish added crunch and the broth was so good.
- Wagyu beef: AMAZING, beautiful marbling
- Toro: my favorite of the night, it was melt-in-my-mouth deliciousness
- Kaisui Uni: deep ocean Hokkaido sea urchin was my 2nd favorite.. so creamy and sweet.
- Bafun Uni: Hokkaido short spine uni was firmer in texture, not as sweet, more ocean-y taste.

Overall, it was a delightful dining experience. Would have been amazing tenfold if we had bar seating, but all the more reason to come back.. Also, to get the Grand Omakase next time around. Definitely worth a pretty penny.

excerpts: Both end with toro & A5 wagyu.
Everything was presented beautifully and seasoned excellently.
There is no soy sauce or wasabi, so that's one less thing to think about.
Of course I enjoyed the buttery toro (fatty tuna).
The wagyu had beautiful marbling.
When he brought out the blowtorch to sear the wagyu, I wanted to take a picture, but he was too quick for me.
The couple next to us also wanted a picture, so Chef Ken turned on the blowtorch just so we could document the moment.
When the chefs weren't busy preparing bites of perfection or entertaining guests, they were collaborating with each other.
I was surprised to see three chefs working together to put together the presentation for one dessert.
The food was very delicious with a very solid fish selection.
What put it over the top for me was the amazing hospitality that made it a great experience.
toro.author: Joy W.
toro.review:
In an ideal world, I would like to have a well-orchestrated sushi omakase dinner on the regular for the following reasons.
- Raw fish is delicious.
- When a chef knows what s/he is doing, I'm more than happy to have the chef execute their well-thought out prix fixe menu.
- I don't have to order. Ordering is not my forte, as I am indecisive by nature. 

Needless to say, Kusakabe does an excellent kaiseki.
Reservations here are highly recommended, and require a credit card to reserve. They are only open Mon- Sat, with 2 dinner seatings a night (5pm & 8pm) and a capacity of 29 guests. 
The cancellation policy is very strict. 
- Cancellations w/in 48 hrs result in a charge of $30 per person.
- Cancellations on the same day or no shows result in a charge of $95 per person.
I have to admit I was glad that they do not accommodate children under age 5. Apparently the venue is not large enough for strollers and high chairs, but we all know that a crying infant or hyperactive toddler could ruin any dining experience. 

Mr. Joy and I were a few minutes late for our reservation, but they were very nice about it. They hold reservations for latecomers for 15 minutes. Our empty seats and place settings were waiting for us when we arrived. The dining area consists of a very long sushi bar and a couple of tables by the door. Our sushi chef explained that the restaurant design deliberately omitted the glass fish case so the patrons can easily see the chefs prepare food. The tables are also deliberately the same height, so even people who do not sit at the sushi bar can get a good view of the sushi chefs. So thoughtful.

Our server asked us the usual 'Do you have any food allergies?' We replied 'No.' She also asked if we eat raw foods, and we confirmed we do. I'm sure that is part of their protocol to double-check everything, but it would be a pity if someone who does not like raw food made a reservation here and wasted a seat.

You can choose between the Omakase ($95) or the Grand Omakase ($195). They are very similar, but the Grand Omakase is more robust in volume. Both end with toro & A5 wagyu.  Everything was presented beautifully and seasoned excellently. There is no soy sauce or wasabi, so that's one less thing to think about. Most people eat the sushi with their hands, as is the traditional way, but they do provide chopsticks too.

Of course I enjoyed the buttery toro (fatty tuna). The wagyu had beautiful marbling. The zuke chutoro (medium fatty tuna) was also excellent with a light sear on top. All the accompanying flavoring agents were excellent. I especially enjoyed the yuzu onion sauce. The only thing I wasn't so fond of was the squid and mountain yam. Once your omakase has concluded, they offer you the a la carte menu of sashimi. Each order comes with one piece. 

Our chef was truly friendly, entertaining, and hilarious as he shared stories about being a sushi chef. When he brought out the blowtorch to sear the wagyu, I wanted to take a picture, but he was too quick for me. The couple next to us also wanted a picture, so Chef Ken turned on the blowtorch just so we could document the moment. When the chefs weren't busy preparing bites of perfection or entertaining guests, they were collaborating with each other. I was surprised to see three chefs working together to put together the presentation for one dessert. 
The food was very delicious with a very solid fish selection. What put it over the top for me was the amazing hospitality that made it a great experience.

excerpts: Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef.
toro.author: Jessica Z.
toro.review:
My bf and I celebrated our anniversary at Kusakabe! I've had this bookmarked for quite some time, just never had a reason to go.

I was pleasantly surprised as I had no clue where we were going to celebrate! 

We ordered the grand omakase with two hot sakes. The grand omakase consisted of 25 pieces, displayed on 7 "dishes". The entire dining experience was amazing from the start to finish. We first started off with the Ichiban Dashi, a small soup. Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef. 

After the omakase, there's an a la carte menu. My bf and I ordered 2 additional pieces each. One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni. 

Although we were pretty satisfied, we wanted to end the meal with dessert! They over heard that we were celebrating our anniversary so they gave us all three desserts on the house. So sweet! Love it. 

Overall, I was pretty blown away and kudos to the services as well! Can't wait to be back :)

excerpts: My favorites: zuke chutoro, toro, barracuda, Copper River sockeye salmon, BBQ white eel, beef croquette, and Canadian ebi (we added this).
You can't add any items from the a la carte menu until after you've finished the omakase
toro.author: Shannon L.
toro.review:
Kusakabe is such a special place. First of all, the food is delicious and reasonable priced for what you get. We did the "grand" omakase for $150 but we got 22 items! 22! (Disclaimer: this may not always be the case.)

In my opinion, I felt that the sushi was the star here. They have non-sushi items as part of the kaiseiki but there are places like Wakuriya that really excel at that. To me, these items at Kusakabe were a little mild for me, with the exception of the beef croquette.

My favorites: zuke chutoro, toro, barracuda, Copper River sockeye salmon, BBQ white eel, beef croquette, and Canadian ebi (we added this). You can't add any items from the a la carte menu until after you've finished the omakase so if you don't want to gamble, do the $95 omakase and get more of your favorites later.

What I love most is the relaxed ambiance. I highly recommend you sit at the bar so you get your one piece of sushi at a time. It really helps you appreciate the beauty while it's on its little pedestal. And of course you get to converse with the chef making your food. That's always nice.

I giggled when I saw at the bottom of the menu that they make rolls upon request. Our chef said he hasn't received that request in the 1.5 years that he has been working there.

excerpts: Splurge on the toro and most of the time the A5 is on target.
toro.author: Cynthia C.
toro.review:
Really good quality sushi, some of the intermediary courses are doused in ponzu and sauces.

Still love the welcome tea.  

Bluefin tuna, fishy.  Bonito, wish they would replace.  

Favorites now:
-Hotate 
-zuke chutoro, can be overseasoned
-bafun uni
-sardine 
-Hirame 
-toro 

The cooked items are really just an afterthought and the sushi while good, not many are wow.  Splurge on the toro and most of the time the A5 is on target.

excerpts: My favorite is hands down the toro - you can never go wrong with toro-
but every single nigiri and sashimi serving was incredibly fresh.
toro.author: Tram N.
toro.review:
Kusakabe definitely deserves its Michelin star because the food and the customer service here is phenomenal. My dining experience was nothing short of exceptional. 

::Food
First of all, I enjoyed the $95 Omakase course very much but if I had to do it again, I would definitely pay a bit more and go for the $150 omakase course. The additional courses that you get for the latter is definitely worth the extra $50 ! Go big or go home ! 

The dinner experience went by so fast like a blur (probably because everything was delicious and it felt like floating on clouds in heaven). My favorite is hands down the toro - you can never go wrong with toro- but every single nigiri and sashimi serving was incredibly fresh. The kussi oysters and the croquette are my second favorites and lastly, if you didn't order the $150 omakase, I would definitely order the uni off of the regular menu. The uni was so light and wasn't overwhelming at all (like most restaurants). The almond ice cream was also a great finishing touch so definitely order dessert because there should always be room for dessert. 

::Service
The servicing was incredibly. Everyone was very attentive and knowledgeable. Sadly, we didn't get a chance to sit at the bar, though the experience was just as nice to have our own table. I would definitely recommend getting a bar seating to learn more about the dishes and get a first seat experience at how the dishes are prepared. Reservations aren't that hard to get if you're booking for a party of 2 but anything more than that will take a long time. It took me about 2-3 months to get a reservation for a party of 4. Definitely worth the experience and I can definitely say that I'll be back again.

excerpts: - Sushi finale.. dat toro.
toro.author: Laverne N.
toro.review:
My experience at KUSAKABE was truly unforgettable. I tried shirako for the first time, which I later found out was fish ballsack, but more on that later. 

So for all the wine-ing and dining Shawn C. has been doing, I couldn't have thought of a better way to return the favor than with a reservation here for his birthday. I somehow managed to secure a Friday reservation just two weeks before via OpenTable. Based on other reviews, reservations here seem to come with a hefty wait, but luckily we didn't have to experience that. 

The omakase is $95pp, with the option to order a-la-carte items at the end. It was worth every single penny. Everything was pretty amazing, mind blowing, orgasmic, you get the idea. 

I won't go through everything, but here's the special mentions:

- Every piece of nigiri was to die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and skillfully made one-by-one in front of you (if you're sitting at the bar of course). Jing was our chef for the night, he's pretty awesome. Shout-out to Jing!

- Our soup, the Yaki-Goma Dofu & Kyoto style Saikyo Miso with snow crab, was unlike anything I've ever tasted before. Sweet and savory at the same time, the dofu was textured like mochi with a hint of sesame. SERIOUSLY SO GOOD.

- SHIRAKO AKA FISH BALLSACK, or milt, "the male genitalia of fish when they contain sperm, used as food." Thanks, Wikipedia. The dish was actually called Yuan-marinated Hokkaido cod with its own Shirako & Satsuma Imo. Yes, I ate fish sperm, and yes, it was 9287473 times better than what I thought it was going to be. Perfectly fried on the outside, yet so creamy and oozy on the inside.. Okay, I'll stop now. 

- Sushi finale.. dat toro. Oh my god, it dissolved in my mouth. 

We received a complimentary yuzu sorbet for Shawn's birthday, and all the employees sang happy birthday to him! He turned bright red - mission accomplished! 

Thank you, KUSAKABE! Your food is pretty amazing, but it was your service that was the cherry-on-top of this amazing dining experience.

excerpts: The finale of toro and A5 wagyu was so delicious too - seriously, melt in your mouth good!
We also ordered the shrimp a la carte which was huge and you get to eat it in two ways, the body quickly poached over rice and the head deep-fried!
toro.author: Cynthia H.
toro.review:
Had one of the most amazing dining experiences of my life here last night!!! The $150 was SO worth it. Chef Nori was so kind and willing to adjust the menu to what me and my boyfriend like and he was great at explaining each dish to us. Whenever we asked him questions, he was very willing to answer them and explain too! We learned a lot about where they source their fish and the insanely quick shipping they have from Japan to SF. 

Overall, the service was on point and the food quality was just amazing - The Kaisui Uni was literally THE best uni I've EVER eaten in my life. The finale of toro and A5 wagyu was so delicious too - seriously, melt in your mouth good! We also ordered the shrimp a la carte which was huge and you get to eat it in two ways, the body quickly poached over rice and the head deep-fried! I also really enjoyed the BBQ eel with sansho pepper, super fatty eel and no bones in it at all.

This experience was more than I could've asked for and I 100% will be back!! Deserves more than 1 michelin star for sure! Chef Nori, food quality, service - all A+++++, well worth the $400 meal.

excerpts: Try both the toro and the wagyu
toro.author: Alice H.
toro.review:
Tips:

Recommend bar seating.
Try both the toro and the wagyu sushi, you won't regret it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hands down one of my favorite sushi experiences yet! I came here on the Monday after Valentines day for the 8pm seating and I had an amazing time.

Service:
- Pace of dinner was perfect: not too fast, but not too slow.
- Staff are extremely attentive and helpful. Answered all our curious questions and explained every dish to us. I never felt intimidated or out of place.
- This was my first Omakaze experience at the bar seating and our sushi chef helped us survive through it! (Thumbs up for Patrick our sushi chef!)

Food:
- Absolutely delicious. Everything from the sushi to the warm dishes to the soup.

I would absolutely come back and recommend coming to Kusakabe for all of my friends.

excerpts: For the finale, I would definitely recommend getting both the wagyu and the toro options!!
You do have to pay extra in order to have both, but definitely worth it.
toro.author: Tiffany P.
toro.review:
One of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF!! 

You have to make a reservation to get seated since they only have two seatings a night. The omakase is only $95 per person, which is super affordable compared to a lot of other options in the city, and the quality is still exceptional. It's definitely not the most extensive omakase menu, but I left feeling pleasantly satisfied, rather than too full to move. And, if you want more of a particular fish, or just want something that wasn't included in the omakase courses, you can also order additional things a la carte.

The omakase has a good mix of warm dishes, quality fish, and other courses. The non-nigiri items were really unique. Two that I remember were a soup with a small meatball / dumpling and a fish marrow gelatin type thing (part of a mini 4-course plating). For the finale, I would definitely recommend getting both the wagyu and the toro options!! You do have to pay extra in order to have both, but definitely worth it. Sooo delicious.

For dessert, I got the pumpkin pudding with caramelized sugar on top. Kind of a twist on a traditional creme brulee, with a slightly different texture. It was unique, not too sweet, and a great end to the meal.

excerpts: My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte).
Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch.
toro.author: Jennifer K.
toro.review:
I took my boyfriend to KUSAKABE for his birthday back in February, and it was quite the eye opening experience!

I've always been a fan of sushi, but this was our first time trying omakase. KUSAKABE took my love for sushi to the next level. Eat with your hands, and no need to dip the nigiri into soy sauce or add any extra wasabi; the chef puts it on your plate, and you stuff it into your mouth. Have a bottle of sake (or two) while you're at it!

My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte). Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch. :)

Can't wait to be back!

excerpts: The toro served at the beginning and the otoro at the end was extremely delicious.
It just melted in my mouth and my taste buds were in heaven.
I also had the pleasure of tasting the Shima Aji which I highly recommend!!!
Its my favorite fish and usually it tastes a little fishy at restaurants that don't treat it well
toro.author: Evelyn Y.
toro.review:
Kusakabe is definitely pricey but worth the experience. Superb service and had extremely fresh ingredients. As a resident of Vancouver I have extremely high expectations for sashimi and Japanese food and Kusakabe did not disappoint. The toro served at the beginning and the otoro at the end was extremely delicious. It just melted in my mouth and my taste buds were in heaven. I also had the pleasure of tasting the Shima Aji which I highly recommend!!! Its my favorite fish and usually it tastes a little fishy at restaurants that don't treat it well but it was perfect here with balanced flavors with the topping and rice. 

Did I mention their rice varies? This is not just your regular sushi joint with fresh fish! Each piece has other spices, toppings or different rice that accompanies the fish which was surprising and delicious. 

Overall, for two people I came in just around $400 for the grand Omakase + two beers.

excerpts: IF YOU GET THE TORO, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE $12 PUSH TO A LA CARTE
I picked the fatty tuna/toro option but it wasn't melt in your mouth tender at all...
toro.author: Elaine N.
toro.review:
East Coast Native, and this is my first Michelin star exp so maybe I had too high of expectations? 

My friend who lives here took us out because she wanted to try it. I liked the experience, small, good service. Great presentation. Surprised it actually took 2 hours - bonus it didn't feel that long. 

The food was good. My favorite was this turtle egg soup thing (I should have taken a picture of the menu). Very good. Overall quality of fish was good except for a few misses. My other favorite was the wagyu beef. IF YOU GET THE TORO, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE $12 PUSH TO A LA CARTE TO TRY THE WAGYU BEEF. It is seriously that good. Melt in your mouth good. 

I think I expected better quality fish. I picked the fatty tuna/toro option but it wasn't melt in your mouth tender at all... it was really chewy.... 

That being said, it was a good experience, but I don't recommend going out of your way. For $150 I did expect higher quality fish... especially for the fatty tuna.

excerpts: My favorite piece of the night was definitely the fatty toro.
Melt-in-your-goodness.
I could probably eat 10 pieces of that alone.
After two hours of indulging delicate, beautiful pieces of art, the restaurant gave me a complementary cream brûlée to celebrate my birthday :,)
toro.author: Annie S.
toro.review:
Breathtaking meal from start to finish, with the best seats in the house - the s/o and I had the privilege of sitting and watching Chef Nori prepare dinner. I felt like I scored a 2 for 1 deal: delicious omakase dinner and front row seats to a live cooking show.

Since I didn't know that my s/o was taking me out to eat at Kusakabe for my birthday (surprise dinner!), I didn't get a chance to read about Chef Nori. But after doing some research (not to sound creepy but I know I will come off creepy anyway), I'm not surprised at the number of awards and accomplishments that he has received.

My favorite piece of the night was definitely the fatty toro. Melt-in-your-goodness. I could probably eat 10 pieces of that alone. After two hours of indulging delicate, beautiful pieces of art, the restaurant gave me a complementary cream brûlée to celebrate my birthday :,) Such a sweet gesture and the cherry on top of a life-changing meal. 

Thank you for making my birthday a memorable one. We will be back to try the Grand Omakase!

excerpts: My favorites of the courses were the chu toro and copper salmon nigiri, although pretty much all the nigiri they served as part of the omakase were delicious.
Each piece was specially seasoned and super fresh.
I loved the turtle soup dish (can't believe I ate a cute little turtle), but  shockingly, it was amazing.
The dish with two crispy fish in a truffle sauce and shishito pepper was another favorite of mine.
Pretty much licked the dish clean because the truffle sauce was so tasty.
I also really enjoyed the 5 piece le petit sampler plate of the chefs specials.
Santa Barbara uni, bbq unagi (soft and very good), toro (amazing), chu toro (they season this extremely well, lots of flavors).
toro.author: Susan M.
toro.review:
Boyfriend took me here to celebrate our anniversary, great choice as this place has been at the top of my list for quite a while now! This was my first Michelin star dining experience and I am so glad it was as it was absolutely amazing. 

We started off with the Omakase courses which were 7 courses for $95pp. I wasn't a huge fan of the seaweed drink they give you to cleanse your palette. My favorites of the courses were the chu toro and copper salmon nigiri, although pretty much all the nigiri they served as part of the omakase were delicious. Each piece was specially seasoned and super fresh. I loved the turtle soup dish (can't believe I ate a cute little turtle), but  shockingly, it was amazing. The dish with two crispy fish in a truffle sauce and shishito pepper was another favorite of mine. Pretty much licked the dish clean because the truffle sauce was so tasty. I also really enjoyed the 5 piece le petit sampler plate of the chefs specials. Huge fan of the crispy eggplant and the tuna over rice piece. 

For the last piece,we chose the a5 wagyu sushi. I gotta say that I was not completely blown away with this piece. I actually think that Sushi Sams in San Mateo has a better A5. I mean it was definitely good, but not as amazing as I was hoping for. 

We ordered a bunch of sushi al a carte. My favorites being the kaisui uni (completely melt in your mouth!!) wish it was a bigger piece though, Santa Barbara uni, bbq unagi (soft and very good), toro (amazing), chu toro (they season this extremely well, lots of flavors). Each bite was complete heaven for me. 

This was my boyfriends first time trying Omakase and he normally doesn't like to eat raw fish other than salmon and hamachi, however, he loved every single bite of their omakase and is now addicted! Uh oh..

Their sake is also very good. I had a glass of reisling, but next time I'd probably refrain from getting this just so I could order more sushi! 

Service was wonderful. The only suggestion that I have is to be more careful and remember if people have specific food restrictions. I asked for no wasabi in all the dishes, however, we had to remind our waitress at least 3 times and there was still some wasabi in my sushi :( which took away from some of the taste for me. They made it up by giving us free dessert for our anniversary. Desserts were delicious, I would highly recommend the pancetta and I'd probably skip out on the corn ice cream next time. 

Make sure you make reservations months in advance if you want to sit at the bar and you can probably get in a months in advance if just for a table. Place is tiny and they have 2 groups for seating, one at 5pm and another at 8pm.

Would I come back? Absolutely! This place is definitely not cheap, but it's worth it to splurge for a special occasion or if you want to take yourself out for some high quality japanese food/sushi. The omakase itself is actually a good amount. It won't get you buffet full, but it's definitely enough and if you order a few pieces al a carte, you should be good to go!

excerpts: I especially loved the final course where they served us baby sweet white shrimp and toro.
toro.author: Joyce C.
toro.review:
I came to Kusakabe with very high expectations. Im probably one of the biggest sushi lovers that you'll ever meet so I was really excited to try this restaurant. Unfortunately it didn't satisfy what I was hoping for. 

My friend and I came for our end of the semester celebration. We both ordered the 95 dollar Omakase. The raw fish here is honestly really fresh and it just melts in your mouth. The halibut from the Sushi Prelude was killed 3 hours before it was served to us. However the Dashi broth was too salty for my liking. Also some items from the Hassun were not for my taste such as the lobster salad with the jelly like thing on top and the persimmon salad with the lotus root chip on top. Despite the few items that did not meet my expectations, the rest of my meal was delicious. I especially loved the final course where they served us baby sweet white shrimp and toro. 

The service here was wonderful. They brought out our food really quick and was on top of refilling our drinks. Every time they brought out our food, they would give us a very detailed explanation of what it was which is something that many restaurants lack. There were 7 sushi chefs making our meals and 3-4 servers. 

Overall, the experience was great but I don't know if I would come back again. The service and 80 percent of the meal was wonderful but if I am going to pay over 100 dollars for sushi, I expect everything to be delicious. 

Food: 4/5 stars because of the items I disliked 
Service: 5/5 stars 
Environment: 5/5 stars

excerpts: And of course we got seconds of o-toro, our favorite.
toro.author: Alice Z.
toro.review: My boyfriend took me here as a surprise birthday celebration after an afternoon from MOIC close by. We had the Grand Omakase and everything was very yummy, also had a great time with the chef. He introduced us to "cod fish roe" aka cod sperm and it was special because they're only able to serve this during the winter. It was so good we asked for seconds! And of course we got seconds of o-toro, our favorite. The uni was also delicious. I enjoyed every minute of it.

excerpts: One of the finale dishes had a choice between toro vs a5 wagyu beef, I opted for the beef, and it was yummy.
toro.author: Minerva L.
toro.review:
Zuke was delicious and was my favorite, followed by milt, and the white eel. 

Service was amazing, on point, friendly. 

I had a 5pm RSVP and basically finished around 7pm. 

Did the grand omasake with two desserts (add on) in the end, it was my bff's bday, so one of the dessert was on the house.

All of the dishes were super elegant, different, and fresh. 

One of the finale dishes had a choice between toro vs a5 wagyu beef, I opted for the beef, and it was yummy. 

You definitely do get full, so plan on coming early, with an empty stomach.

I loved the sake creme brulee!

excerpts: My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro.
toro.author: Daniel L.
toro.review:
Would love to thank Joe, Christina, and Albert for our wonderful experience at Kusakabe. This was our second time here, this time at a table instead of the bar. Food was splendid, better than anything you can get out of a plastic box or local sushi joint. I absolutely love how they carefully explained everything as it came out, and was very mindful of any allergies or dislikes in terms of food. 

They also give you an A La Carte option at the end of your omakase. My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro. My girlfriend told me the only time I make the face I made while eating those is in the bedroom. 

Service is usually something I pay close attention to, and they were very courteous and cheerful in their delivery. Sincere thanks again to Joe, Christina, and Albert.

excerpts:
First
Nigiri toro, halibut, bonito (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DmkADPQrPhbu7Ri_PhcvaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -
The first and the third were my favorites...
toro.author: Mike C.
toro.review:
The growing trend of Japanese restaurants opening in or near downtown is clearly at a fever pitch.  Last year, a friend presented me with a gift card (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MdG5viokZhOm2Qpn12kRBQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q). Due to scheduling logistics, it's been difficult to find a person and the time to enjoy this experience with me.  On a recent Friday, I was able to make a 5 pm reservation for two at the table near the host stand, basically at the center of the restaurant.  There are only five tables available which explains the difficulty in securing reservations without early notice.  The remainder of the seating is on the L-shaped sushi bar which seats around twelve or fifteen.  After my guest arrived, here's what we enjoyed:

Amuse
Konbu cha - Translates to kelp tea, this is more like a soup to me.  Sorry, I drank this without taking a picture as I thought it was "just tea".  Perfect elixir for foggy SF evenings.

First
Nigiri toro, halibut, bonito (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DmkADPQrPhbu7Ri_PhcvaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - The first and the third were my favorites... how can you go wrong with those two?!

Second
Sashimi scallop and maguro (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rkKjr_pOWEbDC8rDxyMNDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pristine, fresh, and tender.  They were a nice contrast with one being soft (scallop) and the other firm (maguro).

Third
Umami tomato soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KJTATBDka63tOnd0NxlrGw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My eyes widened as I searched for the tomato element.  There is a large meatball at the center of this which reminds me of the chicken meatball at Delica in the Ferry Building.

Fourth
Hassun, oysters served with French caviar and four petit plates (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qyg_iiz7Brq9vioVpmRjcQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Like the second, fourth, and fifth plates (from the left) the most.  The first one was a bit fishy for me.

Fifth
Yuba wrap (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zblfKmWoBNJU3ka25XU1RQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Indulgence!  Probably my best description given that there was foie gras in the center and summer truffles shaved on top.

Sixth
Nigiri Stripe jack, salmon, flounder (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SbCSmsZ56nNn2sCv3h6Tkw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Clean flavors and nice prelude to the highlight.

Seventh
Sushi finale, grade A5 Miyazaki wagyu steak (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oy2eVTsOqhr7JkiXmBY9cQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -  All I can say, is "look at that"!

After completing the tasting menu, our waitress kindly offered us their supplement menu in case we wanted to try something else or weren't full from the original meal.  

I chose the Lobster omelet sushi (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=87ql3El1K0eKkdX_xYd-tw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  It's actually a flavored take on tamago (egg) sushi where the lobster flavor is infused with the egg.  Enjoyed this as it was an interested take, but just don't get caught up on trying to find the lobster.
There were also three desserts on the menu (one being panna cotta), but nothing was attractive to my guest so we passed.
As many described, this is authentic Japanese cuisine served in a fine dining atmosphere without the stuffy dress code.  As I walked to use the loo, I noticed a couple of awards to the proprietor as sushi maker of the year, not something that's commonly seen in these parts.  
Yes, I will be back, but need to make sure my dining companions are as open minded menu wise as me.

excerpts: Also just splurge at the end and get both the waygu and toro sushi.
It's worth ittttt.
I'll let my pictures speak for itself
toro.author: Sarah I.
toro.review:
Opt for the $150 option. Do it. Don't even think about it. I compared my $150 meal to the table sitting next to us and they were def missing out on the good sushi and plates. 

As good as this place is, it's just not Japan's fish market standard. HOWEVER, it was still pretty damn good in America. 

Also just splurge at the end and get both the waygu and toro sushi. It's worth ittttt. I'll let my pictures speak for itself

excerpts: At the end, you have a choice of fatty tuna (toro) or A5 Wagyu, and I would suggest getting both for a nominal extra charge.
toro.author: Jenn C.
toro.review:
What a gem. Kusakabe is easily the best sushi restaurant in the Bay Area and likely California. We opted for the omakase (as everyone should) and thoroughly enjoyed each course. At the end, you have a choice of fatty tuna (toro) or A5 Wagyu, and I would suggest getting both for a nominal extra charge.

I have two criticisms, both of which do not concern the superb sushi offerings. First, the server failed to notice that I am left handed, despite my rearranging of the flatware/chopsticks/tea cup every time she placed something down. Any quality sushi restaurant in Tokyo would have noticed that immediately, but I know I'm just being really nitpicky at this point. Also, I would skip dessert. We split a matcha cake with red bean and vanilla ice cream and it was nowhere near the elevated level of the sushi. Not bad, but it was incongruous with the rest of our experience.

excerpts: Some of my favorites of the night were the Zuke Chutoro, Hokkaido Scallop and Uni, Cured King Salmon Roe, Ayu, Shirayaki and the Toro finale.
The ingredients they use are super fresh (they even fly in eel from Tokyo) and of the highest quality, and it really came through during the meal.
toro.author: Jessica Z.
toro.review:
I'm usually not one to drop more than $40 per person on dinner, so coming to Kusukabe was really a special occasion. I took my boyfriend here to celebrate his birthday (and as a treat for myself), and can honestly say that it was worth every penny. At $95 per person for the Omakase and $150 for the Grand Omakase, this place will definitely make a dent in your wallet, but it really is worth it.

We made reservations three weeks in advance for a Thursday night. There are only two seatings: one at 5PM and another at 8PM. We chose the later time so there would be no rush. While they can't guarantee that you will be seated at the sushi bar, you can request when you make the reservation and if you arrive early you have a pretty good chance!

We were lucky enough to have Chef Kusakabe himself prepare our meal and opted for the Grand Omakase ($150 with 15 courses and 25 pieces total). Overall, the pace of the meal was great - being able to watch Kusakabe prepare each piece was a total treat and he explained each piece to us as he was making them. Some of my favorites of the night were the Zuke Chutoro, Hokkaido Scallop and Uni, Cured King Salmon Roe, Ayu, Shirayaki and the Toro finale. The ingredients they use are super fresh (they even fly in eel from Tokyo) and of the highest quality, and it really came through during the meal. We finished the meal with a creme brûlée, and the entire restaurant sang happy birthday to my boyfriend.

Overall, the dining experience at Kusakabe was nothing short of exceptional. From the ambience and customer service to the food, this was one of the most memorable evenings I've had and I hope to be back!

excerpts: What disappointed me the most were the hassun, the toro, and the wagyu beef.
The hassun was gorgeously presented, but of all the items on the dish, not a single one stood out to me.
The toro was chewy and nothing near the melt in the mouth quality
I was hoping for.
Same went for the wagyu beef.
It was so chewy that I ended up swallowing the beef whole.
toro.author: Diana C.
toro.review:
After hearing so much about this place from friends and family, I finally decided to give this place a try. I booked the place for my birthday dinner and psyched myself up for what I was hoping to be an amazing meal. We walked in on a Friday night at 8pm for our 8:15pm reservation. My friends and I were greeted by the host in the front and promptly led to our seats at the bar. The sushi chef in front of us introduced himself to us and asked us about our preferences for fish. We went with the regular omakase over the grand one. The whole experience itself was fun. You got to watch the chef make all the nigiri in front of you.
