5. This is not solely sushi, course items include a choice of soup( summer truffle, or duck dumpling, both miso based), wagyu beef, konbu cha (which is meant to be a palate cleanser ), as well as a small plate that varies with each visit. 
6. Please note that a true omakase takes time, as each piece of sushi is delicately prepared to perfection in front of your eyes. Expect to dine for 2-3 hours and enjoy every minute of the experience.

At just 95$ per person, some may see this as a deal, others as a special occasion splurge , either way, regardless of your budget,  you are truly getting the finest fish and quality ingredients in the world at Kusakabe. You will leave feeling warm, fuzzy, satisfied and enlightened. 

I am an Uni fiend, so I love to try all of the uni types available on the a la carte menu. My favorite is the Bafun Uni, if you love uni, you will respect the way it is prepared at Kusakabe. 
I am hooked on the summer truffle miso soup, which I expect will soon disappear as we move on to winter truffle season. I am highly anticipated any new supplements to the menu as I know they will be just as delicious.
I prefer the wagyu beef over the toro option at the end of the meal, but it's personal preference as both are wonderfully prepared. I love and seek out the highest quality beef in the world.
All of the desserts are great, my favorite is the yuzu sorbet as it is so light and refreshing, yet packed with flavor.

One of the greatest aspects of Kusakabe as an establishment is the impeccable regard for simplicity of design, which is, to me, the most challenging aspect of cuisine to master. Everything, down to the sushi bar itself, which is made from a singular piece of soft, bleached Japanese wood called hinoki, is meticulously thought out and strategically placed.

I can only describe my experiences at Kusakabe as divine and addicting. I would recommend Kusakabe to all people with an open mind and appreciation for artistic cuisine and world-class food.

excerpts: The final item on the menu was the Toro or Wagyu.
My wife picked the Toro and I picked the Wagyu, and we both loved it!
So much, we got another piece.
My wife picked the Toro and I picked the Wagyu, and we both loved it!
So much, we got another piece.
If you like sushi, I'd recommend going with the Toro to wrap up an excellent meal.
toro.author: John C.
toro.review:
Best sushi in the Bay Area.

My wife is a big fan of Sushi, while I tolerate it. However, I have to admit that Kusakabe is Amazing! Fixed course meal which cost about $125 per person. Not bad for a Michelin star (and much cheaper than comparable sushi in Japan, HK or Singapore). 

The final item on the menu was the Toro or Wagyu. My wife picked the Toro and I picked the Wagyu, and we both loved it! So much, we got another piece. If you like sushi, I'd recommend going with the Toro to wrap up an excellent meal.

excerpts: so we went with the $150 selection and finished with the Toro, and we each ordered wagyu a la carte after the meal.
There was not a single piece that we did not enjoy.
Our favorites were of course the Toro and wagyu, but the barbecue eel was right there with them.
It was amazing.
Our favorites were of course the Toro and wagyu, but the barbecue eel was right there with them.
It was amazing.
After the omakase, a la carte wagyu, bottle of wine, and tip, it was just under $500 walking away.
Pricey, but well worth it for a once in a lifetime dining experience.
If we ever come back to SF, we will be paying Kusakabe another visit!
Make sure you sit at the bar so you can see the chefs work their magic with the food.
It is an amazing sight to witness.
toro.author: James M.
toro.review: After extensive research on Bay Area dining experiences, my wife and I decided to eat dinner here while we were on vacation in SF last week. Without question, Kusakabe did not disappoint! This was our first time at an omakase style restaurant, so we were not quite sure what to expect. However, we will try anything when it comes to food so we went with the $150 selection and finished with the Toro, and we each ordered wagyu a la carte after the meal. There was not a single piece that we did not enjoy. Our favorites were of course the Toro and wagyu, but the barbecue eel was right there with them. It was amazing. After the omakase, a la carte wagyu, bottle of wine, and tip, it was just under $500 walking away. Pricey, but well worth it for a once in a lifetime dining experience.  If we ever come back to SF, we will be paying Kusakabe another visit! Make sure you sit at the bar so you can see the chefs work their magic with the food. It is an amazing sight to witness.

excerpts: finale with toro.
toro.author: Rob C.
toro.review:
pretty much my top favorite restaurant at the moment, deserves its star.  current omakase 1-2 hrs, sushi in kaiseki style.
welcoming tea: konbu cha, more salty an savory like a soup
sushi prelude: zuke chutoro, lightly seared, cured in soy, perfect, followed by hirame with shiso and bonito.  excellent rice--vinegar, temperature, texture, grain size and stickiness, ratio rice/fish etc--also knife work, fish freshness, grated wasabi, etc. very satisfying
chef's sashimi (salmon and scallop) nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi & yuzu onion sauce (excellent)
agedashi style tai shinjo with japanese eggplant & shungiku sprout -- tasty flavor profile, like a shrimp ball with corn, dressed perfectly in broth
hassun course with 5 great artistic platings. shigoku oyster with French Daurenki Caviar & four kinds of Chef's assorted Le petite plates. mainstream flavors aimed to please. tuna box oshi sushi.  crab claw with puffed rice cracker.
warm dish with fresh yuba wrapped analog & foie gras Toji Mushi with dashi gravy sauce and summer truffle -- awesome.  pasta like texture with a harmonious blend of flavor and light on foie.
3 nigiri with samekawa karei: shark skin flounder with seared fin, shima aji belly, and sujiko -- perfectly cured.  finale with toro.  a la carte has great selection including 3 types of uni with Kaisui deep ocean Hokkaido vs. Bafun short spine Hokkaido and Suiro long spine white.  will be back again.

excerpts: Definitely choose the toro at the end: its to die for!
toro.author: Mel V.
toro.review:
Just as amazing as we had expected. We were at a table, but will definitely request to be at the bar next time to actually see the sushi being prepared. Our waitress was incredibly polite. What is extra nice is that even though it is an omakase menu we were asked at the beginning if there were any types of food we didn't like, such that these parts could be substituted (my fiancé doesn't like raw oysters so they substituted in I think some sort of Ankimo instead-- he was missing out the oyster was amazing.)

Definitely choose the toro at the end: its to die for!

excerpts: The menu features 10+ items in bite size portions to allow you to sample a bit of everything from nigiri to consomme with luxurious proteins including Waygu and Toro.
It takes a couple hours to enjoy but it is a unique, yet simple, experience.
Although nothing was mind blowing amazing, the freshness and care shows in the quality of the food they serve.
toro.author: Ed L.
toro.review: The single Omakase option keeps things simple in terms of ordering but be ready for an adventure. The menu features 10+ items in bite size portions to allow you to sample a bit of everything from nigiri to consomme with luxurious proteins including Waygu and Toro. It takes a couple hours to enjoy but it is a unique, yet simple, experience. Although nothing was mind blowing amazing, the freshness and care shows in the quality of the food they serve.

excerpts: Picking from various elements that we liked, he created a unique sushi for us: rice, wasabi, and toro - flame kissed by a torch just at one corer; garnished delicately with garlic, chives, and lime zest with a citrus glaze.
An incredible, multi-layered, and complex delight.
Also, don't miss out on the eminently refreshing sorbet, or the profound - almost nostalgic - brown-rice and green tea.
toro.author: Danny L.
toro.review: I am inspired.  My first review ever - in honor of a truly memorable experience.  We were fortunate to get last-minute bar seating for this elegant omakase meal.  We tried the well-reviewed $95 set (there is also a ~$150 set) - but did not at all feel that we missed out.  We were regaled by a parade of fresh, varied, and luscious sushi; deep, soulful soups; and eclectic bites ranging from oysters with caviar to perfectly fried and seasoned crab claws.  The fish was the best I've had.  At the end of our meal, our chef (chef Ngai), asked if we would like to re-taste something or try something new.  Picking from various elements that we liked, he created a unique sushi for us: rice, wasabi, and toro - flame kissed by a torch just at one corer; garnished delicately with garlic, chives, and lime zest with a citrus glaze.  An incredible, multi-layered, and complex delight.  Also, don't miss out on the eminently refreshing sorbet, or the profound - almost nostalgic - brown-rice and green tea.

excerpts: the toro is SO good.
toro.author: Lusha W.
toro.review: Came here one month after their opening and recently went back 1 year later...still great food and excellent service.  The chefs are also super friendly and easy to talk to. They take the time to ask you what type of fish you like to eat and always ask customers for their thoughts after each dish presentation.  It is just too bad each bite cannot last forever....the toro is SO good.

excerpts: I especially enjoyed the kisu, which I had never had before, and the o-toro finale was out of this world.
The truffle miso soup course was also excellent, with a depth of flavors I had never had before in a soup.
toro.author: Michelle C.
toro.review: Truly an exceptional dining experience.  If you love authentic sushi, then you really must come here.  The ambiance is very close to what you would expect to find at a similar establishment in Tokyo.  You should absolutely request seats at the sushi bar if they are available, and even better if you are seated right in front of the chef, who is a master artist.  Everyone in the restaurant is friendly, polite, and unobtrusive.  You could tell our server was truly invested in making sure we had a wonderful experience, and was excited to share her recommendations with us.  The sushi itself is incredible.  Each piece was expertly crafted, with complex flavors blending together beautifully.  I especially enjoyed the kisu, which I had never had before, and the o-toro finale was out of this world.  The truffle miso soup course was also excellent, with a depth of flavors I had never had before in a soup.  The aji was also incredible, as was the Hokkaido uni (deep sea) that you can select a la carte after the omakase menu is complete.  The chef explained each piece you received, and was also pleasant and friendly.  Kusakabe truly brings a taste of Tokyo haute cuisine to the Bay Area, something we had always lamented was missing from the restaurant scene.  We are so happy that Kusakabe is here!

excerpts: the first toro was probably the third nicest bite.
toro.author: grace l.
toro.review:
this meal was amazing. i mean, i'm the type who only reviews if i'm really mad. i just got home, and onto the computer i go. 

the chef who took care of me and my friend was incredibly friendly. he overheard me talking about ingredients i typically hate (green onion & ginger [yes, i'm a terrible asian]), and was careful to explain how they were used. I also expressed distaste for uni and ankimo--i enjoy the flavor, but very much dislike the texture (it's like snot!). i had so much ginger, green onion, uni, and ankimo tonight. it was all soooo good. everything i normally avoid, was delicate and balanced.

my friend rm came once before, and recommended the salmon with sakura leaf. that's seriously some of the best sushi i have ever had. something about the sweet nuances of the leaf...i ate 3 pieces. gluttonous.

the duck and mushroom misos were quite nice. the first toro was probably the third nicest bite. second fav was the sweet fish (ayu). 

service is sick, in the good way. rm was curious about some sweet sake describe with "yogurt." the waitress had the person who wrote the menu come out and explain it. when a neighboring guest requested barracuda for all 3 of us, and they only had 2 portions left, the kickass chef was kind enough to portion it into 3 for us.

rm, you da bes.
barry, you're number two.
i'm going to be hungover tomorrow. order the centrifuge sake. and the snow country sake.

how am i going to ever top this meal? it's only wednesday...

excerpts: The menu began with Chu-toro and ended with Chu-toro which should tell you the procession is a bit off.
In the best Omakase meals, the chef should lead you into an opus from the first movement to an finale which you enjoy a exhilarating ride of sensory pleasures.
However, the fish is some of the best cuts I've had in SF.
Some of the other ingredients were less stellar such as the Compari tomato rather than a heirloom which is just coming into season now.
The most troublesome is that after a 9-10 course meal....one should not be given an a la carte sushi menu to augment the prix fixe in case one is still hungry.
This would not be needed if it was a true style Omakase where the chef would sense your level of enjoyment as well as the adventure in your palate.
Here it is simply a prix fixe menu with supplements.
The service was very attentive and we did enjoy the experience
but it pales still to the real thing in Japan and other parts of Asia.
toro.author: Gregory C.
toro.review: We went there a week ago on the early seating and the place looked very spartan but elegant in a very Japanese way.  The sushi counter is made of a rare wood that is quite long and is the focus of the room where 'Nori' the owner/chef holds court.  The menu began with Chu-toro and ended with Chu-toro which should tell you the procession is a bit off.  In the best Omakase meals, the chef should lead you into an opus from the first movement to an finale which you enjoy a exhilarating ride of sensory pleasures.  However, the fish is some of the best cuts I've had in SF.  Some of the other ingredients were less stellar such as the Compari tomato rather than a heirloom which is just coming into season now.  The most troublesome is that after a 9-10 course meal....one should not be given an a la carte sushi menu to augment the prix fixe in case one is still hungry.  This would not be needed if it was a true style Omakase where the chef would sense your level of enjoyment as well as the adventure in your palate.  Here it is simply a prix fixe menu with supplements.  The service was very attentive and we did enjoy the experience but it pales still to the real thing in Japan and other parts of Asia.

excerpts: The non sushi items like the Matcha Ushio-jiru, fish broth Umami soup and and wagyu dish were also excellent.
wagyu.author: Daniel S.
wagyu.review:
I came for a friend's birthday and opted for their full 11 course omakase ($168 per person). They do offer a smaller omakase for $98 per person. 

Every piece of fish was crafted perfectly. Each was unique and seasoned to perfection. The non sushi items like the Matcha Ushio-jiru, fish broth Umami soup and and wagyu dish were also excellent. My favorite will always be the Toro and it was sooo good. They have a great wine / sake selection as well. They surprised my friend with a nice dessert with a candle, so if you are coming for a birthday, let them know! Service was always on point and they always made sure that our sake glasses were filled. 

They do have some tables beside the sushi bar so make sure you request to sit at the bar! Being able to watch Kusakabe was amazing!

excerpts: The menu included hot items such as matcha soup and the wagyu stew.
wagyu.author: Sylvia Y.
wagyu.review:
My dining experience at Kusakabe was everything I expected it to be.

I had the Omakase prepared by Chef Ken. As with the other Yelp reviewers, I enjoyed the bar seating as half of the experience was getting to interact with the chef and witnessing the craftsmanship first hand.

I'm not going to go into detail of every piece I had, but I liked that not every course was nigiri. The menu included hot items such as matcha soup and the wagyu stew.

Overall, the tasting menu took me on a real trip. The courses were uniquely smoky, herbal, and buttery. One of my favorites was the torched chutoro so I also got the Ji Kinmedai, à la carte, which was also torched and as equally delicious as the chutoro.

I would highly recommend Kusakabe to friends and family looking for a quality omakase restaurant for a special occasion.

excerpts: All in all my favorite was no doubt the A5 Wagyu beef, Uni, eel, and tuna.
I was quite happy (and full) by the end
wagyu.author: Bob L.
wagyu.review:
With so many omakase locations in San Francisco I was pleased to learn from a local friend that I made a correct choice in choosing this location!

We were able to book a month ahead of time with no problems online and were promptly seated when we arrived.  

Right from the get-go I can see this location has been tweaked into a well-oiled machine since despite the fact that there were easily 6+ sushi chef's working for the people at the bar AND for the people in the small dining tables, there was no sign of any chaos.  Everyone was busy but they communicated well and weren't bumping around or reaching over another person which was quite impressive to me.

We went for the 11 course omakase menu which was $168 per person (not including tip or alcohol) which may come off as steep to many people but one must remember that you're there for an experience!  All of the chefs and wait staff were knowledgeable and were keen to explain every little ingredient in every dish which was very much appreciated (though so expansive it started to go over my head after a while).  They must have sensed this as they brought me the ala cart menu to let me know exactly what we were having which was a nice touch.  

Our chef was young but very precise and I could see the focus he had on every dish.  Speaking of dishes, they were excellent and quite unique in flavor.  This establishment favors meshing of multiple ingredients to create a very delicate but complex flavor profile which is different from other sushi omakases I've been to.  

All in all my favorite was no doubt the A5 Wagyu beef, Uni, eel, and tuna.  I was quite happy (and full) by the end and they were kind enough to place a new copy of the ala-cart menu as well as the omakase menu into an envelope to bring home with you!

If you're new to the omakase experience you can always try their "petite" omakase which is 8 courses but at a more reasonable $98 per person!

excerpts: Some dishes included scallop and uni straight from Hokkaido, wagyu beef from Miyazaki, and other kinds of seafood that I've never heard of.
wagyu.author: Garrett F.
wagyu.review:
I've been wanting to try omakase for a very long time, and spent some time researching what the top omakase restaurants were in San Francisco.  There were a ton of "top 10" lists and I narrowed the restaurants down to the "top 3" because if I was going to pay a lot, I wanted the best experience possible.

After looking at all the different omakase restuarants' menus, I eventually decided on Kusakabe.  I looked on their website, and the restaurant seemed pretty popular because most of the reservation spots were taken.

As I entered Kusakabe, I noticed right away that most, if not all, the staff spoke both really good English and Japanese.

I was escorted to my seat, and ordered the Omakase.

The Omakase includes dishes you will not see at a standard Japanese restaurant, and you'll be served one dish (i.e. sushi) at a time.  When you complete each dish, the chef will work on the next dish for you, and you can watch him make it right in front of you.  Some dishes included scallop and uni straight from Hokkaido, wagyu beef from Miyazaki, and other kinds of seafood that I've never heard of.  The food is top notch; the ingredients were fresh and the chef makes your food like it's truly a piece of art.

The service is also top notch.  After each dish was presented, the components of the dish were explained.  Additionally, my water was continuously refilled, and staff asked how my meal was so far throughout the service.

This was an experience of a lifetime; I enjoyed every bite!

I highly recommend!

excerpts: My favorites include the otoro, uni, wagyu nigiri and the tofu tiramisu dessert.
The otoro and wagyu nigari just melt in your mouth, and then left a lingering, exquisite umami aftertaste.
The uni handroll has everything: the creaminess of the uni, the crunchiness of the seaweed, and the softness of the rice.
It created the WOW moment the second I put it in my mouth.
Also the tiramisu tofu dish was so delicious, and it has this unique soy taste, reminiscent of some desserts in my hometown.
Overall the best omakase experience ever, and will definitely come back!
wagyu.author: Yeya Z.
wagyu.review: I regret to dine at Kusakabe as it has spoiled my taste bud so much that I can never go back to regular sushi LOL. We sit at the sushi bar, facing directly to chef Kusakabe, and see how the magic happens from his hand to our plate. We ordered the petit omakase, which is filling enough and at the same time leaving my stomach with enough room for some a la carte dishes after. My favorites include the otoro, uni, wagyu nigiri and the tofu tiramisu dessert. The otoro and wagyu nigari just melt in your mouth, and then left a lingering, exquisite umami aftertaste. The uni handroll has everything: the creaminess of the uni, the crunchiness of the seaweed, and the softness of the rice. It created the WOW moment the second I put it in my mouth. Also the tiramisu tofu dish was so delicious, and it has this unique soy taste, reminiscent of some desserts in my hometown.  Overall the best omakase experience ever, and will definitely come back!

excerpts: Significant pieces were the baby snapper, wagyu tongue stew, eel from Tsukiji market, and of course the toro.
We were celebrating my best friend's birthday and my boyfriend's birthday.
The dessert was on the house for both of them.
I didn't like the tiramisu that much but the creme brulee was excellent.
It was a hefty bill at about $760 for 4 people, but you can splurge once in a while
no?
I was the only person in my part that didn't feel full
so I was low key disappointed in that.
wagyu.author: Veronica N.
wagyu.review:
I've heard of this place for a while and had it bookmarked. When dining at a sushi restaurant in Seattle, I asked the chef where I should go in San Francisco. He too spoke of Kusakabe. Made reservations for 4 to come eat here. Didn't see if there was any way to specify to eat at bar or at table so we sat at the table. A little disappointed for me but I guess we were able to socialize easier. Corkage fee is $25 so we brought our own sake bottle. The servers were super nice, attentive, and charming. We did the regular omakase. Every item came in a timely manner, not too soon or too late after we had finished the previous. It was a good pace. All the items we received were really light but so flavorful. Significant pieces were the baby snapper, wagyu tongue stew, eel from Tsukiji market, and of course the toro. We were celebrating my best friend's birthday and my boyfriend's birthday. The dessert was on the house for both of them. I didn't like the tiramisu that much but the creme brulee was excellent. It was a hefty bill at about $760 for 4 people, but you can splurge once in a while no? I was the only person in my part that didn't feel full so I was low key disappointed in that. Nonetheless, a wonderful experience. 

Service - 5 / Ambiance - 4 / Food - 5 / Price - 3

excerpts: Wagyu is a must.
wagyu.author: Cal C.
wagyu.review:
Good, and definitely $$$$. We were promptly seated at 8:15pm tonight, and were lucky enough to get seated at the bar.

A5 Wagyu is a must. The scallops with uni were super delicious, but we had expected that ;) The 6 small plates from Chef's selection were unique.

The eel was delicious too. Hot and crispy on the top.

Everything was good though quite pricey for what it was... Torn between 4 and 4.5. (Sorry I rounded down!)

excerpts: Let's just say we definitely over indulged in more of the toro and A5 wagyu.
It was sooo frikkin good.
They both just melted in your mouth like buttaaaaa.
wagyu.author: Amanda E.
wagyu.review:
I was in SF for work and wanted to have a nice sushi dinner when I was done with my conference. I started looking around for some sushi spots in the city. Kusakabe was actually my third choice! The first two I called had no reservations left. Let me just say, I was very happy how that all played out.

I didn't realize how amazing this dinner was about to be! We even had 2 seats at the bar, and had Kusakabe serving us himself! Talk about luck! He was so nice and accommodating, indulging me in all my questions and awe over every piece of fish he was handling.

Everything we had was delectable. One of the best omakase I've ever had. Every course was executed perfectly and was well balanced. Everyone was extremely knowledgeable, so any questions you have about the food or drinks, rest assured, you will get an answer. Kusakabe only has Omakase on the menu, but you are allowed to order a la care items after you have finished with your omakase. Let's just say we definitely over indulged in more of the toro and A5 wagyu. It was sooo frikkin good. They both just melted in your mouth like buttaaaaa. It was just ridiculous how delicious this meal was, definitely one I won't forget!

If you're in town and are looking to have a wonderful dinner and experience, I'd definitely recommend coming to Kusakabe.

excerpts: If I go ever back, I will probably get the 8-course omakase which didn't include the wagyu stew and a couple other dishes, and add a la carte sushi to encore.
The price difference of 8 and 11-course 168-98=70, for 70 dollars you can get another 6 to 7 pieces of sushi of your choice which is a better option in my opinion.
wagyu.author: Teresa N.
wagyu.review: Had the 11-course dinner, the omakase was not sushi only, it also included soup and other small plates which were cooked. Quality of sashimi was good in general, but as far as the cooked food go it was just okay. If I go ever back, I will probably get the 8-course omakase which didn't include the wagyu stew and a couple other dishes, and add a la carte sushi to encore. The price difference of 8 and 11-course 168-98=70, for 70 dollars you can get another 6 to 7 pieces of sushi of your choice which is a better option in my opinion.

excerpts: My favorites were the toro, golden eye snapper, sea bream milt w/ quail egg, wagyu beef, and scallop w/ uni.
Really the only item I thought was just okay was the fried carrot and tofu cake in broth.
But that's just being nitpicky.
They prepare these items very well.
wagyu.author: Alfie B.
wagyu.review:
I love sushi. I've done an omakase style meal before at a restaurant in Atlanta, but was really excited to see what San Francisco had to offer, which was a lot!  I ended up eating here at Kusakabe for Cinco de Mayo and selected their 11 course omakase. Long story short...it was amazing!

From the moment I walked in, I was treated very well by all levels of staff. The hostess was incredibly helpful and polite. Servers were super attentive; my glass was never less than half full. My sushi chef Patrick was very friendly and informative about each item that was presented to me.

The restaurant had a very warm, intimate atmosphere. Very inviting and good for a date night. There were all around little touches I really appreciated like the little hooks near your knee to hang any small bags, how when I came back from the bathroom my napkin was made up again, or the meticulous way they place and plate all your dishes/utensils (even positioning my pen I brought to take notes...what can I say, I'm a nerd!). They treat you right here!

As for the food...amazing. My favorites were the toro, golden eye snapper, sea bream milt w/ quail egg, wagyu beef, and scallop w/ uni. Really the only item I thought was just okay was the fried carrot and tofu cake in broth.  But that's just being nitpicky. They prepare these items very well. I still can't get over how tender and soft the scallop was; I never thought a scallop could almost melt in my mouth!  

After the meal they give you an a la carte menu where you can order more stuff if you choose (I ordered a second helping of the sea bream milt :)).  I really wanted to try more of the stuff on their menu, and am curious to see what all they offer during other seasons. This is an easy 5 stars for me. Kusakabe served some of the best sushi I've ever had in my life!

excerpts: One thing I did miss out on is the A5 Wagyu Beef
so be sure to get that (may not be on the $98 menu
so get the more expensive menu (
$165)or add it a la carte).
wagyu.author: Marlon T.
wagyu.review:
Ever since my wife has been pregnant, I've been seeking a delicious melt-in-your-mouth omokase meal that leaves you wanting more (and never fills you up). I've been to a couple other Omokase restaurants in the city and KUSAKABE has been a standard that everyone raves about so I was happy to snag a last second reservation on a Saturday.

Did it live up to the hype? Yes. Everything was so good that it's hard to choose a favorite--you're just going to want anything again. This is the best value omokase in SF (starting at $98) so don't miss out on it if you're a big fan of high-quality sushi. One thing I did miss out on is the A5 Wagyu Beef so be sure to get that (may not be on the $98 menu so get the more expensive menu ($165)or add it a la carte). Service is excellent and the ambience is best described as Japanese ceremonial (just not sitting on a tatami on the floor).

Pro tip: If you want a seat at the bar, make your reservation as early as possible and specifically request bar seating. Yes it's worth it because you can interact with the chefs and, more importantly, snap good photos of the sushi! The lighting at the bar is ideal for pictures (versus sitting at a table where it's a bit more dim (I sat at a table--see my posted pictures). Only do table if you're on a date and want to focus 100% on the other person. But, even if you were on a date you should probably do the bar!

Second pro-tip: Close your eyes as you bite into heavenly bliss for enhanced umami taste sensation!

excerpts: Next came a multi-course presentation of baby sea eel, wagyu rice cracker croquette, crab cake, Washington oyster with caviar, octopus with octopus roe, tuna cake, and egg cake, all of which offered unique tastes and textures.
Next came the ultimate in savory fattiness: a piece of toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and an exquisitely heavenly piece of wagyu beef.
wagyu.author: Vincent L.
wagyu.review:
I've gotten into the habit of marking every 100th Yelp review of mine with a Michelin-starred establishment, and I'm pleased to bestow whatever honor that's implied by my 2500th review upon Kusakabe. Although it lost its Michelin star for 2017, my experience here was first-rate, and I'm hoping it regains its star when the 2018 ratings for the Bay Area are announced this coming week.

Occupying a prime location directly underneath the Transamerica pyramid, Kusakabe is a sleek, modern venue dominated by a large sushi bar that seats about a dozen people. There are also small tables up front that seat another 10-12 people. Because of the limited amount of seating, reservations are virtually mandatory, although I lucked out by walking in as the first in line 20 minutes ahead of opening time.

Even though pricey omakase menus are a dime a dozen in the West Bay these days, I found the top-tier course to be an impressive value given the quality and quantity of the pieces of fish that came my way. In total, there were about 28 pieces to the omakase experience, including items like the amuse bouche, soup, and dessert.

To start, a modestly fatty series of nigiri that included zuke chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce), hirame (halibut), and katsuo (bonito) helped prime the appetite. Next, the relatively chewy sumi ika (Japanese cuttlefish squid) with uni (sea urchin) and sayori (Japanese half beak cured with ryuhi konbu) provided textural contrast. This was followed by a plate of hon maguro (center loin bluefin tuna), kasugodai (bamboo leaf cured young red snapper), and tairagai (ear shell clam) that offered a variety of contrasting seafood flavors. Next came a multi-course presentation of baby sea eel, wagyu rice cracker croquette, crab cake, Washington oyster with caviar, octopus with octopus roe, tuna cake, and egg cake, all of which offered unique tastes and textures.

This was followed by a palate-cleansing bowl of soup, which opened the way for a course of shima aji (stripe jack), a super-delicious piece of copper river king salmon, and ebodai (Japanese butter fish), followed further by bafun uni (Hokkaido short spine sea urchin) and a deliciously seared piece of shirayaki (fresh BBQ white eel with sansho pepper). Next came the ultimate in savory fattiness: a piece of toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and an exquisitely heavenly piece of wagyu beef. Then, a course of umimasu (lightly poached Tasmanian ocean trout), ji kinmedai (golden eye snapper) and gyoku (fresh lobster omelet with organic egg), followed by dessert, rounded out what was a truly indulgent omakase experience.

Bite after bite, everything was simply amazing. Service was also helpful and professional, and all in all it was fantastic value given the price, quantity, and quality of what I got. Highly recommended!

excerpts: I especially loved Wagyu beef for the course.
MUST TRY.
wagyu.author: Jenny O.
wagyu.review:
It was amazing experience at Kusakabe. Everyone was really nice, kind and polite. They call you before your reservation to check if you have any allergy while conferming your reservation. 

I loved their interior which had nice balance of wood tables including sushi bar with brick wall on the other side. Seperate tables were little dark compare to sushi bar. 

We had Grand Omakase $165 per person. It was totally worth it. worth every penny. I was just amazed how each dish tasted and enjoyed every single of them. I especially loved Wagyu beef for the course. MUST TRY. not sure if they make it everyday. 

I just loved this place. want to recomend people who wants to try something upscale version of omakase.

excerpts: In particular, my favourites would be the bonito sushi and the wagyu
sushi.
I'd never had bonito sushi before, but its smokey and rich flavour stuck in my mind long after the meal.
Moreover, the wagyu beef was so silky, decadent, and packed with umami that it was one of my favourites even though it wasn't fish.
wagyu.author: Karen L.
wagyu.review:
I'm a huge sushi fan and always wanted to try omakase. After researching a couple of restaurants in SF, I decided to come here for the "Grand Omakase" ($165, 10 courses). All of the courses were delicious and thoughtfully made, and watching the sushi chef create each piece made the dining experience even more wonderful.

Each course was amazing, with the perfect fish to rice ratio and just the right amount of sauce and garnish to bring out the true flavours of the fish. Moreover, I liked the different textures of all the dishes and how the dishes were ordered to make the eating experience really enjoyable. In particular, my favourites would be the bonito sushi and the wagyu sushi. I'd never had bonito sushi before, but its smokey and rich flavour stuck in my mind long after the meal. Moreover, the wagyu beef was so silky, decadent, and packed with umami that it was one of my favourites even though it wasn't fish. 

I was lucky enough to get a seat at the bar, and I'd say that half of the experience was watching the sushi chef work his magic! It was so enthralling to observe him assemble each perfect piece of sushi, and I also really enjoyed listening to the description of each course as it was being served. The servers are very professional, and the atmosphere here is upscale but not overly formal. Furthermore, the green tea that they serve tastes really good (I think it might be matcha).

If you're willing to splurge on high quality sushi and an amazing dining experience, Kusakabe is the place to be. Eating here isn't just about enjoying delicious food, but also observing and appreciating the skills of the experienced sushi chefs!

excerpts: My favorite is the soft boiled wagyu beef tongue, very very delicious, high cost-effective restaurant, highly recommended.
wagyu.author: 会懿
wagyu.review: This is a sushi kaiseki restaurant, the owner and head chef Nori is very nice, sushi rice is made with red vinegar, Katsuo is smoked, I like it very much. My favorite is the soft boiled wagyu beef tongue, very very delicious, high cost-effective restaurant, highly recommended.

excerpts: The wagyu was seasoned with salt, pepper and lemon juice -- a touch too much lemon juice IMO.
wagyu.author: Doris K.
wagyu.review:
I'm not sure how, but I was able to score Saturday reservations just under a week before the day I wanted to go. I think. Or that's what my emails tell me at least. The sushi stars aligned to make Kusakabe happen for the boyfriend's birthday *sparkles*

We planned to arrive early, not knowing how bad parking would be in the area, but we found parking easily! This meant we were about 15 minutes early, and when we walked by their doors were still locked. We strolled around the area a bit (nothing to see though), but it would've been nice if they had a sitting/waiting area for people who are early. Impossible with how small the place is though! They have enough bar seats for maybe 20-ish people, and then a couple 2-4 tops to the side. 

When they called to confirm my reservations, I asked for bar seating and I believe they said they had it available. I don't think there was an option to make a note when I made the reservations online. 

Highlights of the Grand Omakase:
- Bonito: This was smoked and topped with spiced radish. I'm not usually a fan of smokiness, but I remember really enjoying it. 
- Baby anago with quail egg: Very interesting! For a second, we were a bit creeped out since you could see the eyes but we got over it
- Hon maguro and kanpachi sashimi: The yuzu onion sauce was SO GOOD
- Red miso soup: YUM. The foam on top was such a nice addition, and the lime zest added the perfect hint of citrus. The meatball in the soup was super tender and melted in my mouth.
- Chiayu: The bamboo that came with this was so sweet, in the good way
- Nodoguro: I ordered this a la carte because we don't see it often. Such buttery, fatty goodness. 
- Yuzu sorbet: I LOVE yuzu, and this sorbet was so smooth and tarte. The perfect finish to the meal
- Creme brulee: The bf really enjoyed this as it was super creamy and not too sweet.

I didn't really care too much for the hassun (fancy assorted appetizer-looking dish) too much, but the crab claw was my favorite of the bunch. The fuji sake w/ cherry leaf had a bitterness that I didn't really enjoy, but I think it was intended. The wagyu was seasoned with salt, pepper and lemon juice -- a touch too much lemon juice IMO. 

Service was nothing less than what you'd expect at a high-end omakase restaurant. Our server was super friendly the whole time. I didn't catch our chef's name, but he was super sweet and chatted with us when he could. Like all omakase spots, each nigiri and dish was clearly explained to us. 

I'm glad to be able to check Kusakabe off my list of must-try omakase spots. Writing this review 4 months since our visit, I can't say that anything in particular stood out to me. It was a solid omakase meal in a lovely, intimate environment with great service.

excerpts: You can have more complex conversations about the specific sushi, techniques, ask for the Wagyu Beef's certificate, etc.
Their wagyu is also A5 Grade 12!
Make sure to enjoy every bite.

If you are more of an expert with a developed and specific taste, you can go with the regular omakase and get exactly what you want a la carte after to maximize the customization of your meal and have more of exactly what you want.
wagyu.author: Mario B.
wagyu.review:
Kusakabe is the place to go for a special occasion! It's some of the best sushi not just in SF but period. I've tried numerous Michelin Star Sushi places in the city and the best Sushi spots in So Cal and this is by far my favorite.  Yes, it's better than even the sushi at the Tokyo fish market (albeit more expensive; but so is a flight to Japan).

Kusakabe blends traditional and modern perfectly. It provides multiple complex flavors with each bite. It's made to please everyone and it's quite different than Omakase's edomae style, for example. It's very San Francisco's and it incorporates things like avocado. That being said it still keeps the tradition of sushi and respectfully modernizes it and elevates the flavor profiles. Nothing quite like it.

Make sure to ask to be seated at the bar so you can converse with your chef and make it a personal experience (bonus points: ask for the main Chef, Mitsunori). Ask them about why they are there and how hard they had to work to get where they are. Trust me, it will change your perspective on sushi and you'll find a new appreciation for the art (oh and if you don't know proper etiquette, they'll teach you that, too). Already experienced at fine dining and sushi? You can have more complex conversations about the specific sushi, techniques, ask for the Wagyu Beef's certificate, etc. 

I've done table seating, too, and it's a completely different experience. That being said, if you want to minimize the interactions with chefs, the staff, and want to just eat your food in peace and privacy, you can go the table route.

The food is amazing, the pairings fit well, and the staff is perfect. 

So what should you get? I'd say if you are going, might as well get the grand omakase! And while you are at it, at the end go crazy and get things like toro with uni, gold flakes and caviar (if available). Their wagyu is also A5 Grade 12! Make sure to enjoy every bite. If you are more of an expert with a developed and specific taste, you can go with the regular omakase and get exactly what you want a la carte after to maximize the customization of your meal and have more of exactly what you want.

excerpts: However I didn't really enjoy the petit plates and the wagyu tongue stew no matter if I was full or not.
Reading the reviews
I know most people love these two courses,
but maybe I have a different palate.
I liked the fish a lot more.
Honestly I don't think we would have missed out if we had picked the petite omakase.
Frankly speaking Im not being entirely fair to the restaurant since I got full half way.
So I asked my boyfriend if he enjoyed it
and he said not really.
wagyu.author: Lisa M.
wagyu.review:
3.5 stars
I made a reservation for my boyfriend's birthday online three weeks ago. Online reservation is very convenient, unlike some other restaurants calling them is the only way to make reservation. We were very excited for this meal because it was both of our first time having omakase. Seeing all the great reviews and mouthwatering photos of the sushi gave us really high expectation for this place. We were 30 minutes early(we though there would be traffic but there was none) but was seated promptly. We were given three menus: omakase/petite omakase menu, sake/wine pairing menu, regular sake/wine menu. The server didn't tell us there was an a la carte menu but I heard the server at the next table told his customers and explained the difference between the two omakase menu. I wanted to do the petite omakase and ordered from a la carte menu afterwards, but my boyfriend wanted to try the full omakase. It was his birthday so I let him pick whatever. We didn't do the pairing because we tried wine pairing at another restaurant on my birthday and I was buzzed half way through and couldn't enjoy the rest of the meal. However we did ordered an 8oz sake to drink slowly throughout the course. The first half of the menu was AMAZING. The fish were very fresh and flavorful. The second half of the menu was not as amazing as the first half. Maybe because I was getting full since I ate a lot in the morning. I should have thought it through. For the last 4-5 courses I was shoveling food down my throat without really spent time tasting them in my mouth. I was so full I had to give a few pieces of my sushi to my boyfriend. I am sure the sushi courses would taste a lot better if I had the appetite. However I didn't really enjoy the petit plates and the wagyu tongue stew no matter if I was full or not. Reading the reviews I know most people love these two courses, but maybe I have a different palate. I liked the fish a lot more. Honestly I don't think we would have missed out if we had picked the petite omakase. Frankly speaking Im not being entirely fair to the restaurant since I got full half way. So I asked my boyfriend if he enjoyed it and he said not really. The only thing he liked was the uni. But I will definitely bookmark this restaurant and come back here again with a very empty stomach so I can update a fairer review next time!

I totally forgot to take pictures of the second half courses. I was so full and just wanted to get them over with.

excerpts: We chose the regular omakase and added the wagyu sashimi from the a la carte menu.
The quality of the fish they used was the freshest I've had in the city!
Everything was presented beautifully.
We also got the sake pairing with our omakase, and unless you're willing to drink A LOT during this meal, I advise you to pass on this (it's not cheap either haha).
We got a super generous amount of sake for every course, so much that I shamefully did not finish and avoided eye contact with the server every time she took away our glasses.
Overall, it was a good experience.
Next time, I'll definitely get a seat at the bar and no sake pairing.
wagyu.author: Nancy C.
wagyu.review: Came here for dinner and got a table seat, which is more private and less interactive than a bar seat. This was my first Japanese Omakase experience, so I probably should've went with the bar seating. We chose the regular omakase and added the wagyu sashimi from the a la carte menu. The quality of the fish they used was the freshest I've had in the city! Everything was presented beautifully. We also got the sake pairing with our omakase, and unless you're willing to drink A LOT during this meal, I advise you to pass on this (it's not cheap either haha). We got a super generous amount of sake for every course, so much that I shamefully did not finish and avoided eye contact with the server every time she took away our glasses. Overall, it was a good experience. Next time, I'll definitely get a seat at the bar and no sake pairing.

excerpts: To end this meal, me and my friends ordered extra wagyu and toro nigiri a la carte.
You will end up leaving satisfied but not overwhelmingly full.
wagyu.author: Sui N.
wagyu.review: Best omakase I've had. I can't go back to eating cheap nigiri at regular sushi restaurants anymore! Every piece of fish was buttery smooth. I enjoyed the broth and all the other small dishes of raw delicacies which I can't remember the names of. To end this meal, me and my friends ordered extra wagyu and toro nigiri a la carte. You will end up leaving satisfied but not overwhelmingly full.

excerpts: Highlights were the A5 Wagyu, the Uni, and this fish (I forgot) topped with Uni.
wagyu.author: Catherine T.
wagyu.review:
Trying to not be biased.
Trying to not be biased.
Trying to not be biased.

I had the best omakase meal (BEST MEAL OF MY LIFE) in Japan. Knowing that anywhere else would never compare I was excited to try Kusakabe with a grain of salt. 

We did the Grand Omakase ($165) and I had the Sake Flight ($50). It was a mixture of sushi and special Kaiseki dishes. Highlights were the A5 Wagyu, the Uni, and this fish (I forgot) topped with Uni. While the meals were of high quality and delicious, we were still hungry after our meal. 

Service was excellent. Chef Ngai made sure to note allergies and was fun to watch and interact with as he prepared our courses. Service given by other staff made sure our dinner was enjoyable. 

I don't mind paying for a great meal, but something about this experience did not WOW me. Maybe my omakase experience in Japan did alter my expectations, so maybe my review is unfair. But eat sushi in Japan and come back and tell me you don't feel the same.

excerpts: We did the 7 course and both got a  wagyu nigiri from a la carte and that was such a good amount.
GET THE WAGYU NIGIRI!!!
This was mind-blowingly good.
We still talk about it and we regret not getting another 1....or 2...or 7
lol
wagyu.author: Jennifer T.
wagyu.review:
My BF took me here for my birthday and I have heard mixed things, so I was not sure what to expect, but Kusakabe was a treat - a damn good treat. We enjoyed the entire experience and so did everyone around us. We had a couple next to us visiting from NY, which has TONS of food, but they still thought Kusakabe was good.

They do a 7 course omakase for $98 or a 12 for $165. Near the end of your omakase, they give you an a la carte menu, so you can always order more! We did the 7 course and both got a  wagyu nigiri from a la carte and that was such a good amount. GET THE WAGYU NIGIRI!!! This was mind-blowingly good. We still talk about it and we regret not getting another 1....or 2...or 7 lol the sake creme brulee was so good as well.

I really liked our sushi chef, who took time to answer any questions and who gave me the best dang uni ever haha he must have heard the longing in my voice when I was talking about how much I love uni, because for our last course, he subbed out the fish and gave me uni!!! They recommend you eat all the nigiri with your hands so that was super fun. We didn't take too many pictures because we couldn't help ourselves from devouring everything right when it was placed on our plate....hey.....don't let the freshness go to waste!!!

Yes, Kusakabe is $$$, so it's not a place I can eat every month, but it is a nice place to go and celebrate something. TREAT YO' SELF!!!!

Disclaimer: Kusakabe does change their menu and I have heard of folks getting some MEH menus!

excerpts: We were seated promptly by our reservation time at 8:15 and we chose the Grand Omakase because of the delicacy menu options (Truffle, A5 Wagyu beef, Hokkaido Sea Urchin,
The wagyu beef tartare was one of the most delicious tartare that I ever had.
The most disappointing course would definitely be the seared A5
Wagyu sushi, they over-seasoned it with too much pepper and salt overpowering the taste of the wagyu.
wagyu.author: Gloria C.
wagyu.review:
Since Kusabake is an omakase restaurant, I was hoping we can sit in front of the sushi bar to see how they prepare the sushi and serve it right in front of us. However, it was disappointing to find out party of two or more were not able to sit by the sushi bar and we had 4 people. I feel like that is part of the experience if I was to dish out $200 bucks for a meal. 

We were seated promptly by our reservation time at 8:15 and we chose the Grand Omakase because of the delicacy menu options (Truffle, A5 Wagyu beef, Hokkaido Sea Urchin, Eel from Tsukiji Market and Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly). An important thing to point out is we were NEVER served the Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly like the menu stated. Instead we were served Negitoro, which is minced fatty tuna with micro onion on a roasted seaweed. Those are two very different things, I wanted to ask why we were served the negitoro instead of the fatty tuna belly, but since my friends didn't mention I didn't want to be particular. Now that I think about it, I am quite angry that the manager didn't mention anything at all about switching our menu. 

Anyways, a review on the food that we DID have. It was a 10 course menu (with 2 soups) and it was more than enough. A tip for everyone, if you want to do a la carte towards the end, I suggest you choose the regular Omakase with less courses. Actually with the Grand Omakase, there is a course with non-sashimi/sushi dish. So if you here for the sushi/sashimi definitely choose the regular Omakase then do a la carte at the end. 

One thing to note about the sushi here is that they seasoned all their rice. At first it looked like brown rice, then we realized every piece of rice has soy sauce seasoned so the flavor is even throughout. My favorite sushi would definitely be the Oshinogi with Scallop+Uni sushi, Nata with poached egg on spoon, the uni sushi and surprisingly the Shima Aji (stripe jack) which is the chef's choice of sushi. The Hassun which included 6 small plates was also very tasty, I love how the food is like art. The wagyu beef tartare was one of the most delicious tartare that I ever had. The most disappointing course would definitely be the seared A5 Wagyu sushi, they over-seasoned it with too much pepper and salt overpowering the taste of the wagyu. It felt like they wasted a perfectly fine piece of meat, except the meat itself had a bit too much lines in it. 

Overall, I highly recommend Kusakabe for Omakase on a special occasion or if you are visiting from out of town. It seems like a popular date place, you can impress somebody by bringing them here and eating in front of the sushi bar. It's a shame we didn't get to sit there to watch as the sushi chef prepare our dishes. There might have been 1 or 2 disappointment, nevertheless it was a good experience. And I figured out why they lost their star; it was not perfect like it should be.

excerpts: Also, the wagyu beef was seared just to the right level of tenderness, and carried a little smooth texture on top, very unique taste!
wagyu.author: Elaine H.
wagyu.review:
Grand Omakase is certainly the legit way to open up this great Japanese gem, as one gets to experience the carefully made sushi pieces, but also have an opportunity to try some of the kitchen made dishes. Michelin one star for the past two years, yet was taken away the star this year, unfortunately.

Plus: all their uni was from Hokkaido (I personally did not like Uni from the west coast - it was big in size yet less flavorful), so made it a great combo with either the scallop or the vinegar rice itself. Also, the wagyu beef was seared just to the right level of tenderness, and carried a little smooth texture on top, very unique taste!

Minus: the cooked sweet fish was a bit bitter that I did not find myself quite fond of. 

This is my first Kaiseki in the west coast and pros certainly overweighted cons. Kusakabe definitely worth a star in my opinion, compared with some of the east coast sushi places. 

Last piece of advice - don't miss the dessert part, as it was not included in the Kaiseki fixed menu.

excerpts: One sushi that I do highly highly recommend is the A5 wagyu.
The wagyu is absolutely the best thing that I put into my mouth that night.
wagyu.author: James L.
wagyu.review:
Worth every single dollar that you have. Kusakabe is the best restaurant experience of my life. 

We came on a reservation. Be sure to sit at the bar as it heightens the experience. Once seated, the server will ask for any allergies and any fish that you like/dislike. 

Once that is finished, you start your dining experience right away. The have to menu's to pick from, one that costs $98 per head or the one that costs $150 per head. We opted to go for the $98 per head. The menu is a 20 course meal with a chance at the end to order a la carte. 

I will not explain every singe course but it was just a symphony of flavors that took you on a dining journey. Kusakabe will have you experience all types of emotions. There was times where I caught myself laughing for no apparent reason. The food here will make you feel some type of way. One sushi that I do highly highly recommend is the A5 wagyu. The wagyu is absolutely the best thing that I put into my mouth that night. It was an indescribable moment, it is just something people need to have when here. 

Kusakabe is the best dining experience that I've been to, and it will be yours as well.

excerpts: To finish our meal we tried the wagyu beef which is a must!!!
It's included in the grand omakase and available on the a la carte menu.
wagyu.author: Melissa M.
wagyu.review:
Made a reservation two months in advance for the bf and I. We celebrated his birthday and were lucky enough to get bar seating. We chose the 8:00pm seating time, figured it would allow us to eat at our own pace and not be rushed for time. 

The place itself is beautiful, clean, and the service was amazing. Friendly hosts, servers and sushi chefs made the entire experience even more enjoyable. We were so happy to get bar seating. We checked in early around 7:30 hoping that if we came in early it would determine our seating place. However, it looks like it depends on how early you make your reservations and your party size. The smaller the party and the earlier you reserve, you'll likely get a bar seat. 

We started with a nice warm hand towel and then the dashi broth which was honestly one of my favorite parts of the meal. We decided to chose the regular omakase and order a la carte afterwards. Some highlights from our meal was of course the dashi broth, blue fin tuna, red miso broth, and the list goes on. Everything was wonderfully made and delicious. I found myself closing my eyes and thinking holy crap with every bite I had. To finish our meal we tried the wagyu beef which is a must!!! It's included in the grand omakase and available on the a la carte menu. Definitely worth the $14 for each piece. 

All in all, this is a must if you're a fan of sushi or if you're celebrating an event. From the service to the food to the overall experience, it was amazing. I seriously felt like I was on a high because it was just such an awesome time. I was dreaming about my meal for days after and I can't wait to have an excuse to go back.

excerpts: Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle.
wagyu.author: David K.
wagyu.review:
Kusakabe is an experience. You go for the chef-led omakase and are presented with course after course of beautifully-formed, high-quality dishes that take your palate on a little tour of Japanese flavors and techniques. The dining room is small and reservations are required, but I got to come with a group of seven friends, and it was a great experience trying and discussing all the different courses together. This is not your typical, run-of-the-mill sushi, so be prepared to splurge (the base menu comes at a hefty $98/head), and come with an appreciation for the quality and cost of purveyance of the ingredients. 

Course #1: a subtly-flavored dashi broth. Nothing unusual (after all, there are only three ingredients in this fish-based broth), but very clean tasting and a nice way to start the meal.

Course #2: The zuku chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna) was seared on one side, giving the fish a great texture to complement its flavors. The hirame halibut with its own liver had a slightly spicy kick, and the cold-smoked bonito (katsuo) resounded with the flavors of the wood smoke.

Course #3: Bluefin sashimi and poached amberjack (a surprising favorite of mine). These pieces were served simply with soy and yuzu onion sauces, and came with little slices of fuji apple and radish. You had some of every flavor here--sweet from the apple, bitter from the radish, salty/umami from the soy, and tart from the yuzu. 

Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle. But my favorite dish was definitely the soft-shell crab, which was so creamy on the inside and delicately crunchy on the inside!

Course 5: Red miso soup with a duck and lotus root meatball, layered with soy cream foam. Delicious, umami soup with layers of flavor that change as you sip, and the lotus root adds an unexpected, pleasant chewiness to the meatball.

Course 6: My favorite sushi of the meal was the shima aji, the stripe jack with daikon radish, which was so buttery in texture and had a scallop-like flavor. The cherry salmon and the kasugodai (red snapper with crystallized egg yolk) both melted in your mouth as well. Unbelievable!

Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

Course by course, everyone is served at the same time, and the staff explain each and every component--the work that goes behind each of these dishes/components is indeed immense! After the omakase meal, we were given an a la carte menu, from which we could order even more sushi or sashimi. I got the aori ika (big fin reef squid), which was extremely creamy in texture, though not particularly vibrant in flavor. 

And then we went for dessert! We ordered one of each item to share, and each of the desserts was so unique. The yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet was nice and refreshing (slightly acidic and herbal flavors), the (unsweetened kome koji) ice cream had sweetness imparted to it from the same fermented flavors that you find in sake, and the Daiginjo sake kasu crème brulee had the same fermented flavors as the ice cream, but was much sweeter and decadent.

Overall, a great meal and definitely something to experience! The restaurant itself is small but homey and authentic (the bathroom even features an automated Japanese toilet). The service is the epitome of Japanese hospitality and the prices are exorbitant, so make sure to come with an appreciation of the work, care, and quality that goes behind each bite of food.

excerpts: I go to experience the A5 wagyu beef nigiri, and it blew my mind.
wagyu.author: Alice Z.
wagyu.review:
4.5/5. I came here for my birthday and the experience was great. We were literally the last ones in the restaurant the night before the news broke that Kusakabe lost its Star. Compared to Wako, Kusakabe was probably not as worth the money and the fish at Wako was of slightly higher quality than here, hence the -0.5 stars. However, it is still a reasonable meal at $98 for the quality of the fish and craftsmanship of the nigiri. I would definitely recommend trying to get a reservation if you have a special event to celebrate. 

[Omakase]
A-la-carte menu is always the best part of omakase, in my opinion. I go to experience the A5 wagyu beef nigiri, and it blew my mind. My other favorite roll was the Toro. I didn't know fish could taste like this (I guess it does at $15 extra per piece). I also really like the Sashimi. Oyster set was very creative. Since it was my birthday, the restaurant gave me a sorbet on the house that I thought was really nice! Otherwise, desert is extra. I did still feel hungry after my regular Omakase, so I would recommend maybe upgrading to the Grand.  You're going to want to spend more on extra nigiri at the end anyway so you might as well.

[Service / Decor]
Our chef was great. He explained each piece to us and, sitting at the bar, we were able to watch the nigiri come to life right before our eyes. I really like the decor of the restaurant. It was slightly larger than the overage Omakase, but still cozy and well lit. 

Overall, I think Kusakabe is a great restaurant that offers great Omakase with pricing in line with comparable restaurants. I did like Wako slightly more, but both are still worth trying.

excerpts: It mainly has sushi and with A5 Wagyu and soup.
All of them are pretty good.
Recommend tofu tiramisu~
wagyu.author: 碧晴
wagyu.review:
My boyfriend and I have Grand Omakase, which contains 11 courses. It mainly has sushi and with A5 Wagyu and soup. All of them are pretty good. 
Recommend tofu tiramisu~

excerpts: I also recommend that you try both the a5 wagyu and the toro...
wagyu.author: Sherry L.
wagyu.review:
Kusakabe definitely delivers a fine dining experience. Just the quality of the food and service should automatically give this place more than 5 stars. Reservations must be made in advance and I believe there are 2 seatings - one at 5 and another at 8. I made my reservation months in advance.  This place is very small and a little hidden but has a cute entrance through a curtain. The inside had a very nice ambiance going on and was very intimate. There was bar seating and a few table seating on the side but I suggest you choose the bar seating (or hopefully you get lucky enough to get bar seating) because you get the watch the sushi chefs make your omakase and have them explain each and every piece to you.

Their omakase menu changes from time to time but their dinner is priced at either $95pp or $150 pp for their grand omakase. I say you should get the grand omakase because it's so much more worth it if you're already going to spend $$$$ - might as well go all out! I also recommend that you try both the a5 wagyu and the toro... AND the UNI!! I can tell you that their uni here is to die for!! Specifically their deep sea hokkaido uni - it literally melts in your mouth and taste like heaven for a few seconds. (It is also their most expensive item on their ala carte menu) everything on their menu was just mouthwatering.

The service here is incomparable to other places - they treat you like a king and queen from seating you and even putting your coats on. They are also quick to refill your drinks/clean your tables and all other manners they are quick to address. Please do make some time if you come to the later seating. We sat down at 8pm and probably did not leave the restaurant till 11pm. Also if it's your birthday - tell them in advance!  They will comp you a item from their dessert menu. :)

excerpts: My boyfriend ordered the a5 Miyazaki wagyu beef.
Although his last choice was good
wagyu.author: Lyra C.
wagyu.review:
Wow the food here is amazing!! Everything is well thought out and I literally disliked NOTHING. All of the dishes were unique and crafted so nicely.

I celebrated Valentine's day here with my boyfriend and we went all out and ordered the grand omakase. The omakase started out with a bang. First, we got the chu toro... It was the best I've had. Then... A really soft textured jellyfish unlike any I've had before topped with uni. It was delicious. A few seared items came next, the golden eye... We even had our nigiri topped with crystallized egg yolk. One of our boxed presentations had eels that tasted like noodles and toro in croquette form! The bafun uni was one of my favorite uni... We ended the omakase a bit differently, as one of our options. I ordered toro to end my meal... My boyfriend ordered the a5 Miyazaki wagyu beef. Although his last choice was good I preferred the lighter taste of fish. 

The chef's were a lot of fun to talk to as well. I had a great time here. Would definitely recommend :)

excerpts: The biggest difference is the wagyu dish.
We chose the omakase.
While there are technically 11 courses, some come with multiple pieces of sushi or bites of food.
Overall, I was very happy with the quality and preparation of food.
It is comparable to some of the best places I've been in NYC.
My only complaint is that for $168, it should have included dessert.
We got the yuzu shiso leaf sorbet which was light and refreshing but feel it should have been included.
My husband's favorite course was the wagyu; mine was the scallop
wagyu.author: Musetta S.
wagyu.review: Definitely one of the best omakase places in SF. There are two menu options: petit omakase ($98 for 8 courses) or omakase ($168 for 11). The biggest difference is the wagyu dish. We chose the omakase. While there are technically 11 courses, some come with multiple pieces of sushi or bites of food. Overall, I was very happy with the quality and preparation of food. It is comparable to some of the best places I've been in NYC. My only complaint is that for $168, it should have included dessert. We got the yuzu shiso leaf sorbet which was light and refreshing but feel it should have been included. My husband's favorite course was the wagyu; mine was the scallop

excerpts: I ordered the Hokkaido scallop and A5 wagyu as a la carte options, and loved them as well.
We ordered the yuzu sorbet for dessert which was tasty and super refreshing-
I loved it!
Also, they were so nice and comped it since it was our anniversary.
I can never go back to eating mediocre sushi after dining at Kusakabe!
It is quite pricy at $98/person (or $165/person for the grand omakase), so I would recommend coming for a special occasion!
wagyu.author: Chloe Z.
wagyu.review: My boyfriend and I came here to celebrate our two-year anniversary and had the BEST omakase experience. I would say it was just as good as, if not better, than the sushi we had in Japan. Each piece of sushi takes you on a flavor journey that you wish could last longer than just the one bite! My personal favorite was the toro, but honestly every course was amazing. I ordered the Hokkaido scallop and A5 wagyu as a la carte options, and loved them as well. We ordered the yuzu sorbet for dessert which was tasty and super refreshing- I loved it! Also, they were so nice and comped it since it was our anniversary. I can never go back to eating mediocre sushi after dining at Kusakabe! It is quite pricy at $98/person (or $165/person for the grand omakase), so I would recommend coming for a special occasion!

excerpts: we ordered a few more items such as the organic lobster omelette and the Miyazaki wagyu....
Wagyu was lightly salted and it was good...
I felt like we could skip on the lobster omelette because we couldn't taste any lobster....despite my rating on the restaurant itself....
everything else was impeccable!
Tables, lighting, and fantastic service!
We don't have an issue splurging on a meal...
I expected a little more since I was blown away by Omakase on Townsend St.     :(
After $500 I expected a little bit more...
Maybe I should give Kusakabe another chance to bump up my review.
wagyu.author: Hang H.
wagyu.review: I definitely feel that Kusakabe is totally hyped up...However, service was outstanding and food was cool...but why the 3 stars? I've been to numerous omakase's in the past, but I felt the food was just ok. We had the honor of sitting right in front of Chef Kusakabe himself. My boyfriend & I ordered the $98 omakase that included the 8 dishes. Every dish was executed in a very timely manner. The starter soup was very good & soothing especially for the cold SF weather. As for the nigiri, Kusakabe's style has more of a hickory smoked/ bonito flavor and the other dishes were beautifully presented to us...but after a while I felt like it tasted ehhhh...the ratio of the fish and the marinated rice tasted the same dish after dish....we ordered a few more items such as the organic lobster omelette and the Miyazaki wagyu....Wagyu was lightly salted and it was good...I felt like we could skip on the lobster omelette because we couldn't taste any lobster....despite my rating on the restaurant itself....everything else was impeccable! Tables, lighting, and fantastic service! We don't have an issue splurging on a meal...I expected a little more since I was blown away by Omakase on Townsend St.     :(    After $500 I expected a little bit more... Maybe I should give Kusakabe another chance to bump up my review.

excerpts: Dishes that I was not too crazy about were les petit plats and the wagyu rib cap (tasted too fatty and oily...
yes, I like marbled meats but this was too much).
The Miyazaki wagyu they served later nigiri-style was much better in my opinion.
wagyu.author: Joan S.
wagyu.review:
4.5 stars. My friend and I came here last night for the 8:00 p.m. seating and got the Grand Omakase menu for $165. The sushi was probably some of the best sushi I have ever had in my life. The fish was really the star and all the additions added did not overwhelm what you are ultimately here for, which is the fish. Kusakabe did a brilliant job of elevating high-quality fish through the use of umami soy sauce, shiso leaves, yuzu etc. These ingredients brought out the flavor of the fish and gave it something extra.

The stars for me was the Kegani which was Hokkaido crab with quail egg (this is usually served with shrimp but since I don't like shrimp, they substituted with crab), Hotate (Hokkaido scallop topped with uni) and Zuke Chutoro (bluefin tuna).

Dishes that I was not too crazy about were les petit plats and the wagyu rib cap (tasted too fatty and oily...yes, I like marbled meats but this was too much). The Miyazaki wagyu they served later nigiri-style was much better in my opinion. 

We definitely felt full afterwards and felt that we had a very enjoyable and special experience. We have both lived in Japan and been to various kaiseki/omakase places and we agreed that this was pretty top-notch.

excerpts: At the end, if you choose the Grand Omakase, you get to choose between toro or wagyu.
I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards.
I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards.
I HIGHLY recommend trying the wagyu if you haven't tried it before!
Don't get me wrong
- I love toro
and I always order it where ever I go, but only a few places have wagyu
so I recommend giving it a try!
I can't even describe the incredible taste...
wagyu.author: Letty H.
wagyu.review:
I love trying Kaiseki style restaurants because that way, you can have a variety and try a little of everything! :) We made reservations and I recommend making them at the bar so that way, they serve each nigiri to you one at a time and so you can also chat with the chef! There is street parking and some pretty cheap parking garages close by. We sat in front of Chef Ken and had an amazing time. 

For drinks, we started off with the sake flight ($50) and some Koshihikari Echigo beer ($9), which I really enjoyed - I've never tried it before and I've never seen it in any Japanese restaurants I've been to. We decided on the Grand Omakase ($150 per person), it comes with 25 items. They start off by asking if you have any allergies and what your favorite type of sushi is, then you start your dinner! 

You wipe your hands with the towel they provide and the chef explains that you eat the nigiri with your fingers and they seasoned it already so there's no soy sauce. You use chopsticks for everything else. It's really fun because they explain what they're serving you each time and they wait until you're done before they serve the next item.

I won't go into too much depth because their menu changes a little every night depending on what is fresh. I tried so many different things and even though we were served some sushi that I'm not usually a fan of, I decided to try it anyways and it was worth it because everything is so fresh and tasty. 

At the end, if you choose the Grand Omakase, you get to choose between toro or wagyu. I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards. I HIGHLY recommend trying the wagyu if you haven't tried it before! Don't get me wrong - I love toro and I always order it where ever I go, but only a few places have wagyu so I recommend giving it a try! I can't even describe the incredible taste... It was lightly salted, a little sweet, semi- seared...just amazing, trust me and give it a try!!

At the end, we had Daiginjo Sake Kasu creme brulee for dessert paired with some dessert wine, Sauternes Chateau Laribotte, Bordeaux, France 2009, which was so delicious and a great way to finish off the night. 

This restaurant can be pricey depending on what you order (if you choose to order a la carte, drinks, etc.), but the regular Omakase menu is $99 and you can always order a la carte if they don't serve you an item you want to try! Our total for 3 people was about $730, including tax & tip. Overall, I highly recommend because of the fresh food and excellent service. I'll be back!

excerpts: Since the finale is a choice of either Toro or A5 Wagyu, my bf order a la carte the one that we didn't select for our finale.
wagyu.author: Lena V.
wagyu.review:
A friend had recommended KUSAKABE to celebrate a special occasion. My bf decided to take me here for my birthday. 

They have 2 omakase menu choices. The regular omakase menu starts at $95pp for 19 items and the grand omakase menu is priced at $150pp for 25 items. We had original opted for the the regular omakase menu since I get full fast but after the first piece we were served, my bf quickly changed his mind an wanted us to upgrade to the grand omakase menu. It was so worth it.

I was full but I wasn't so stuffed that I couldn't keep eating more. The entire dining time was about 2 hours or a bit more. Each course was presented beautifully and timed perfectly. They also offer an a la carte menu for after if you find yourself still hungry. Since the finale is a choice of either Toro or A5 Wagyu, my bf order a la carte the one that we didn't select for our finale. Both are priced at $12.50 each for a piece.

Everything was so delicious. Before you get started, the chef will ask you if there's any type of fish that's your favorite or what you don't like so they can avoid serving you something that you wouldn't want to eat. 

There was just so many pieces that I don't even remember the names of each, sadly. So I can't pinpoint a favorite but each item was to die for.

I highly recommend for anyone who loves sushi and is looking for a place to celebrate a special occasion to make reservations for KUSAKABE.

excerpts:
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef.
wagyu.author: Danny L.
wagyu.review:
Instead of going to our Company holiday dinner this year, Lily T. & I decided to skip that and go here instead. It took us 1.5 months to find a decent reservation and the wait was so worth it. This restaurant is amazing- definitely worth the Michelin star. Reservations are super competitive though, so don't expect to last minute plan it but keep hopes!

We had the opportunity to seat right in front of Chef Kusakabe which was amazing because he explained every little detail about each fish and we saw all the finishing touch. Lily T. & I opted in for the $150 grand omakase which included 25 items. Each piece of nigiri was a die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and also added with some citrus and wasabi depending on the nigiri. I love for a fact the Chef also asks you if you're allergic to anything and if you had any favorite fish so they can do a little remix.
