Metered street parking was easily found before 6 pm. The nearest garage is 2 blocks away at the Embarcadero Garage ($3/hour after 5 pm).

Some of our highlights were:
Fatty Tuna
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef. (OMG, melt in your mouth....) 

Nice interior, excellent food, and above & beyond customer service. Not once did I need to flag down a waiter down for tea. Everyone had a smile on their face.  Major props! Kusakabe was my first Michelin star restaurant and I definitely felt the "VIP" treatment.

Thanks, Kusakabe! I'll be back.

excerpts: Also, the wagyu was some of the most stringy fatty rather than marbled I've ever had.
wagyu.author: Matthew C.
wagyu.review:
Very rare I disagree with a yelp 4.5 star rating, but I'm totally confused by this one.  We were a party of four with two from Southern California and two from Hong Kong so very familiar paying a premium for high quality sushi, but everyone was left perplexed.  Before knowing the price (friend and I were trading meals), I thought it was a solid 3 to 4 star meal as there were some highlights, but also low lights, but then when I learned it was over $800 per couple (including sake pairing) then it became one of the most overpriced meals of my life.  As mentioned, some courses really shined, though they use sauces or smoking that overpower the fish rather than letting the product truly shine.  Also, the wagyu was some of the most stringy fatty rather than marbled I've ever had.  Overall, very disappointing meal and have had way better for significantly less to boot.

PS - Who has ever heard of a 4 ounce wine pour?!  My wife was one of three around us who made the same complaint after receiving a glass.  Talk about nickle and diming.

excerpts: I had the A5 Wagyu at the end and my boyfriend had the Kaisui uni and both were very delicious.
wagyu.author: Janice L.
wagyu.review:
My boyfriend and I decided to come here to celebrate his early birthday and our anniversary because we both love sushi. We never had an omakase experience before so we were very excited to try it out. Made reservations online and thankfully they had it on the day we wanted to go. 

Our reservations wasn't until 8:15 but when we got there at 8, they seated us right away at the bar. We ordered the regular omakase thinking that we can just add more at the end if we're still hungry. We ended up being super full and only ordered 1 extra each. I had the A5 Wagyu at the end and my boyfriend had the Kaisui uni and both were very delicious. At the end, they gave us a yuzu dessert to celebrate our anniversary and that was very thoughtful of them. 

Definitely a great experience and the fish were fresh and delish! I had a great time and enjoyed everything that was served. I personally never liked oysters, so I was scared to try the Japanese raw oyster, but it was so good and ended up being one of my favorites. Definitely recommended and will be coming back!

excerpts: The only thing that I was a little less impressed with was the A5 Wagyu beef with a poached egg; it came out on a hot, mini-cast iron skillet, and had a sauce poured over that was supposed to sizzle and help cook the meat.

Unfortunately, we were the last of three couples who were being served at the same time and our skillets had cooled down where it barely sizzled and all the ingredients were a little more under cooked than I think it was intended to be.
wagyu.author: Tiffany T.
wagyu.review:
Before I start - definitely sit at the bar. It's such a delight to watch everything being prepared.

I went to Kusakabe with the boyfriend a few weeks ago for an anniversary dinner and it was just fantastic. It was the first time either of us had omakase and went with the Grand Omakase menu. Definitely come with an empty stomach because we were just STUFFED by the end of it.

We were seated at the sushi bar and our chef asked us for any favorites/dislikes/allergies. We personally didn't have any dislikes, but one person seated next to us apparently didn't like uni, and the chef was mindful of that through the entire meal and substituted other fish for her.

Every piece of fish is thoughtfully prepared and oh so tender. It's awesome to hear about each piece, what fish it is, and what preparation had gone into it.

The only thing that I was a little less impressed with was the A5 Wagyu beef with a poached egg; it came out on a hot, mini-cast iron skillet, and had a sauce poured over that was supposed to sizzle and help cook the meat. Unfortunately, we were the last of three couples who were being served at the same time and our skillets had cooled down where it barely sizzled and all the ingredients were a little more under cooked than I think it was intended to be. It was still pretty tasty and honestly a fairly minor thing.

If you're looking to step up your sushi game, I highly recommend it. It is 300% for sure worth the higher price tag and I'm already trying to think of the next special occasion to have an excuse to go back.

excerpts: Hearing very positive reviews about their A5 Miyazaki Wagyu nigiri and after tasting fantastic Kobe beef in Japan, definitely knew I had to try a piece.
My expectations were high and the Wagyu nigiri blew past them with ease.
The beef was super marbley and tender, and the umami and fatty juices just burst in my mouth with every bite.
This is definitely my recommended must-try, extremely worth the $14 for the piece.
Afterwards, we ordered a couple desserts to share.
We started with the yuzu and shiso leaf sorbet, which was very refreshing and tangy.
Next we had their kome koji (ingredient used to make sake) ice cream, which was very unique, although unsweetened.
Finally, we tried their daiginjo sake kasu creme brulee - also great, very rich and sweet creme brulee with a bit of sake kick.
Very great to share with a group.
The bill came out to be about $115 per person pre-tax/tips.
For the high quality of the food, and the very attentive and friendly staff, definitely felt the price was worth the unforgettable 3-hour experience I had at Kusakabe.
Big 5 stars, highly recommend a try for sushi lovers!
wagyu.author: Alvin W.
wagyu.review:
After many months of long wait, had an absolutely phenomenal omakase experience at Kusakabe! Came with a group of seven on a Saturday night with a reservation made a few months in advance. We arrived for the 5pm seating and received a very friendly welcome from the staff as we entered through the door.
 
We ordered the $98 regular omakase, which was a fantastic, well-decorated, seven course meal. Every item was unique and delicious - prepared extremely carefully by the wonderful chefs. Some of the highlights of the meal: amberjack sashimi (very meaty), raw oyster and caviar (extremely fresh), akadashi soup with duck and soy cream foam (savory, rich broth and duck flavor), and the toro (phenomenally fatty and fresh). The servers were friendly and very detailed in describing each of the items in the courses.
 
After the omakase, they present an a-la-carte menu so that you can order additional pieces of nigiri. Hearing very positive reviews about their A5 Miyazaki Wagyu nigiri and after tasting fantastic Kobe beef in Japan, definitely knew I had to try a piece. My expectations were high and the Wagyu nigiri blew past them with ease. The beef was super marbley and tender, and the umami and fatty juices just burst in my mouth with every bite. This is definitely my recommended must-try, extremely worth the $14 for the piece.
 
Afterwards, we ordered a couple desserts to share. We started with the yuzu and shiso leaf sorbet, which was very refreshing and tangy. Next we had their kome koji (ingredient used to make sake) ice cream, which was very unique, although unsweetened. Finally, we tried their daiginjo sake kasu creme brulee - also great, very rich and sweet creme brulee with a bit of sake kick. Very great to share with a group.
 
The bill came out to be about $115 per person pre-tax/tips. For the high quality of the food, and the very attentive and friendly staff, definitely felt the price was worth the unforgettable 3-hour experience I had at Kusakabe. Big 5 stars, highly recommend a try for sushi lovers!

excerpts: If I had to chose my most favorite was the scallops topped with uni nigiri and A5 wagyu beef nigiri.
We also ordered a dessert at the end and got the creme brûlée, OMG it was so good.
All desserts are homemade and the creme brûlée was so unique, it had a hint of sake flavor.
The whole restaurant and the chef sang happy birthday to my mom, it was very thoughtful and sweet :)
They also told me at the end that the dessert was on the house!
wagyu.author: Natalie L.
wagyu.review:
One of the most amazing dining experience ever! I must say I was impressed. I booked a month in advance for my mom's birthday dinner, we sat at the bar and Chef Kusakabe was the one serving us (super awesome!). 

We ordered the Grand Omakese and I highly recommend getting that one since there is more to try (25 items). Chef Kusakabe asked us what kind of fishes or nigiri that we like and he will customize it with the meal. Each nigiri was mouth watering, fresh and tasted very authentic with it's own style. I honestly couldn't think of ONE thing I DIDN'T like at all. If I had to chose my most favorite was the scallops topped with uni nigiri and A5 wagyu beef nigiri. We also ordered a dessert at the end and got the creme brûlée, OMG it was so good. All desserts are homemade and the creme brûlée was so unique, it had a hint of sake flavor. The whole restaurant and the chef sang happy birthday to my mom, it was very thoughtful and sweet :) They also told me at the end that the dessert was on the house! :D

Thank you so much Kusakabe for making my mom's birthday so special and memorable! We definitely will be coming back again!

excerpts: It also came with something that tasted like wagyu croquette, covered in crispy rice.
It was quite small, so it was difficult to taste the wagyu.
wagyu.author: Christine L.
wagyu.review:
Got here about 10-15 minutes before our reservation at 8:15pm on a Friday (made a month in advance). They were able to seat us promptly even though we were early.
We sat at the table right next to the door partition. It was a smallish place, so it was a bit tight for the servers to get past me. I felt bad since I didn't realize this until we left. They were all nice enough not to say anything! 

They had two choices: the regular omakase (8 courses) or the grand omakase (11 courses). We opted for the regular $98 omakase menu. After we ordered, they gave us the dashi broth, along with warm towels and other eating utensils. We had more than one server bring us our food, and each one explained what they had placed on the table. I got too excited when they brought the sushi out so I didn't get to take pictures of the first sushi course. It was a piece of cured bluefin chutoro sushi that had a wonderful smoky flavor, paired with a piece of fresh fish served as is (not cured, marinated, etc.). You have one piece that was heavily flavored with soy sauce contrasting with another that was light and fresh, no frills. It was a very thoughtful pairing that not only didn't overwhelm my palate, but brought out the flavor of each piece of sushi. This theme continued throughout the meal with the sushi plates. 

Eventually, after a few rounds of sushi and sashimi, they brought out the Hassun, which consisted of 6 tiny dishes, and was the most beautifully plated out of all the courses. I loved that you got a tiny bite of everything, rather than one entree. I won't go over everything, but wasn't blown away by the taste of the overall dish. I'm sure people who love clams would like the cold clam soup. I felt like it really brought out the flavor of the clams. I didn't particularly like it, but that's because I'm not a huge fan of clams. There was a lightly fried shrimp and taro, like shrimp and taro karage. Tasted like what you would expect. It also came with something that tasted like wagyu croquette, covered in crispy rice. It was quite small, so it was difficult to taste the wagyu. 

We ended the meal with more fresh and melt-in-your-mouth sushi: a fun and delicious DIY hand roll served with scallop sushi topped with uni. They brought out an add-ons menu if we wanted to order anything a la carte. We were pretty satisfied, so we didn't add get anything else. After that, they came out with what I think was a yuzu sorbet, with a candle, on the house! I had forgot that they called ahead about a week before to ask if we were coming for any special reason. I had mentioned to them on the phone that it was my boyfriend's birthday. It was a nice surprise. The sorbet itself had a nice citrusy flavor, and came in a really cute little tea cup. 

In general, I really liked the quality of the sushi and sashimi, along with the their flavors and the little additions and sauces served with them. This was the main reason fo coming here. There warm dishes and soups weren't bad, but they definitely weren't the stars of the show. The servers were also all really nice and professional.

excerpts: miyazaki wagyu beef - you really can't go wrong with either.
wagyu.author: Megan K.
wagyu.review:
Came here for a special celebration dinner and made reservations a month or so in advance. Make sure to request bar seating (I called in closer to the date of the reservation to confirm) for a better experience.

The Omakase menu price is very reasonable - $95 per person - and we (surprisingly) did not leave the restaurant starving (although I could have probably stuffed a couple more pieces of sashimi down my throat if I wanted... but that's what the a la carte menu is for). The menu has 8 line items and our sushi chef asked us what kind of fish we liked and catered some things to us for some of the later dishes. The whole menu is pretty set, but for the last item we had a choice between toro bluefin fatty tuna or grade a5 miyazaki wagyu beef - you really can't go wrong with either. Since there was two of us we got one of each (:

Some of the things on the menu strayed away from a traditional Japanese omakase menu - for example the bone marrow gelatin and a lamb croquette bite. I thought it was creative and added variety to an otherwise standard Japanese tasting menu, but if you're expecting something traditional like you would get in Japan, this might catch you off guard. 

Overall a really great experience, but the meal as a whole didn't really blow my mind. If you want to go all out for a Japanese dinner I would recommend Omakase over Kusakabe, or at least go to Kusakabe first to temper your expectations.

excerpts: The next piece that truly stood out to me was the A5 wagyu beef nigiri.
It was a raw piece of A5 wagyu beef placed on top of rice, and torched so it was seared on top, yet perfectly rare in the middle.
A5 is the highest possible grade of beef, and it was marvelous and extremely "meaty" tasting.
I had never had beef that was so fatty, pure, and clean tasting before, and I'm not sure how many more times in my life I'll be able to have beef that good.
wagyu.author: Alana L.
wagyu.review:
I have always loved Japanese food for its delicate and umami flavors. The level of detail and care put into all Japanese dishes has always astounded me. I am a huge fan of donburis, udon noodles, and of course, sushi. However, a couple of months ago, I had a totally new, mind-blowing, and quite frankly, life-changing culinary experience with Japanese cuisine. For my birthday, my friend took me out for omakase style sushi in San Francisco. The term "omakase" is a Japanese phrase that means "I'll leave it up to you(the chef)." The whole sushi meal is decided by the chef, and is tailored towards which fishes are in season at the time, and whatever flavors the chef wants to present that night, so it is a meal you should go into with zero expectations. 

We went to KUSAKABE, a 1-Michelin starred omakase restaurant placed in the heart of San Francisco, California's financial district. This meal consisted of 15-20 different types of nigiri, or slices of raw fish/meat over rice. We were seated at a simple, wooden bar, and were assigned 1 chef for the entire night to take us through the omakase experience. Every piece was placed in front of us, one at a time, after we had finished each previous piece. Everything was extremely simple and clean, but it was some of the most fresh and most melt-in-my-mouth sushi experiences I had ever had. I practically melted along with each piece of sushi in my mouth. 

Priced at $165 per person for the "Grand Omakase" dinner, you better bet you're going to get a mind-blowing food experience. I can go on and on for hours about each piece of sushi I had that night, but I will just point out some of my highlights:

- One of the most memorable and unique pieces was the Tsukiji fish market squid nigiri with crystallized egg yolk and a single yuzu leaf. It was almost "rubbery" in texture but extremely smooth and silky, the egg provided a creamy accent, and the yuzu was a pop of fresh lemon taste. This single bite was the most unique, and most harmonious pieces of food I have ever eaten. 

- The next piece that truly stood out to me was the A5 wagyu beef nigiri. It was a raw piece of A5 wagyu beef placed on top of rice, and torched so it was seared on top, yet perfectly rare in the middle. A5 is the highest possible grade of beef, and it was marvelous and extremely "meaty" tasting. I had never had beef that was so fatty, pure, and clean tasting before, and I'm not sure how many more times in my life I'll be able to have beef that good. My jaw physically dropped after this one. 

KUSAKABE provided a life-changing Japanese food experience and I hope that everyone has the opportunity to try omakase sushi at least once in their lives, especially if they love sushi and Japanese culture. Even if you don't love or know much about Japanese culture, though, this would be a great introduction. If anyone ever wants to learn more about omakase too, and the history of it, I would highly recommend watching the documentary "Jiro Dreams of Sushi," which is about a famous sushi chef in Japan whose restaurant takes reservations 1 year in advanced because it is so well-known for its omakase. I hope to try different omakase restaurants in my life when I am older and have more money to do so. But for now, I will just fondly remember and dream of this KUSAKABE experience

excerpts: - Wagyu beef: AMAZING, beautiful marbling
wagyu.author: Vera N.
wagyu.review:
4.5 stars because I wasn't able to get bar seating, but rounded up. We were first on waitlist and got the call 2 days before that we had gotten seats, but no guarantees are bar seating. Since we actually came at our reservation time, we were seated at the table. Found out later that a party didn't show up, but those seats were given to a walk-in an hour later. I was pretty butthurt, but it's okay, meal was worth it and I would definitely go again just so I can sit front row.

We settled with the $95 omakase and intended to order some a la carte pieces afterwards. Everything was amazing, the service, the ambience, and especially the food. The atmosphere was warm and inviting, but also exclusive and refined at the same time. The lighting focused on the chefs and the food at our table. The service was amazing, explained each course with detail. Even brought out another beer free of charge because they had brought the wrong drink the first time. 

Highlights of my meal:
- Halibut with its own liver
- Scallop sashimi with the yuzu and garlic sauce: delicate and sweet, counterbalanced with the sauces
- Snap pea soup: different textures, the fried fish added crunch and the broth was so good.
- Wagyu beef: AMAZING, beautiful marbling
- Toro: my favorite of the night, it was melt-in-my-mouth deliciousness
- Kaisui Uni: deep ocean Hokkaido sea urchin was my 2nd favorite.. so creamy and sweet.
- Bafun Uni: Hokkaido short spine uni was firmer in texture, not as sweet, more ocean-y taste.

Overall, it was a delightful dining experience. Would have been amazing tenfold if we had bar seating, but all the more reason to come back.. Also, to get the Grand Omakase next time around. Definitely worth a pretty penny.

excerpts: Both end with toro & A5 wagyu.
Everything was presented beautifully and seasoned excellently.
There is no soy sauce or wasabi, so that's one less thing to think about.
Of course I enjoyed the buttery toro (fatty tuna).
The wagyu had beautiful marbling.
When he brought out the blowtorch to sear the wagyu, I wanted to take a picture, but he was too quick for me.
The couple next to us also wanted a picture, so Chef Ken turned on the blowtorch just so we could document the moment.
When the chefs weren't busy preparing bites of perfection or entertaining guests, they were collaborating with each other.
I was surprised to see three chefs working together to put together the presentation for one dessert.
The food was very delicious with a very solid fish selection.
What put it over the top for me was the amazing hospitality that made it a great experience.
wagyu.author: Joy W.
wagyu.review:
In an ideal world, I would like to have a well-orchestrated sushi omakase dinner on the regular for the following reasons.
- Raw fish is delicious.
- When a chef knows what s/he is doing, I'm more than happy to have the chef execute their well-thought out prix fixe menu.
- I don't have to order. Ordering is not my forte, as I am indecisive by nature. 

Needless to say, Kusakabe does an excellent kaiseki.
Reservations here are highly recommended, and require a credit card to reserve. They are only open Mon- Sat, with 2 dinner seatings a night (5pm & 8pm) and a capacity of 29 guests. 
The cancellation policy is very strict. 
- Cancellations w/in 48 hrs result in a charge of $30 per person.
- Cancellations on the same day or no shows result in a charge of $95 per person.
I have to admit I was glad that they do not accommodate children under age 5. Apparently the venue is not large enough for strollers and high chairs, but we all know that a crying infant or hyperactive toddler could ruin any dining experience. 

Mr. Joy and I were a few minutes late for our reservation, but they were very nice about it. They hold reservations for latecomers for 15 minutes. Our empty seats and place settings were waiting for us when we arrived. The dining area consists of a very long sushi bar and a couple of tables by the door. Our sushi chef explained that the restaurant design deliberately omitted the glass fish case so the patrons can easily see the chefs prepare food. The tables are also deliberately the same height, so even people who do not sit at the sushi bar can get a good view of the sushi chefs. So thoughtful.

Our server asked us the usual 'Do you have any food allergies?' We replied 'No.' She also asked if we eat raw foods, and we confirmed we do. I'm sure that is part of their protocol to double-check everything, but it would be a pity if someone who does not like raw food made a reservation here and wasted a seat.

You can choose between the Omakase ($95) or the Grand Omakase ($195). They are very similar, but the Grand Omakase is more robust in volume. Both end with toro & A5 wagyu.  Everything was presented beautifully and seasoned excellently. There is no soy sauce or wasabi, so that's one less thing to think about. Most people eat the sushi with their hands, as is the traditional way, but they do provide chopsticks too.

Of course I enjoyed the buttery toro (fatty tuna). The wagyu had beautiful marbling. The zuke chutoro (medium fatty tuna) was also excellent with a light sear on top. All the accompanying flavoring agents were excellent. I especially enjoyed the yuzu onion sauce. The only thing I wasn't so fond of was the squid and mountain yam. Once your omakase has concluded, they offer you the a la carte menu of sashimi. Each order comes with one piece. 

Our chef was truly friendly, entertaining, and hilarious as he shared stories about being a sushi chef. When he brought out the blowtorch to sear the wagyu, I wanted to take a picture, but he was too quick for me. The couple next to us also wanted a picture, so Chef Ken turned on the blowtorch just so we could document the moment. When the chefs weren't busy preparing bites of perfection or entertaining guests, they were collaborating with each other. I was surprised to see three chefs working together to put together the presentation for one dessert. 
The food was very delicious with a very solid fish selection. What put it over the top for me was the amazing hospitality that made it a great experience.

excerpts: I believe for the grand finale, you get to pick between a fatty tuna belly nigiri or a Japanese wagyu nigiri, both were heavenly!
If you are still hungry after you finish the set menu, you may order from the a la carte menu.
Everything was executed perfectly; the sushi rice was superb and the fishes were exceptional!
wagyu.author: Sam M.
wagyu.review: Amazing sushi, great service, lovely experience. They only have one set menu, so you just sit back, relax and enjoy whatever they serve you. In addition to sushi and sashimi, they also serve other Japanese delicacies. I believe for the grand finale, you get to pick between a fatty tuna belly nigiri or a Japanese wagyu nigiri, both were heavenly! If you are still hungry after you finish the set menu, you may order from the a la carte menu. Everything was executed perfectly; the sushi rice was superb and the fishes were exceptional!

excerpts: Also don't miss out on the wagyu tongue- hot damn.
Every piece was worth it and savory.
Our last piece of fatty tuna was decadent.

A couple fun facts: they get fish deliveries daily, their rice is brown because they use red vinegar in their sushi rice (traditional method), and they make a point to know if you're celebrating something.
I really felt that they hosted my husband and me very well.
I also loved that their bathroom has a toto Japanese toilet seat.
Don't get scared that the seat is warm lol.
I do recommend the sorbet and tofu "tiramisu"- the sorbet is palette cleansing and the tofu tiramisu is just tasty without being overly sweet.
I'm coming back soon!
wagyu.author: Krizelda M.
wagyu.review: I'm in love. This is the closest experience to omakase (based off of food taste and quality and critical methodology to serving perfect dishes) I experienced in Japan, albeit bougier. The service as soon as you enter the door is impeccable. Our chef was Brandon and we were next to the couple being served by Chef Nori so we were able to hear some of his information as he served them. If you go, get the Omakase, unless you have a very small appetite I don't think the petite Omakase is enough! Also don't miss out on the wagyu tongue- hot damn. Every piece was worth it and savory. Our last piece of fatty tuna was decadent. A couple fun facts: they get fish deliveries daily, their rice is brown because they use red vinegar in their sushi rice (traditional method), and they make a point to know if you're celebrating something. I really felt that they hosted my husband and me very well. I also loved that their bathroom has a toto Japanese toilet seat. Don't get scared that the seat is warm lol. I do recommend the sorbet and tofu "tiramisu"- the sorbet is palette cleansing and the tofu tiramisu is just tasty without being overly sweet. I'm coming back soon!

excerpts: Some of my favorites were the Zuke Chutoro, Ocean Trout, Striped Jack, Red Snapper, and A5 Wagyu.
I especially loved the torched fish/A5 - the perfect amount of smokiness flavor and felt like it melted in my mouth like butter.
What differentiated this restaurant from others was how the chef managed to mix the perfect amount and selection of oils/sauces to best emphasize the true taste of the fish.
Some even had wasabi mixed in beforehand!
Traditionally, you don't need to dip the fish in the soy sauce, and you're supposed to eat the nigiri with your hands
(Erick T. actually did this).
But... I ate most of my nigiri with chopsticks and dipped my fish in soy sauce anyway because I love soy sauce.
I actually think the sushi chef got a bit offended when he saw me do this.
wagyu.author: Christina L.
wagyu.review:
Surprised Erick T. with reservations back in October 2015 for his 27th birthday, and KUSAKABE has remained as one of my favorite omakase restaurants in the city since then. It was $95 pp, but I heard that they now offer a $150 prix fix menu. Definitely another reason why I need to come back. :']

It's a rather small restaurant (12-15 people), and I love how the majority of the seating is at the bar. My favorite! Lighting was also amazing, and the service was indeed Michelin star worthy.

Some of my favorites were the Zuke Chutoro, Ocean Trout, Striped Jack, Red Snapper, and A5 Wagyu. I especially loved the torched fish/A5 - the perfect amount of smokiness flavor and felt like it melted in my mouth like butter. What differentiated this restaurant from others was how the chef managed to mix the perfect amount and selection of oils/sauces to best emphasize the true taste of the fish. Some even had wasabi mixed in beforehand! Traditionally, you don't need to dip the fish in the soy sauce, and you're supposed to eat the nigiri with your hands (Erick T. actually did this). But... I ate most of my nigiri with chopsticks and dipped my fish in soy sauce anyway because I love soy sauce. I actually think the sushi chef got a bit offended when he saw me do this. Whoops, sorry! 

The one thing I actually really wished was not on the menu was the box of assorted small plates (oyster, squid, etc.) I have a very picky palette, and they were all honestly just too fishy for me. I ended up giving most of them to my boyfriend. Maybe it won't be on the menu when I come back?

Ordered sake pairings for the both of us ($75 pp), which I highly recommend! I thought their selection of sakes in comparison to that of other omakase restaurants was far more tasty and unique. But if you don't drink much, I suggest only ordering one tasting. Surprisingly, they pour you BIG shots/glasses, and I died halfway through my meal. Don't want to be stumbling out the door like I did. Our waitress was also able to answer all my questions about the choices of sake for each dish and was very informative. Thank you!

Overall, Erick T. and I were blown away by how delicious everything was for the price and how shockingly full we were! But who knows, maybe it was the sake that filled us up.

excerpts: Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef.
wagyu.author: Jessica Z.
wagyu.review:
My bf and I celebrated our anniversary at Kusakabe! I've had this bookmarked for quite some time, just never had a reason to go.

I was pleasantly surprised as I had no clue where we were going to celebrate! 

We ordered the grand omakase with two hot sakes. The grand omakase consisted of 25 pieces, displayed on 7 "dishes". The entire dining experience was amazing from the start to finish. We first started off with the Ichiban Dashi, a small soup. Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef. 

After the omakase, there's an a la carte menu. My bf and I ordered 2 additional pieces each. One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni. 

Although we were pretty satisfied, we wanted to end the meal with dessert! They over heard that we were celebrating our anniversary so they gave us all three desserts on the house. So sweet! Love it. 

Overall, I was pretty blown away and kudos to the services as well! Can't wait to be back :)

excerpts: After adding extra Wagyu A5 and Hokkaido Uni and drinks, this place will surely make a small dent in your wallet.
Thank goodness it was my Birthday!
Great place to go for a celebration!
wagyu.author: Melanie N.
wagyu.review:
Amazing Omakase Experience!  If you can get a reservation, make sure you sit at the bar so that you can watch the chef at work- they are so meticulous with their work.  Everything was so fresh!  And it was my first time having turtle in the turtle soup.  

Dined here for my Birthday for the $95 Omakase menu- everything was so fresh and beautifully presented! After adding extra Wagyu A5 and Hokkaido Uni and drinks, this place will surely make a small dent in your wallet.  Thank goodness it was my Birthday! =)  Great place to go for a celebration!

excerpts: Their A5 Wagyu was not of the most marbleous that I have ever had.
Top notch - don't get me wrong.
wagyu.author: Tiffany D.
wagyu.review:
Michelin star means that I have high expectations of this place to be exceptional. 

I thought it was the norm of gourmet sushi, sashimi, sake and nigiri, but the proportions was a bit lacking for the price tag - I am talking about their omakase set.  

Quality was there, but it didn't stand out as spectacular to other upscale sashimi, omakase offerings that I have tried.

Their A5 Wagyu was not of the most marbleous that I have ever had.  Top notch - don't get me wrong.  However, not the best.

Their omakase nigiris were of the standard.  Again, it lacks the feeling of amazing!  Not too much creativity either.  Let me rave about it the next day, kind of feeling that I usually have on dazzling food spots!  It took me awhile to express myself about this place as you have read thus far that I left quite unimpressed. 

Sake was nicely fragrant and complimented well with the nigiri.  I was disappointed that they didn't include Hokkaido uni to their omakase set.  We had to order it as an addition.  I loved the freshness that you can taste from the uni.  Downside, it wasn't on the omakase set as it should have since it was such a delight to taste and would have been overlooked if we didn't order it.

As much as I want to really flatter this place, it didn't spark me as oh my, I have to return for their almighty sashimi, sushi and so forth.  It's a tucked away small spot and discrete.  Reservations are required and you have to tell them ahead of time that you want the chef's counter.  

I left feeling: yes, it was fine dining splurge.  Great celebratory restaurant to attend to.  Not the best sashimi ever, but you get it Michelin style.

excerpts: The finale of toro and A5 wagyu was so delicious too - seriously, melt in your mouth good!
We also ordered the shrimp a la carte which was huge and you get to eat it in two ways, the body quickly poached over rice and the head deep-fried!
wagyu.author: Cynthia H.
wagyu.review:
Had one of the most amazing dining experiences of my life here last night!!! The $150 was SO worth it. Chef Nori was so kind and willing to adjust the menu to what me and my boyfriend like and he was great at explaining each dish to us. Whenever we asked him questions, he was very willing to answer them and explain too! We learned a lot about where they source their fish and the insanely quick shipping they have from Japan to SF. 

Overall, the service was on point and the food quality was just amazing - The Kaisui Uni was literally THE best uni I've EVER eaten in my life. The finale of toro and A5 wagyu was so delicious too - seriously, melt in your mouth good! We also ordered the shrimp a la carte which was huge and you get to eat it in two ways, the body quickly poached over rice and the head deep-fried! I also really enjoyed the BBQ eel with sansho pepper, super fatty eel and no bones in it at all.

This experience was more than I could've asked for and I 100% will be back!! Deserves more than 1 michelin star for sure! Chef Nori, food quality, service - all A+++++, well worth the $400 meal.

excerpts: Try both the toro and the wagyu
wagyu.author: Alice H.
wagyu.review:
Tips:

Recommend bar seating.
Try both the toro and the wagyu sushi, you won't regret it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hands down one of my favorite sushi experiences yet! I came here on the Monday after Valentines day for the 8pm seating and I had an amazing time.

Service:
- Pace of dinner was perfect: not too fast, but not too slow.
- Staff are extremely attentive and helpful. Answered all our curious questions and explained every dish to us. I never felt intimidated or out of place.
- This was my first Omakaze experience at the bar seating and our sushi chef helped us survive through it! (Thumbs up for Patrick our sushi chef!)

Food:
- Absolutely delicious. Everything from the sushi to the warm dishes to the soup.

I would absolutely come back and recommend coming to Kusakabe for all of my friends.

excerpts: For the finale, I would definitely recommend getting both the wagyu and the toro options!!
You do have to pay extra in order to have both, but definitely worth it.
wagyu.author: Tiffany P.
wagyu.review:
One of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF!! 

You have to make a reservation to get seated since they only have two seatings a night. The omakase is only $95 per person, which is super affordable compared to a lot of other options in the city, and the quality is still exceptional. It's definitely not the most extensive omakase menu, but I left feeling pleasantly satisfied, rather than too full to move. And, if you want more of a particular fish, or just want something that wasn't included in the omakase courses, you can also order additional things a la carte.

The omakase has a good mix of warm dishes, quality fish, and other courses. The non-nigiri items were really unique. Two that I remember were a soup with a small meatball / dumpling and a fish marrow gelatin type thing (part of a mini 4-course plating). For the finale, I would definitely recommend getting both the wagyu and the toro options!! You do have to pay extra in order to have both, but definitely worth it. Sooo delicious.

For dessert, I got the pumpkin pudding with caramelized sugar on top. Kind of a twist on a traditional creme brulee, with a slightly different texture. It was unique, not too sweet, and a great end to the meal.

excerpts: My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte).
Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch.
wagyu.author: Jennifer K.
wagyu.review:
I took my boyfriend to KUSAKABE for his birthday back in February, and it was quite the eye opening experience!

I've always been a fan of sushi, but this was our first time trying omakase. KUSAKABE took my love for sushi to the next level. Eat with your hands, and no need to dip the nigiri into soy sauce or add any extra wasabi; the chef puts it on your plate, and you stuff it into your mouth. Have a bottle of sake (or two) while you're at it!

My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte). Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch. :)

Can't wait to be back!

excerpts: My other favorite was the wagyu beef.
TO TRY THE WAGYU BEEF.
It is seriously that good.
wagyu.author: Elaine N.
wagyu.review:
East Coast Native, and this is my first Michelin star exp so maybe I had too high of expectations? 

My friend who lives here took us out because she wanted to try it. I liked the experience, small, good service. Great presentation. Surprised it actually took 2 hours - bonus it didn't feel that long. 

The food was good. My favorite was this turtle egg soup thing (I should have taken a picture of the menu). Very good. Overall quality of fish was good except for a few misses. My other favorite was the wagyu beef. IF YOU GET THE TORO, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE $12 PUSH TO A LA CARTE TO TRY THE WAGYU BEEF. It is seriously that good. Melt in your mouth good. 

I think I expected better quality fish. I picked the fatty tuna/toro option but it wasn't melt in your mouth tender at all... it was really chewy.... 

That being said, it was a good experience, but I don't recommend going out of your way. For $150 I did expect higher quality fish... especially for the fatty tuna.

excerpts: For the last piece,we chose the a5 wagyu sushi.
I gotta say that I was not completely blown away with this piece.
I actually think that Sushi Sams in San Mateo has a better A5.
wagyu.author: Susan M.
wagyu.review:
Boyfriend took me here to celebrate our anniversary, great choice as this place has been at the top of my list for quite a while now! This was my first Michelin star dining experience and I am so glad it was as it was absolutely amazing. 

We started off with the Omakase courses which were 7 courses for $95pp. I wasn't a huge fan of the seaweed drink they give you to cleanse your palette. My favorites of the courses were the chu toro and copper salmon nigiri, although pretty much all the nigiri they served as part of the omakase were delicious. Each piece was specially seasoned and super fresh. I loved the turtle soup dish (can't believe I ate a cute little turtle), but  shockingly, it was amazing. The dish with two crispy fish in a truffle sauce and shishito pepper was another favorite of mine. Pretty much licked the dish clean because the truffle sauce was so tasty. I also really enjoyed the 5 piece le petit sampler plate of the chefs specials. Huge fan of the crispy eggplant and the tuna over rice piece. 

For the last piece,we chose the a5 wagyu sushi. I gotta say that I was not completely blown away with this piece. I actually think that Sushi Sams in San Mateo has a better A5. I mean it was definitely good, but not as amazing as I was hoping for. 

We ordered a bunch of sushi al a carte. My favorites being the kaisui uni (completely melt in your mouth!!) wish it was a bigger piece though, Santa Barbara uni, bbq unagi (soft and very good), toro (amazing), chu toro (they season this extremely well, lots of flavors). Each bite was complete heaven for me. 

This was my boyfriends first time trying Omakase and he normally doesn't like to eat raw fish other than salmon and hamachi, however, he loved every single bite of their omakase and is now addicted! Uh oh..

Their sake is also very good. I had a glass of reisling, but next time I'd probably refrain from getting this just so I could order more sushi! 

Service was wonderful. The only suggestion that I have is to be more careful and remember if people have specific food restrictions. I asked for no wasabi in all the dishes, however, we had to remind our waitress at least 3 times and there was still some wasabi in my sushi :( which took away from some of the taste for me. They made it up by giving us free dessert for our anniversary. Desserts were delicious, I would highly recommend the pancetta and I'd probably skip out on the corn ice cream next time. 

Make sure you make reservations months in advance if you want to sit at the bar and you can probably get in a months in advance if just for a table. Place is tiny and they have 2 groups for seating, one at 5pm and another at 8pm.

Would I come back? Absolutely! This place is definitely not cheap, but it's worth it to splurge for a special occasion or if you want to take yourself out for some high quality japanese food/sushi. The omakase itself is actually a good amount. It won't get you buffet full, but it's definitely enough and if you order a few pieces al a carte, you should be good to go!

excerpts: One of the finale dishes had a choice between toro vs a5 wagyu beef, I opted for the beef, and it was yummy.
wagyu.author: Minerva L.
wagyu.review:
Zuke was delicious and was my favorite, followed by milt, and the white eel. 

Service was amazing, on point, friendly. 

I had a 5pm RSVP and basically finished around 7pm. 

Did the grand omasake with two desserts (add on) in the end, it was my bff's bday, so one of the dessert was on the house.

All of the dishes were super elegant, different, and fresh. 

One of the finale dishes had a choice between toro vs a5 wagyu beef, I opted for the beef, and it was yummy. 

You definitely do get full, so plan on coming early, with an empty stomach.

I loved the sake creme brulee!

excerpts: My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro.
wagyu.author: Daniel L.
wagyu.review:
Would love to thank Joe, Christina, and Albert for our wonderful experience at Kusakabe. This was our second time here, this time at a table instead of the bar. Food was splendid, better than anything you can get out of a plastic box or local sushi joint. I absolutely love how they carefully explained everything as it came out, and was very mindful of any allergies or dislikes in terms of food. 

They also give you an A La Carte option at the end of your omakase. My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro. My girlfriend told me the only time I make the face I made while eating those is in the bedroom. 

Service is usually something I pay close attention to, and they were very courteous and cheerful in their delivery. Sincere thanks again to Joe, Christina, and Albert.

excerpts: Miyazaki wagyu steak (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oy2eVTsOqhr7JkiXmBY9cQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -
wagyu.author: Mike C.
wagyu.review:
The growing trend of Japanese restaurants opening in or near downtown is clearly at a fever pitch.  Last year, a friend presented me with a gift card (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MdG5viokZhOm2Qpn12kRBQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q). Due to scheduling logistics, it's been difficult to find a person and the time to enjoy this experience with me.  On a recent Friday, I was able to make a 5 pm reservation for two at the table near the host stand, basically at the center of the restaurant.  There are only five tables available which explains the difficulty in securing reservations without early notice.  The remainder of the seating is on the L-shaped sushi bar which seats around twelve or fifteen.  After my guest arrived, here's what we enjoyed:

Amuse
Konbu cha - Translates to kelp tea, this is more like a soup to me.  Sorry, I drank this without taking a picture as I thought it was "just tea".  Perfect elixir for foggy SF evenings.

First
Nigiri toro, halibut, bonito (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DmkADPQrPhbu7Ri_PhcvaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - The first and the third were my favorites... how can you go wrong with those two?!

Second
Sashimi scallop and maguro (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rkKjr_pOWEbDC8rDxyMNDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pristine, fresh, and tender.  They were a nice contrast with one being soft (scallop) and the other firm (maguro).

Third
Umami tomato soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KJTATBDka63tOnd0NxlrGw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My eyes widened as I searched for the tomato element.  There is a large meatball at the center of this which reminds me of the chicken meatball at Delica in the Ferry Building.

Fourth
Hassun, oysters served with French caviar and four petit plates (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qyg_iiz7Brq9vioVpmRjcQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Like the second, fourth, and fifth plates (from the left) the most.  The first one was a bit fishy for me.

Fifth
Yuba wrap (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zblfKmWoBNJU3ka25XU1RQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Indulgence!  Probably my best description given that there was foie gras in the center and summer truffles shaved on top.

Sixth
Nigiri Stripe jack, salmon, flounder (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SbCSmsZ56nNn2sCv3h6Tkw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Clean flavors and nice prelude to the highlight.

Seventh
Sushi finale, grade A5 Miyazaki wagyu steak (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oy2eVTsOqhr7JkiXmBY9cQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -  All I can say, is "look at that"!

After completing the tasting menu, our waitress kindly offered us their supplement menu in case we wanted to try something else or weren't full from the original meal.  

I chose the Lobster omelet sushi (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=87ql3El1K0eKkdX_xYd-tw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  It's actually a flavored take on tamago (egg) sushi where the lobster flavor is infused with the egg.  Enjoyed this as it was an interested take, but just don't get caught up on trying to find the lobster.
There were also three desserts on the menu (one being panna cotta), but nothing was attractive to my guest so we passed.
As many described, this is authentic Japanese cuisine served in a fine dining atmosphere without the stuffy dress code.  As I walked to use the loo, I noticed a couple of awards to the proprietor as sushi maker of the year, not something that's commonly seen in these parts.  
Yes, I will be back, but need to make sure my dining companions are as open minded menu wise as me.

excerpts: At the end, you have a choice of fatty tuna (toro) or A5 Wagyu, and I would suggest getting both for a nominal extra charge.
wagyu.author: Jenn C.
wagyu.review:
What a gem. Kusakabe is easily the best sushi restaurant in the Bay Area and likely California. We opted for the omakase (as everyone should) and thoroughly enjoyed each course. At the end, you have a choice of fatty tuna (toro) or A5 Wagyu, and I would suggest getting both for a nominal extra charge.

I have two criticisms, both of which do not concern the superb sushi offerings. First, the server failed to notice that I am left handed, despite my rearranging of the flatware/chopsticks/tea cup every time she placed something down. Any quality sushi restaurant in Tokyo would have noticed that immediately, but I know I'm just being really nitpicky at this point. Also, I would skip dessert. We split a matcha cake with red bean and vanilla ice cream and it was nowhere near the elevated level of the sushi. Not bad, but it was incongruous with the rest of our experience.

excerpts: I still dream about the Zuke chutoro and the wagyu.
wagyu.author: Jenny B.
wagyu.review:
OH boyyy. When someone is doubtful that paying a lot for good sushi is worth it, bring them here. 

My husband and I were visiting from Chicago were able to book a spot for a weekday evening with less than a month's notice. We did not make a selection for seating preference, and we ended up sitting up at the sushi bar, which ended up being a great experience as we got to interact with our sushi chef and see how each piece is made. 

FOOD:
We were blown away by the food from the first bite. We went with the full Omakase menu and did not regret it one bit. They have a petite omakase menu which is a little shorter and cheaper, but I would recommend going with the full menu as some of my favorites were in the full menu. They do ask for allergies beforehand, and were careful to avoid any allergens (mine was scallop). Each item is thoughtfully made and presented, and we did feel full after our meal. I loved almost everything they put in front of me, although I felt that the tofu w/carrot could have been a little more flavorful. At the end of the meal, you get an a la carte menu where you can order extras, but we were stuffed. Despite this, we still ordered dessert--not because we had room, but because we were certain that the dessert would be amazing. We got the creme brulee, which was AMAZING. Was hesitant at first because I was not sure I could handle something so heavy while being so full, but their version is definitely lighter and more refreshing, but still creamy. I would say this is my favorite version of creme brulee that I've had. We also got the sorbet, which was also fantastic. I'm not a fan of heavy desserts, so these two were absolutely on point.  P.S. I still dream about the Zuke chutoro and the wagyu. 

AMBIANCE: 
Lovely, warm, serene. Lots of wood and clean lines. Good for both dates and outings with family or friends. 

SERVICE:
Great service. Entire staff is very polite, attentive, genuinely friendly and personable. Very approachable and easy going staff, despite their attentiveness, which I greatly appreciated (overly formal staff makes dining a bit too awkward for me). Did not have to try to flag down help or anything. Fantastic attention to detail. 

PRICE TO QUALITY:
Absolutely worth the splurge! My only qualm is that every time I eat sushi elsewhere, I'll just be sad that it's not as good as what we had at Kusakabe :c

excerpts: What disappointed me the most were the hassun, the toro, and the wagyu beef.
The hassun was gorgeously presented, but of all the items on the dish, not a single one stood out to me.
The toro was chewy and nothing near the melt in the mouth quality
I was hoping for.
Same went for the wagyu beef.
It was so chewy that I ended up swallowing the beef whole.
wagyu.author: Diana C.
wagyu.review:
After hearing so much about this place from friends and family, I finally decided to give this place a try. I booked the place for my birthday dinner and psyched myself up for what I was hoping to be an amazing meal. We walked in on a Friday night at 8pm for our 8:15pm reservation. My friends and I were greeted by the host in the front and promptly led to our seats at the bar. The sushi chef in front of us introduced himself to us and asked us about our preferences for fish. We went with the regular omakase over the grand one. The whole experience itself was fun. You got to watch the chef make all the nigiri in front of you. Fresh from their hands straight onto your plate. Our chef was super friendly and let us try to guess which fish was coming next. 

My favorite item of the night was the sashimi of tuna and scallops that came beautifully arranged atop a bowl of ice. The scallops were amazingly sweet and the tuna just melted in your mouth. This item earned 5/5 stars for me and I wish I could have eaten it all night long. Other honorable mentions were the hamachi+mackerel (forgot what the name of the fish was) and the cherrywood smoked tuna. Both were very unique in flavor and the fish was super fresh and supple. 

What disappointed me the most were the hassun, the toro, and the wagyu beef. The hassun was gorgeously presented, but of all the items on the dish, not a single one stood out to me. The toro was chewy and nothing near the melt in the mouth quality I was hoping for. Same went for the wagyu beef. It was so chewy that I ended up swallowing the beef whole. For $15 extra a piece, I was quite bitter about ordering it after eating it. 

For $100 for an omakase, I would most likely not be coming back here anytime soon. The quality of the fish was decent, but the items themselves were nothing to rave over. I will say that if you want to come here, ask for a reservation at the bar. It is well worth it. I honestly think the whole experience was as good as it was because we sat at the bar instead of at the tables. The food itself gets a 3/5 stars for me, but the service was a 5/5. 

Cons: 
- Pricey (but most people come here knowing they are going to have to dish out a good chunk of money for this meal)
- Hard to find parking (true for a lot of places around SF though)
- A lot of courses were lackluster and left me wanting more 

Pros: 
- Great service 
- Sushi chef was super friendly and accommodating
- Gorgeous interior decor and nice ambiance

excerpts: It's hard to pick a favorite of the night, but I'd have to say aside from the obvious A5 Wagyu and toro, the white Alaskan salmon was to die for.
wagyu.author: Mara A.
wagyu.review:
Thank you Kusakabe for an amazing dining experience to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday.

The grand omakase is definitely the way to go. Although 25 courses may seem like a lot, each course is perfectly timed so that you do not over eat or get too full too fast. At $150 pp, it is definitely a good value for the quality and amount of food.

The atmosphere of Kusakabe is friendly and inviting. My boyfriend and I felt very comfortable sitting at the sushi bar, and enjoyed our time making conversation with our sushi chef Brian.

The quality of the fish was in a class of its own, and I am definitely going to be dreaming of it until we find another chance to return. It's hard to pick a favorite of the night, but I'd have to say aside from the obvious A5 Wagyu and toro, the white Alaskan salmon was to die for. 

At the end of our meal, the whole staff and restaurant sang happy birthday to my boyfriend, and the sorbet they gave him was the perfect ending to an already perfect meal.

excerpts: Everything on the omakase menu for surprised us pleasantly dish after dish, but I think my favorite was the bonito, finale (got both wagyu beef and toro), and
wagyu.author: Annie L.
wagyu.review:
I really approve of this place! I had to make reservations a month in advance, but it was well worth the wait. 

I ended up taking my mom and we were seated at the sushi bar, pretty much immediately when we walked in. There was a bit of a wait before our waiter approached us, but the service was pretty good after that. Everything on the omakase menu for surprised us pleasantly dish after dish, but I think my favorite was the bonito, finale (got both wagyu beef and toro), and the kaisuke uni. 

Can't wait til my next visit :) really good price for omakase and the unique fish!

excerpts: It's undeniable that fish is extraordinary: the Toro Bluefin fatty tuna was incredible and the grade 5A Miyazaki Wagyu was "melt in your mouth" good.
But I wouldn't go as far to say that this was the BEST SUSHI EVER as most have mentioned in their reviews.
For this price point and being sealed with a Michelin Star I expected so much more than what I got.
wagyu.author: Caye Q.
wagyu.review:
I might just be the one weirdo who didn't fall head over heels with this place. 

It's undeniable that fish is extraordinary: the Toro Bluefin fatty tuna was incredible and the grade 5A Miyazaki Wagyu was "melt in your mouth" good. But I wouldn't go as far to say that this was the BEST SUSHI EVER as most have mentioned in their reviews. For this price point and being sealed with a Michelin Star I expected so much more than what I got. We ordered the chef's tasting menu and after the sushi prelude, sashimi, nigiri and sushi finale I was still unsatisfied. I left this place disappointed and wanting more.....

excerpts: We decided to go with the course with both the Wagyu and Toro finale, totally worth it!
wagyu.author: Kevin P.
wagyu.review:
So far, best sushi I've had in the city.  The whole experience was wonderful!  Right when you enter, you are greeted and sat at your reserved location.  We decided to go with the course with both the Wagyu and Toro finale, totally worth it!

Advice: if you want to have the head chef serve you, book as soon as the reservations are made available online!

excerpts: -WAGYU (A5 grade Miyazaki Wagyu strip loin):
Lightly seared and salted, it's definitely the best wagyu
sushi
I've had.
The sear is key!
-TORO (Bluefin fatty tuna belly): Ridiculous.
Watching Chef Kusakabe cut this fish and then watching the chefs gingerly pass the pieces down the line and then watching your chef assemble the sushi is a ridiculous level of anticipation.
wagyu.author: Christina L.
wagyu.review:
This place is OUT OF CONTROL. How much so? My fiance and I are currently trying to buy a house yet Kusakabe let us to a real discussion of whether it would be better to put our money into a mortgage or maybe just eating at Kusakabe a couple times every week. I mean, seriously, I'm sure owning your own home is overrated.

Kusakabe operates under a omakase menu style with a $95 or $150 option. We opted for the $95 option and it is pretty much set although the sushi chef has a little bit of wiggle room with 5 different seasonal sushis of the day. He will also ask you at the beginning what type of fish you usually like! Pro tip: MUST sit at the bar. After your omakase is done you can opt to go a la carte to try other types of fish. Spoiler alert: You will likely feel compelled to continue after your omakase is done, there is just so much good stuff to try!

Here's an overview of our meal. Standouts will be emphasized with CAPITAL LETTERS!
1. First brewed dashi: A light broth with tons of umami, good to kick off your appetite
2. Sushi Prelude: 
-SEARED CHUTORO comes standard and was amazing!
Two kinds of seasonal sushi of the day: 
-Hirame (Halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf) - I'm not usually a fan of halibut but this was really good quality and the shiso leaf added freshness while the liver added creaminess
-Katsuo (Lightly cherry wood smoked bonito) - Smokey flavor added a lot to this one and the smooth tuna texture had a great mouth feel
3. Sashimi course: Maguro and Hokkaido Scallop with fresh wasabe & yuzu onion sauce. Both really good quality, the scallop was sweet and delicious with a good portion and the yuzu onion sauce was intriguing.
4. Hassun: This was 7 bites served together and you are free to eat it in any order. I chose to try and eat it in order of lighter to heavier -
-Baby Eel: This was something new, not too much flavor but the broth it came in was delicious
-DUCK BREAST: refreshing to get a bite of meat and it was well cooked and served over broccolini
-Salmon wrapped in daikon: Good salmon flavor, tastes more refreshing with the daikon
-Kusshi oyster: Fresh oyster, yum
-Rice octopus: Good texture and flavor
-Tamago with snapper: This egg was super fluffy and sweet tasting, not like your usual tamago
-TORO ON BOX RICE: The toro was amazing and the rice perfectly seasoned
5. SOUP: Spring hamaguri soup with fresh bamboo shoot, wakame & shiitake mushrooms - perfect to have something warm. The clams were perfectly cooked, broth filled with umami.
6. Sushi Chic:
-BURI (Wild Yellowtail): Basically the best yellowtail ever. It had more fattiness like chutoro but tons of that delicious yellowtail flavor. See picture for amazing fattiness!
-Kuromutsu (Japanese blue fish): Very light flavor but nice bite and texture
-COPPER RIVER KING (Wild Alaskan king salmon with Oboro Konbu): Best salmon ever, so much flavor and the bit of seaweed on top gives it a touch of earthiness. 
7. Sushi Finale:
-WAGYU (A5 grade Miyazaki Wagyu strip loin): Lightly seared and salted, it's definitely the best wagyu sushi I've had. The sear is key!
-TORO (Bluefin fatty tuna belly): Ridiculous. Watching Chef Kusakabe cut this fish and then watching the chefs gingerly pass the pieces down the line and then watching your chef assemble the sushi is a ridiculous level of anticipation. And it was worth it.

At this point you're essentially devastated that your meal is over and it's time to make some tough decisions. We added:
-KAMASU: Lightly seared Japanese Barracuda - great sear flavor on a slightly fishier taking fish. Definitely a good add.
-TORO: What, again?? We needed to have another bite but this time our sushi chef seared the toro gently and added all sorts of other goodies. It completely changed up the flavor of the toro and was so worth it. MUST do again.

Next time I will add:
-KAISUI UNI (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin): If you're looking for a different type of uni this is an interesting bite. Creamier texture, lighter flavor, more sweet. We watched the guy next to us eat it jealously.
-JI KINMEDAI (Cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper): I didn't over this because I had it at Akiko's before but the guy next to us, again, said it was the best. Dammit. Next time.

All in all it was an amazing dining experience and I can't wait to go again! It is a SAN FRANCISCO MUST.

excerpts: Honestly the toro nigiri and wagyu A5 nigiri will be the best things to ever enter your mouth.
wagyu.author: Khanh T.
wagyu.review:
Honestly the toro nigiri and wagyu A5 nigiri will be the best things to ever enter your mouth.

Seriously though, this hands down was the best meal of my life. Every single detail of our meal here was perfection. The $95 omakase menu is a great value, considering you'd spend more per head at any other michelin star restaurant in SF. Of course, we couldn't resist tacking on a-la-carte items such as the life changing bafun uni, but we did bring our own sake and paid a modest $25 corkage fee (vs. $85 sake pairing per person).

Tip - Most of the seats here are at the sushi bar, so you have direct interaction with your sushi chef - a memorable experience that is unmatched by any other restaurant. However, if you're the last ones in for your seating time, you will be seated at the tables, so arrive on time if not early! There are two seatings per night - 5pm or 8pm.

excerpts: Of the omakase menu, my favorites were the Shigoku oyster with caviar with the petite plates, the miso glazed alaskan halibut, and the grade A5 wagyu beef.
SO DELICIOUS.
wagyu.author: June Y.
wagyu.review:
4.5 STARS. Took my mommy to a lovely dinner at Kusakabe yesterday to celebrate late mommy's day. My mother is just as crazy about sushi as I am (if not more) and after taking her to Wakuriya for her birthday, I had to find a comparable restaurant for Mother's day. Kusakabe is definitely of the same caliber as Wakuriya but the experience is entirely different.

Omakase style dinner is pretty much the Japanese version of prix fixe except with a little bit more excitement to it because certain parts of the menu (specifically the sashimi) will change depending on what the sushi chef feels like making. That being said, the chances of you liking every single type of sashimi may not be 100% but that's to be expected with any tasting menu. Still, while certain cuts of sashimi were too thick or too chewy for my taste, there's no denying the freshness and quality of the fish. Of the omakase menu, my favorites were the Shigoku oyster with caviar with the petite plates, the miso glazed alaskan halibut, and the grade A5 wagyu beef. SO DELICIOUS. I'll have seconds of those three dishes, please.

After the omakase (which lasts about 1.5 hours), they give you an a la carte menu to order from (you can only do a la carte after omakase). We tried the Aoebi (steamed blue prawn with crystallized egg yolk) - yummy but not what I expected. I imagined the crystallized egg yolk to look and taste different but it kind of just looked like yellow dyed roe and didn't really taste like anything. The steamed blue prawn was delicious though but I'm not quite sure if it's worth $7.5 per piece. We also tried the Sakuramasu (Japanese cherry salmon with cherry leaf) - yummy and melts in your mouth. The cherry salmon did not have the typical milky taste people tend to associate with salmon; the taste was milder but still delicious. For dessert, we each got a scoop of sweet potato ice cream which was super yummy! :)

Atmosphere is slightly busier than Wakuriya. They had about 4 servers and 5 sushi chefs (W only has one server and one sushi chef). The place is also slightly bigger and was able to accommodate approx. 20 people when we were there. 

Dining experience lasted about 2.5 hours and was paced perfectly. We didn't feel rushed throughout the meal nor did we have any awkwardly long wait time in between dishes.

Pricing wise, the omakase is $95 per person which I think is very reasonable for a Michelin star restaurant. Their a la carte items are more expensive if you consider each piece of nigiri is priced at around $7 to $15. This adds up fast but still, I would recommend trying one or two items from the a la carte menu and of course getting dessert!

Only street parking available but we found parking easy enough! There are a bunch of metered parking spaces available on Washington Street.

To sum it up, GO GO GO. Don't even think about the price or whatever else is stopping you. Just make that reservation!

excerpts: The wagyu beef was so good we got seconds of that.
wagyu.author: Lily L.
wagyu.review:
My dining companion and I came to Kusakabe  for dinner.  We called to say we were running 10 minutes late and the hostess was very understanding and thanked us for calling and told us not to worry.  We were seated at the sushi bar in Chef Nori's section.  What a treat.

The sushi is absolutely fresh and wonderful.  I loved his technique of smoking fish.  He placed the sliced fish on a cherry board and used a torch to burn the surrounding wood which gave the fish a slight hint of smokiness.  Delish!

We did the grand Omakase tasting menu with the sake pairing.  It was very good.  The portions were not enough so we ordered a few more items.  The wagyu beef was so good we got seconds of that.  He also had 3 types of uni that night: regular uni from Hokkaido, short spine uni from Hokkaido, and regular uni from Santa Barbara.  We got to do a side-by-side taste test.  We loved the two from Hokkaido the best.

I would go back in a heart beat...after I break the piggy bank.

excerpts: Cod egg, black salmon, shigoku oyster with french daurenki caviar, toro with salmon flakes, and wagyu beef.
My favorite was the cod egg since it tasted the most unique.
The sushi finale is either the bluefin fatty tuna or miyazaki wagyu beef.
My giflfriend and I split one of each.
The bluefin fatty tuna just melts in your mouth and
so does the wagyu beef because of
it's high fat content.
The wagyu is seared on one side and raw on the other side.
wagyu.author: Edward W.
wagyu.review:
Best meal experience ever!

I made a reservation for 5:45pm on Saturday night and had requested bar seating ahead of time. We were lucky enough to be seated right in front of Chef Kusakabe! 

The kaiseki began with kelp tea, something I've never had before, but exactly how you would imagine it to taste.

The sushi prelude consisted of zuke chutoro, halibut, and bonito. The halibut was served with bits of halibut liver, adding a nice kick to each bite. 

The sashimi had hokkaido scalop and blue fin tuna nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi and yuzu onion sauce. I found the scallop surprisingly not chewy and delicious. I'd highly recommend using the sauce to give the sashimi lots of flavor.

The "kamo dango" duck and "asari" clam Miso soup with Mitsuba leaf
large clam tasted amazing and overflowing with flavor. The duck meatballs were quite a treat. 

The hassun consisted of 5 different petite plates. Cod egg, black salmon, shigoku oyster with french daurenki caviar, toro with salmon flakes, and wagyu beef. My favorite was the cod egg since it tasted the most unique. I've never had caviar before, but it just tasted salty.

The warm dish was a tofu-chwan-mushi with fresh steamed dungeness crab and nameko mushroom. It tasted so good and I wish I could have had more.

The sushi chic consisted of wild hamachi, japanese barracuda, and alaskan king salmon with sakura leaf.
 
The sushi finale is either the bluefin fatty tuna or miyazaki wagyu beef. My giflfriend and I split one of each. The bluefin fatty tuna just melts in your mouth and so does the wagyu beef because of it's high fat content. The wagyu is seared on one side and raw on the other side.

After the Kaiseki style meal, we were presented with the a la Carte menu. We opted for the shirayaki (fresh bbq white eel) and the hokkaido sea urchin. This sea urchi tasted extremely creamy and is the best I've had. It is shipped from Japan and packed with ocean water to maintain the freshness. The piece of shirayaki was thicker than most unagi, had a crunchy skin, and sauced perfectly.

For dessert we had the yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet. I really enjoyed this dessert and it was not very sweet at all with lots of natural yuzu flavor.

This place really encourages eating sushi the traditional way, aka with your fingers. I thought it greatly added to the experience and having Chef Kusakabe serve us personally was a HUGE plus. In between dishes, we had the pleasure of watching him masterfully prep the sashimi. I'd highly recommend coming here and sitting at the bar.

excerpts: The finishing A5 Miyazaki wagyu beef and otoro sushi melted like butter in my mouth and ended the meal on a high.
One of my all time favorite sushi experiences with excellent service.
wagyu.author: Kevin B.
wagyu.review:
Perfectly seasoned and fresh sushi that came at a good pace. Thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish. I normally don't like uni but the uni scallop sushi flavors blended together well.

I enjoyed the non-sushi dishes. The Les petit plats was fun to explore and a good variety between sushi pieces. The snap pea soup with crispy fish was surprisingly flavorful.

The finishing A5 Miyazaki wagyu beef and otoro sushi melted like butter in my mouth and ended the meal on a high. One of my all time favorite sushi experiences with excellent service.

excerpts: I've tasted better toro and wagyu preparation as well
but it was still good.
wagyu.author: Nit A.
wagyu.review: Hmm, okay. So I love sushi. In short, I don't think they deserve a 5 star...at least on the night I went. I did the grand omakase with my friends. Yes there were some interesting dishes in the beginning but towards the end, the quality of their nigiri went down. Maybe it wasn't cured correctly? It was fishy. The owner/chef didn't seem to care all that much. Maybe he was having a bad day- which is fine. It's not the reason why I gave the 4 stars. It just means that he's human. $250/per person. I've tasted better toro and wagyu preparation as well but it was still good.

excerpts: - Sushi Finale - ended with Unagi (BBQ eel) and a choice of toro or wagyu beef.
I'd recommend the wagyu beef since it is so tender and they sear it right in front of you with a touch of pepper.
It just melted in my mouth like butter.
wagyu.author: Jingxi Z.
wagyu.review:
Best omakase by far in SF! My lovely BF surprised me with reservations here for our anniversary and oh my god it was such a beautiful and creative dining experience.

Reservations become available online 2 months in advance and for the true omakase experience you gotta sit at the sushi bar so you can watch your chef can personalize each part of the meal to your liking :) 

They only serve omakase, a $150 grand set or the $95 set, with options for add-ons at the end of the meal. Feeling fancy, we opted for the grand set and if you're looking for a time to splurge, this would be it!

The omakase experience is unique to each restaurant but the creativity and care that goes into each piece is where Kusakabe really shines. Each dish was well-thought out and went beyond just the typical nigiri. Before our meal our sushi chef asked us if there was anything we didn't like or really liked. I really dislike wasabi and usually for omakase they add it to every piece of sushi. However our chef made sure to only put a small amount for all my pieces and I couldn't even taste it!

I believe the menu changes seasonally, but here's what we had:
- Ichiban Dashi - first up was soup, like a fancier version of miso soup, probably the best soup I've had using dashi broth!
- Sushi prelude - next we were served 5 pieces of nigiri sushi, one was the king of all sushi - the toro tuna! So soft and buttery, each and every piece. The other 4 pieces were seasonal and the chef makes sure to tell you where each fish comes from :) I believe we had scallop from Santa Barbara!
- Sashimi - next we were given four different types of sashimi paired with 4 different unique types of sauce/toppings. One included truffle shavings and another was mussels. The flavor combos were so good, although some I liked more than others but definitely all flavors I had never tried before.
- Hassun - the creativity continues with a box of a random assortment of seafood in all shapes and forms. But presentation on point for errything. Honestly some weren't that tasty (there was a weird seafood cracker that I didn't like) but again, just so unique and such detailed preparation.
- Soup - this was a creamy cauliflower soup with abalone and abalone mushrooms. Tasted like a lighter version of clam chowder but seriously soo delicious!
- Sushi Chic - more nigiri sushi including uni (sea urchin) from Santa Barbara! I'm not a big uni fan but oh boy this one was so buttery and creamy and slightly sweet. Definitely can taste the quality and freshness!
- Sushi Finale - ended with Unagi (BBQ eel) and a choice of toro or wagyu beef. I'd recommend the wagyu beef since it is so tender and they sear it right in front of you with a touch of pepper. It just melted in my mouth like butter. How is this possible?! 

On top of the amazing food was amazing service. They surprised us at the end with sorbet at the end to celebrate our anniversary! If you want a perfect dining experience this is it.

excerpts: The wagyu was mediocre probably because they added too much salt.
The yuzu sorbet wasn't that great either as the shiso leaf taste too strong.
wagyu.author: Sylvia C.
wagyu.review:
One Word: Delicious! Came here for valentine's day, so we ordered the grand omakase. The nigiri was amazing. Every sauce or pairing enhanced the flavor of the fish so well, I would have stayed there all night. After the omakase, you are free to order whatever you like. I was in love with the Kasai Uni! Had 1 spoonful, then I ordered 3 more for myself. My second favorite would be the baracuda. Although the fish was only seared, the crisp on top and the sweet taste was perfect.

The wagyu was mediocre probably because they added too much salt. The yuzu sorbet wasn't that great either as the shiso leaf taste too strong. But on the bright side, they creme Brulee was good. 

Service was great. The waiters were quite attentive and our glass was always full.

excerpts: Only difference will be the portion and maybe the wagyu beef at the end.
wagyu.author: t.s. and r.s. x.
wagyu.review:
My Fiance took me here on my birthday last year and I loved it! The experience was excellent from making the reservation to enjoying the meal.

Since then we've probably eaten here 3 more times. They now have a "Grand Omakase" option. Value-wise it's great and it's also very filling. Let me break my experience down. 

OMAKASE: a set menu of deliciousness. All 90% of the sushi served is nigiri. The fish is fresh and the flavors are not overwhelming. Good and simple does the trick. We recently had the "grand omakase" and it was filling for me. Why opt for the GRAND version? It has more sushi pieces and popular items that are usually ordered are already included. In the end, the GRAND will save you more money.
The regular Omakase is still an excellent option. The experience and quality of fish does not change with the regular omakase. Only difference will be the portion and maybe the wagyu beef at the end. 

SAKE: Kusakabe offers a wine or sake pairing. My husband always tried the sake and I would take little sips just to try (I'm a lightweight.). Let me tell you, this place serves some of the best sake! I'm definitely more of a sake person than wine. You don't have to do the pairing but I do suggest the Dassai "Centrifuge." It's light, sweet, and not too dry. 

CUSTOMER SERVICE: Excellent. I have nothing more to say except that they are on point. 

CON: pricey but it is high quality. Some items on the petit plats were not my favorite. 

This place is a must if you love traditional sushi. Highly recommended! Definitely a Michelin star deserving establishment.

excerpts:
It melted in your mouth like butter
Wagyu beef - this was the best wagyu beef that I've ever had.
