IMO this was a mistake as the few extra pieces do not really justify paying 50% more. In fact I felt overstuffed at the end, so much so that it was difficult to enjoy the Grande Finale of Wagyu beef and Toro sushi. Speaking of Toro, I was pretty disappointed to see a major vein running up the center of the fish (I saw this was true for the Toro that everyone else received, too). I'm sorry, but you would never see that in a high end sushi restaurant in Japan. The whole point of dining in these places is to enjoy a quality of fish that you cannot find in your average neighborhood joint. Now to be fair the atmosphere is nice, the staff is attentive, and the menu features many price points for sake. The food itself is beautiful (though the tourist taking photos of every piece are a bit annoying). Some of the sushi is really, really good, and the all important rice is top quality. But I could do without the Hassan middle course in a box which just seemed like filler. For half the price this would be a steal, but at this price point you quite a expect a bit more.

excerpts: The non-nigiri dishes were fantastic as well -- miso soup with duck meatballs, assorted sashimi, and wagyu beef, among a few others.
wagyu.author: Amanda L.
wagyu.review:
Perfect. And an amazing experience for only $95. I'll definitely be back every time I'm in San Francisco.

We sat at the sushi bar to watch all the action. Chef Kusakabe executed dinner with such attention to detail. He was friendly and talked to his guests. We felt so welcome!

The rest of the staff was just as great. Our servers were so sweet and incredibly helpful about sake recommendations. They continually checked on us to make sure we were enjoying everything (and we were).

The food was worth every penny. The fish was so fresh, and each piece of nigiri had a unique flavor. The non-nigiri dishes were fantastic as well -- miso soup with duck meatballs, assorted sashimi, and wagyu beef, among a few others.

I let them know it was my birthday when I made my reservation, and they did the whole happy birthday she-bang with soy milk ice cream. It was the cherry on top of a great meal.

Don't even think about it. Just make reservations and go, before it becomes impossible to get a table.

excerpts: Be prepared to indulge, but for the price you pay, you do get really good quality food you probably won't find anywhere else (like wagyu beef!
Yum!).
Come here for special occasions and request sitting at the bar.
Watching the chefs work their magic is lots of fun!
wagyu.author: Alex D.
wagyu.review: My boyfriend and I are always on the lookout for great sushi places in the Bay Area so when I saw that this was relatively new but had great reviews, I checked it out and RSVP'd with some reluctance. However, we were both very surprised and excited with the food and the amazing service. You'll definitely get a full meal here with the omakase menu. If you count up how many pieces of sushi you'll get plus all the extra little dishes, you'll leave happy (and with a bit of a food coma). Be prepared to indulge, but for the price you pay, you do get really good quality food you probably won't find anywhere else (like wagyu beef! Yum!). Come here for special occasions and request sitting at the bar. Watching the chefs work their magic is lots of fun!

excerpts: This is not solely sushi, course items include a choice of soup( summer truffle, or duck dumpling, both miso based), wagyu beef, konbu cha (which is meant to be a palate cleanser ), as well as a small plate that varies with each visit.
Please note that a true omakase takes time, as each piece of sushi is delicately prepared to perfection in front of your eyes.
I prefer the wagyu beef over the toro option at the end of the meal, but it's personal preference as both are wonderfully prepared.
I love and seek out the highest quality beef in the world.
wagyu.author: Alexandra C.
wagyu.review:
I have been waiting to write this review until after I had the pleasure of dining at Masa, in New York. Masa (450$ per person for omakase-+150$pp for kobe supplement), is highly regarded as the best quality sushi and sushi experience in America. 
I have dined at Kusakabe 6 times now and I will continue to frequent this spot. Kusakabe is on the same level as Masa. Kusakabe blows all other SF sushi restaurants out of the water, including Akiko's and Maruya, by far. The experience that dining at Kusakabe delivers far surpasses all sushi experiences that I have had in the US, other than Masa, which is just as good. I will go as far as to say that Kusakabe is the French Laundry of Sushi.

After returning from Japan, I have had a difficult time soothing my crave for the love of good sushi. In the Bay Area, it's almost appalling that we don't have great sushi bars, considering the large Japanese population. I had temporarily eased my fix at Sakae Sushi in San Mateo, but after discovering Kusakabe I can finally sleep peacefully at night knowing that quality sushi as great tasting and painstakingly prepared as I found in Japan, can also be found right here in San Francisco. It really is a dream come true, if you are a fellow sushi-lover and self-proclaimed sushi connoisseur, you will surely understand. 

Things that you need to understand before you dine here:
1. True Kaiseki style (Omakase) means that the chef's have prepared a menu for the day, depending on availability of product, and season of fish/food. Adjustments are made accordingly to individual diners tastes. You will be asked at the start of the meal, "What is your favorite sushi?" 
2.The menu differs from day to day, week to week, depending upon availability. You will trust in the sushi chef(either  Mitsunori Kusakabe or Ken Ngai) to deliver a mind-blowing, taste-bud tingling experience to your body & soul for 95$ per person. 
3.After you have enjoyed the set number of courses (about 10 filling courses), you may order nigiri/sashimi or hand rolls from the a la carte menu.
4. Do not come here without a reservation, you won't be seated. Reservations are booked weeks in advance so I recommend scheduling them far apart and many in between. 
5. This is not solely sushi, course items include a choice of soup( summer truffle, or duck dumpling, both miso based), wagyu beef, konbu cha (which is meant to be a palate cleanser ), as well as a small plate that varies with each visit. 
6. Please note that a true omakase takes time, as each piece of sushi is delicately prepared to perfection in front of your eyes. Expect to dine for 2-3 hours and enjoy every minute of the experience.

At just 95$ per person, some may see this as a deal, others as a special occasion splurge , either way, regardless of your budget,  you are truly getting the finest fish and quality ingredients in the world at Kusakabe. You will leave feeling warm, fuzzy, satisfied and enlightened. 

I am an Uni fiend, so I love to try all of the uni types available on the a la carte menu. My favorite is the Bafun Uni, if you love uni, you will respect the way it is prepared at Kusakabe. 
I am hooked on the summer truffle miso soup, which I expect will soon disappear as we move on to winter truffle season. I am highly anticipated any new supplements to the menu as I know they will be just as delicious.
I prefer the wagyu beef over the toro option at the end of the meal, but it's personal preference as both are wonderfully prepared. I love and seek out the highest quality beef in the world.
All of the desserts are great, my favorite is the yuzu sorbet as it is so light and refreshing, yet packed with flavor.

One of the greatest aspects of Kusakabe as an establishment is the impeccable regard for simplicity of design, which is, to me, the most challenging aspect of cuisine to master. Everything, down to the sushi bar itself, which is made from a singular piece of soft, bleached Japanese wood called hinoki, is meticulously thought out and strategically placed.

I can only describe my experiences at Kusakabe as divine and addicting. I would recommend Kusakabe to all people with an open mind and appreciation for artistic cuisine and world-class food.

excerpts: The final item on the menu was the Toro or Wagyu.
My wife picked the Toro and I picked the Wagyu, and we both loved it!
So much, we got another piece.
My wife picked the Toro and I picked the Wagyu, and we both loved it!
So much, we got another piece.
If you like sushi, I'd recommend going with the Toro to wrap up an excellent meal.
wagyu.author: John C.
wagyu.review:
Best sushi in the Bay Area.

My wife is a big fan of Sushi, while I tolerate it. However, I have to admit that Kusakabe is Amazing! Fixed course meal which cost about $125 per person. Not bad for a Michelin star (and much cheaper than comparable sushi in Japan, HK or Singapore). 

The final item on the menu was the Toro or Wagyu. My wife picked the Toro and I picked the Wagyu, and we both loved it! So much, we got another piece. If you like sushi, I'd recommend going with the Toro to wrap up an excellent meal.

excerpts: The Wagyu was to die for.
wagyu.author: Anj H.
wagyu.review:
Came here around the time when the restaurant first opened. Great ambience, attentive service (waitress who was extremely knowledgeable about different well-acclaimed sushi restaurants in Japan.. also gave us great recommendation for sake).

Food was FANTASTIC!! Soo fresh that each bite of the fish melted in your mouth. The Wagyu was to die for. The Omakase menu was delish but be prepared to order dishes off the a la carte because you won't be full... 

Overall a wonderful experience. Will definitely go back again!

excerpts: so we went with the $150 selection and finished with the Toro, and we each ordered wagyu a la carte after the meal.
There was not a single piece that we did not enjoy.
Our favorites were of course the Toro and wagyu, but the barbecue eel was right there with them.
It was amazing.
Our favorites were of course the Toro and wagyu, but the barbecue eel was right there with them.
It was amazing.
After the omakase, a la carte wagyu, bottle of wine, and tip, it was just under $500 walking away.
Pricey, but well worth it for a once in a lifetime dining experience.
If we ever come back to SF, we will be paying Kusakabe another visit!
Make sure you sit at the bar so you can see the chefs work their magic with the food.
It is an amazing sight to witness.
wagyu.author: James M.
wagyu.review: After extensive research on Bay Area dining experiences, my wife and I decided to eat dinner here while we were on vacation in SF last week. Without question, Kusakabe did not disappoint! This was our first time at an omakase style restaurant, so we were not quite sure what to expect. However, we will try anything when it comes to food so we went with the $150 selection and finished with the Toro, and we each ordered wagyu a la carte after the meal. There was not a single piece that we did not enjoy. Our favorites were of course the Toro and wagyu, but the barbecue eel was right there with them. It was amazing. After the omakase, a la carte wagyu, bottle of wine, and tip, it was just under $500 walking away. Pricey, but well worth it for a once in a lifetime dining experience.  If we ever come back to SF, we will be paying Kusakabe another visit! Make sure you sit at the bar so you can see the chefs work their magic with the food. It is an amazing sight to witness.

excerpts: When our server came to take our order, we had make a choice for which soup we wanted (course number 5 or so), and also our last dish (wagyu or fatty tuna).
End to end, each dish was fantastic.
I was skeptical about whether or not I would be full after our meal, but I was stuffed.
I was also skeptical about whether or not I'd be able to tell the difference between all the different types of fish in the tasting menu
and I can absolutely tell you, with fish of this quality, you can absolutely taste the difference.
Bring your special somebody here for a special occasion.
You won't regret it.
wagyu.author: Austin W.
wagyu.review: I brought my girlfriend here for her birthday and we had an excellent dining experience. Although we had reservations through Open Table and were seated immediately at 5pm when they opened, there were a few tables that remained open during our meal, so I don't think a reservation (for a table at least) is *required*. Taking the advice of fellow Yelpers, I noted in my reservation that I wanted to sit at the bar, and wow, what an experience. You sit a foot away from the sushi chef delicately prepping each piece of the tasting menu and it is something that you do not want to miss. The tasting menu is the only dining option that Kusakabe offers (to my knowledge), but they are very accommodating if you have dietary restrictions. When our server came to take our order, we had make a choice for which soup we wanted (course number 5 or so), and also our last dish (wagyu or fatty tuna). End to end, each dish was fantastic. I was skeptical about whether or not I would be full after our meal, but I was stuffed. I was also skeptical about whether or not I'd be able to tell the difference between all the different types of fish in the tasting menu and I can absolutely tell you, with fish of this quality, you can absolutely taste the difference. Bring your special somebody here for a special occasion. You won't regret it.

excerpts: The wagyu beef was also to die for.
This was one of the best meals of my life.
wagyu.author: Danielle T.
wagyu.review: This was easily the best Nigiri I've ever had. Shin was our chef and he was phenomenal. We sat at the sushi bar and were intrigued by the detail and originality that went into each piece. The meal was kaiseki style -- we had the tasting menu (and I ordered extra pieces of the zuke chotoro-- easily my favorite). The wagyu beef was also to die for. This was one of the best meals of my life.

excerpts: Wagyu beef was amazing.
wagyu.author: Cindy L.
wagyu.review:
Amazing night.

Best scallop sashimi I ever tasted. Wagyu beef was amazing. Everything else was super delicious!

Our waitress Hiromi (not sure how to spell it correctly) was amazing - super kind and we got to know each other :D

Definitely coming back for more.

excerpts: Kisu:
kisu.author: Marilyn H.
kisu.review:
I've been back quite a few times since the first review, and I think it's gotten better in the last year as they re-structured and changed up the menu. 

We started with a sake flight - three 4 oz pours that were all quite different ($50.) We ended up getting two more 8 oz sakes, and in the end, the sake and food cost about the same. Sake definitely complements the sushi, though.  I love their glassware (design, thinness). Sadly, it's pretty much all from a special source in Japan and is not easy to get

We did the grand tasting ($150/person) and some add ons.
1. Dashi to start: served warm in a small cup

2. Sushi: I love their rice, and I liked each piece of the sushi to the point that there was no clear cut favorite
  - Seared chutoro: nice and fatty, cured with soy sauce, love the sear 
  - Hirame: wild halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf
  - Katsuo: smoked in cherry wood, topped with garlic, chives, radish, and it tasted almost like bbq  
  - Hotate: super sweet and tender, topped with uni 
  - Baby snapper topped with crystallized egg yolk 

3. Sashimi: the maguro and barracuda were meant to be dipped with either house grated onion with yuzu, chive, and salt or traditional soy sauce + wasabi
  - Thinly sliced salmon wrapped around cucumber with a bamboo charcoal miso: the miso was very unique 
  - Red snapper: wrapped with ankimo, topped with Italian summer truffle and sitting on a ponzu truffle gelee.  I couldn't taste the truffle much, but the gelee was good 
  - Kamazu: barracuda with micro onion
  - Maguro

4. Hassun: this was a beautifully arranged platter with lots of flavors and textures
  - Oyster with caviar
  - Tempura crab: coated in rice crackers
  - Shrimp cake with sweet corn: best eaten warm; good with dipping salt 
  - Nasu agedashi: served in a little glass bowl with kani and ikura; this dish is very light
  - Squid: very thinly sliced, with baby kiwi, toasted pine nuts, and wakame. The wakame was my favorite part of the dish
  - Box sushi: tuna topped with bonito flakes
  - Box sushi: tamago with a layer of crab underneath, topped with a goji berry 
  - Fried fish with red onion and a vinegar dashi

5. Soup: Puree of cauliflower, which was very rich tasting. It came with a sweet potato paste in the center for more sweetness and thickness, abalone, trumpet mushrooms, abalone mushrooms

6. Sushi Chic and Sushi Finale 
  - Shima aji: topped with daikon and yuzu
  - Arctic char: with sea salt and yuzu 
  - Sanma: with grated ginger lime zest, and chives
  - Uni, but I opted for non uni, and it was a torched oily snapper cured in kombu, which was really good 
  - Shirayaki: BBQ white eel, finished with a light drizzle of sauce and sansho pepper. I like that the sauce doesn't obscure the fish
  - Wagyu (you could also choose toro): A5, super smooth and buttery

Extras: prices range from $6-15 per piece (tamago vs uni)
  - Jin kinmedai: golden eye snapper smoked in cherry wood
  - Kisu: whiting cured with bonito and konbu

We were too full for dessert by the end.  It ends up being a lot of food.  My only complaint is that there's only one bathroom, so there can sometimes be a wait. 

Service is always impeccable, and Chef Ngai did a great job of educating us on the dishes. Definitely get a seat at the sushi bar. I've done a table once, and it was NOT the same.  I think it's a party of 3 or so max for the sushi bar; otherwise, you get seated at the table.

excerpts: Newly discovered favorite nigiri was the kisu.
Looking forward to my next dining experience here.
kisu.author: Dorothy L.
kisu.review: Another spectacular dining experience at Kusakabe.  You are such a bad influence on my wallet.  I'm a fan of the nigiri.  Wish we could just order straight from the a la carte menu.  Still love the toro and wagyu beef.  Newly discovered favorite nigiri was the kisu.  Looking forward to my next dining experience here.

excerpts: I especially enjoyed the kisu, which I had never had before, and the o-toro finale was out of this world.
The truffle miso soup course was also excellent, with a depth of flavors I had never had before in a soup.
kisu.author: Michelle C.
kisu.review: Truly an exceptional dining experience.  If you love authentic sushi, then you really must come here.  The ambiance is very close to what you would expect to find at a similar establishment in Tokyo.  You should absolutely request seats at the sushi bar if they are available, and even better if you are seated right in front of the chef, who is a master artist.  Everyone in the restaurant is friendly, polite, and unobtrusive.  You could tell our server was truly invested in making sure we had a wonderful experience, and was excited to share her recommendations with us.  The sushi itself is incredible.  Each piece was expertly crafted, with complex flavors blending together beautifully.  I especially enjoyed the kisu, which I had never had before, and the o-toro finale was out of this world.  The truffle miso soup course was also excellent, with a depth of flavors I had never had before in a soup.  The aji was also incredible, as was the Hokkaido uni (deep sea) that you can select a la carte after the omakase menu is complete.  The chef explained each piece you received, and was also pleasant and friendly.  Kusakabe truly brings a taste of Tokyo haute cuisine to the Bay Area, something we had always lamented was missing from the restaurant scene.  We are so happy that Kusakabe is here!

excerpts: All in all my favorite was no doubt the A5 Wagyu beef, Uni, eel, and tuna.
I was quite happy (and full) by the end
uni.author: Bob L.
uni.review:
With so many omakase locations in San Francisco I was pleased to learn from a local friend that I made a correct choice in choosing this location!

We were able to book a month ahead of time with no problems online and were promptly seated when we arrived.  

Right from the get-go I can see this location has been tweaked into a well-oiled machine since despite the fact that there were easily 6+ sushi chef's working for the people at the bar AND for the people in the small dining tables, there was no sign of any chaos.  Everyone was busy but they communicated well and weren't bumping around or reaching over another person which was quite impressive to me.

We went for the 11 course omakase menu which was $168 per person (not including tip or alcohol) which may come off as steep to many people but one must remember that you're there for an experience!  All of the chefs and wait staff were knowledgeable and were keen to explain every little ingredient in every dish which was very much appreciated (though so expansive it started to go over my head after a while).  They must have sensed this as they brought me the ala cart menu to let me know exactly what we were having which was a nice touch.  

Our chef was young but very precise and I could see the focus he had on every dish.  Speaking of dishes, they were excellent and quite unique in flavor.  This establishment favors meshing of multiple ingredients to create a very delicate but complex flavor profile which is different from other sushi omakases I've been to.  

All in all my favorite was no doubt the A5 Wagyu beef, Uni, eel, and tuna.  I was quite happy (and full) by the end and they were kind enough to place a new copy of the ala-cart menu as well as the omakase menu into an envelope to bring home with you!

If you're new to the omakase experience you can always try their "petite" omakase which is 8 courses but at a more reasonable $98 per person!

excerpts: Some dishes included scallop and uni straight from Hokkaido, wagyu beef from Miyazaki, and other kinds of seafood that I've never heard of.
uni.author: Garrett F.
uni.review:
I've been wanting to try omakase for a very long time, and spent some time researching what the top omakase restaurants were in San Francisco.  There were a ton of "top 10" lists and I narrowed the restaurants down to the "top 3" because if I was going to pay a lot, I wanted the best experience possible.

After looking at all the different omakase restuarants' menus, I eventually decided on Kusakabe.  I looked on their website, and the restaurant seemed pretty popular because most of the reservation spots were taken.

As I entered Kusakabe, I noticed right away that most, if not all, the staff spoke both really good English and Japanese.

I was escorted to my seat, and ordered the Omakase.

The Omakase includes dishes you will not see at a standard Japanese restaurant, and you'll be served one dish (i.e. sushi) at a time.  When you complete each dish, the chef will work on the next dish for you, and you can watch him make it right in front of you.  Some dishes included scallop and uni straight from Hokkaido, wagyu beef from Miyazaki, and other kinds of seafood that I've never heard of.  The food is top notch; the ingredients were fresh and the chef makes your food like it's truly a piece of art.

The service is also top notch.  After each dish was presented, the components of the dish were explained.  Additionally, my water was continuously refilled, and staff asked how my meal was so far throughout the service.

This was an experience of a lifetime; I enjoyed every bite!

I highly recommend!

excerpts: Their uni was so tender it was almost like liquid.
uni.author: Young Y.
uni.review:
Been here twice. Keep forgetting how good this place is. Not for the faint of heart, it's pricey. $98 for the petite 8-course and $168 for the 11-course. Once, I started down the 8-course and promptly switched to the 11-course. 

Notable sushi: usually hate squid and it was melt in your mouth. Their uni was so tender it was almost like liquid. The bonito was great and might be my new favorite. 

Great staff and mostly Japanese. Fine sake selection and I had a nice, crisp seasonal sake for $44 8oz. Splurging with no regrets.

excerpts: My favorites include the otoro, uni, wagyu nigiri and the tofu tiramisu dessert.
The otoro and wagyu nigari just melt in your mouth, and then left a lingering, exquisite umami aftertaste.
The uni handroll has everything: the creaminess of the uni, the crunchiness of the seaweed, and the softness of the rice.
It created the WOW moment the second I put it in my mouth.
Also the tiramisu tofu dish was so delicious, and it has this unique soy taste, reminiscent of some desserts in my hometown.
Overall the best omakase experience ever, and will definitely come back!
uni.author: Yeya Z.
uni.review: I regret to dine at Kusakabe as it has spoiled my taste bud so much that I can never go back to regular sushi LOL. We sit at the sushi bar, facing directly to chef Kusakabe, and see how the magic happens from his hand to our plate. We ordered the petit omakase, which is filling enough and at the same time leaving my stomach with enough room for some a la carte dishes after. My favorites include the otoro, uni, wagyu nigiri and the tofu tiramisu dessert. The otoro and wagyu nigari just melt in your mouth, and then left a lingering, exquisite umami aftertaste. The uni handroll has everything: the creaminess of the uni, the crunchiness of the seaweed, and the softness of the rice. It created the WOW moment the second I put it in my mouth. Also the tiramisu tofu dish was so delicious, and it has this unique soy taste, reminiscent of some desserts in my hometown.  Overall the best omakase experience ever, and will definitely come back!

excerpts: We even ordered additional uni and some of our favorite sashimi.
uni.author: Karen L.
uni.review:
I took my husband here for his birthday and was really blown away by their omakase menu. We chose the full menu which was $168 person and it was completely worth it. 

We sat at the sushi bar with a dedicated sushi chef. Bar seating is recommended as it's a more intimate experience, they have a few sit down tables but not for large parties. Our sushi chef was a bit quiet however super skilled and professional. I've never had sushi quite like this, flavors are perfectly balanced and served just at the right temperature. 

Each course complimented each other and we were constantly impressed by the next. We even ordered additional uni and some of our favorite sashimi. I highly recommend this experience, only wished Kusakabe himself was present that night!

5 STARS

excerpts: The scallops with uni were super delicious, but we had expected that ;)
uni.author: Cal C.
uni.review:
Good, and definitely $$$$. We were promptly seated at 8:15pm tonight, and were lucky enough to get seated at the bar.

A5 Wagyu is a must. The scallops with uni were super delicious, but we had expected that ;) The 6 small plates from Chef's selection were unique.

The eel was delicious too. Hot and crispy on the top.

Everything was good though quite pricey for what it was... Torn between 4 and 4.5. (Sorry I rounded down!)

excerpts: My favorites of the night were the toro, and the Hokkaido uni.
The fried tofu soup, the fish jelly, and the shrimp roll - didn't care for them much.
Service was good.
We left very full and very happy.
uni.author: Basil M.
uni.review:
This was the best sushi I have ever had, there was just a few misses. 
We opted for the full omakase experience. 
Almost Every course was well thought out and well executed. My favorites of the night were the toro, and the Hokkaido uni. The fried tofu soup, the fish jelly, and the shrimp roll - didn't care for them much. 
Service was good. 
We left very full and very happy.

excerpts: The most memorable for me was actually the "deep sea" uni, which is very different from regular uni (if you can call uni regular at all).
Deep sea uni tastes like an... UNI CLOUD!
It's delicious!
It's like a cotton candy fluff with 10x the uni flavor.
SO YUM.
The only reason I cannot give Kusakabe 5 stars is because of the price.
For $100, you will leave hungry.
uni.author: Sherry L.
uni.review: Super belated review for Kusakabe. I came here within a year of its opening, so it was a looooong time ago, obviously. Kusakabe definitely serves the highest of high end sushi. It's expensive, to be sure. But man oh man, you will enjoy every piece. The most memorable for me was actually the "deep sea" uni, which is very different from regular uni (if you can call uni regular at all). Deep sea uni tastes like an... UNI CLOUD! It's delicious! It's like a cotton candy fluff with 10x the uni flavor. SO YUM. The only reason I cannot give Kusakabe 5 stars is because of the price. For $100, you will leave hungry.

excerpts: My favorites were the toro, golden eye snapper, sea bream milt w/ quail egg, wagyu beef, and scallop w/ uni.
Really the only item I thought was just okay was the fried carrot and tofu cake in broth.
But that's just being nitpicky.
They prepare these items very well.
uni.author: Alfie B.
uni.review:
I love sushi. I've done an omakase style meal before at a restaurant in Atlanta, but was really excited to see what San Francisco had to offer, which was a lot!  I ended up eating here at Kusakabe for Cinco de Mayo and selected their 11 course omakase. Long story short...it was amazing!

From the moment I walked in, I was treated very well by all levels of staff. The hostess was incredibly helpful and polite. Servers were super attentive; my glass was never less than half full. My sushi chef Patrick was very friendly and informative about each item that was presented to me.

The restaurant had a very warm, intimate atmosphere. Very inviting and good for a date night. There were all around little touches I really appreciated like the little hooks near your knee to hang any small bags, how when I came back from the bathroom my napkin was made up again, or the meticulous way they place and plate all your dishes/utensils (even positioning my pen I brought to take notes...what can I say, I'm a nerd!). They treat you right here!

As for the food...amazing. My favorites were the toro, golden eye snapper, sea bream milt w/ quail egg, wagyu beef, and scallop w/ uni. Really the only item I thought was just okay was the fried carrot and tofu cake in broth.  But that's just being nitpicky. They prepare these items very well. I still can't get over how tender and soft the scallop was; I never thought a scallop could almost melt in my mouth!  

After the meal they give you an a la carte menu where you can order more stuff if you choose (I ordered a second helping of the sea bream milt :)).  I really wanted to try more of the stuff on their menu, and am curious to see what all they offer during other seasons. This is an easy 5 stars for me. Kusakabe served some of the best sushi I've ever had in my life!

excerpts: Toro, uni and the cod smelt were definitely the highlight dishes of the night.
I never had cod smelt before and didn't even bother to ask, but was admittedly taken a back post swallow when I found out I had just eaten fresh cod sperm.
Probably less surprised and more embarrassed since I had just seconds earlier expressed my excitement loudly to the chef about how "smooth and creamy" it was.
Heeyyyyy.
uni.author: Joanna Q.
uni.review:
Nectar of the gods. This place was everything I dreamed it would be and quality was definitely on par with what I experienced in Japan.

Kusakabe is Kaiseki style - a Japanese  style of serving food as a multi-course meal. The service was exceptional and all the dishes were amazing. I can see why it's so popular. Be ready to throw down a pretty penny though. For two people with the Grand Omakase option and a couple drinks  I think the total bill came out to about $500 including tip and tax.

Toro, uni and the cod smelt were definitely the highlight dishes of the night. I never had cod smelt before and didn't even bother to ask, but was admittedly taken a back post swallow when I found out I had just eaten fresh cod sperm. Probably less surprised and more embarrassed since I had just seconds earlier expressed my excitement loudly to the chef about how "smooth and creamy" it was. Heeyyyyy. ‍

excerpts: Next, the relatively chewy sumi ika (Japanese cuttlefish squid) with uni (sea urchin) and sayori (Japanese half beak cured with ryuhi konbu) provided textural contrast.

This was followed by a palate-cleansing bowl of soup, which opened the way for a course of shima aji (stripe jack), a super-delicious piece of copper river king salmon, and ebodai (Japanese butter fish), followed further by bafun uni (Hokkaido short spine sea urchin) and a deliciously seared piece of shirayaki (fresh BBQ white eel with sansho pepper).
uni.author: Vincent L.
uni.review:
I've gotten into the habit of marking every 100th Yelp review of mine with a Michelin-starred establishment, and I'm pleased to bestow whatever honor that's implied by my 2500th review upon Kusakabe. Although it lost its Michelin star for 2017, my experience here was first-rate, and I'm hoping it regains its star when the 2018 ratings for the Bay Area are announced this coming week.

Occupying a prime location directly underneath the Transamerica pyramid, Kusakabe is a sleek, modern venue dominated by a large sushi bar that seats about a dozen people. There are also small tables up front that seat another 10-12 people. Because of the limited amount of seating, reservations are virtually mandatory, although I lucked out by walking in as the first in line 20 minutes ahead of opening time.

Even though pricey omakase menus are a dime a dozen in the West Bay these days, I found the top-tier course to be an impressive value given the quality and quantity of the pieces of fish that came my way. In total, there were about 28 pieces to the omakase experience, including items like the amuse bouche, soup, and dessert.

To start, a modestly fatty series of nigiri that included zuke chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce), hirame (halibut), and katsuo (bonito) helped prime the appetite. Next, the relatively chewy sumi ika (Japanese cuttlefish squid) with uni (sea urchin) and sayori (Japanese half beak cured with ryuhi konbu) provided textural contrast. This was followed by a plate of hon maguro (center loin bluefin tuna), kasugodai (bamboo leaf cured young red snapper), and tairagai (ear shell clam) that offered a variety of contrasting seafood flavors. Next came a multi-course presentation of baby sea eel, wagyu rice cracker croquette, crab cake, Washington oyster with caviar, octopus with octopus roe, tuna cake, and egg cake, all of which offered unique tastes and textures.

This was followed by a palate-cleansing bowl of soup, which opened the way for a course of shima aji (stripe jack), a super-delicious piece of copper river king salmon, and ebodai (Japanese butter fish), followed further by bafun uni (Hokkaido short spine sea urchin) and a deliciously seared piece of shirayaki (fresh BBQ white eel with sansho pepper). Next came the ultimate in savory fattiness: a piece of toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and an exquisitely heavenly piece of wagyu beef. Then, a course of umimasu (lightly poached Tasmanian ocean trout), ji kinmedai (golden eye snapper) and gyoku (fresh lobster omelet with organic egg), followed by dessert, rounded out what was a truly indulgent omakase experience.

Bite after bite, everything was simply amazing. Service was also helpful and professional, and all in all it was fantastic value given the price, quantity, and quality of what I got. Highly recommended!

excerpts: Highlights of the meal included cod milt with uni.
Milt is nearly impossible to find here in the US (I couldn't even find it in Japan).
The chef gently explained that milt is "a type of egg.
Since I knew what it was, I asked him if it was a "male egg" which he nodded.
I've not had milt before, but I must say that it perfectly complemented the uni and it was incredible.
Other favorites were the amazing toro, Hokkaido uni, and A5 Wagu beef.
uni.author: Allen T.
uni.review:
The Grand Omakase dinner was the best sushi meal I've ever had, even better than the Michelin starred sushi I had in Tokyo (seriously)! We had the pleasure of sitting at the bar, served by Chef Kusakabe himself. It was a pleasure watching him skillfully and meticulously prepare his kaiseki-style sushi. The chef was a very gracious host, patiently explaining in detail each beautiful piece of nigiri. 

Highlights of the meal included cod milt with uni. Milt is nearly impossible to find here in the US (I couldn't even find it in Japan). The chef gently explained that milt is "a type of egg." Since I knew what it was, I asked him if it was a "male egg" which he nodded. I've not had milt before, but I must say that it perfectly complemented the uni and it was incredible. Other favorites were the amazing toro, Hokkaido uni, and A5 Wagu beef. 

The service was friendly and efficient - our sommelier helped us choose some pleasant and crisp sake to accompany our meal, along with a nice pinot noir as the dishes got progressively heavier. 

Overall - the meal was very expensive, but also of incredibly high quality and was well worth it. HIghly recommended!

excerpts: Their uni was on another level.
I will definitely come back.
uni.author: J R.
uni.review:
I came here for a 10-course Valentine's Day dinner. I've been to Wako and Juni, and Kusakabe is my favorite.

I loved their serene, intimate setting, and well-balanced authentic Kaiseki cuisine. Their uni was on another level. I will definitely come back.

excerpts: The fish was very fresh, especially the uni.
I've had bad experiences with uni
so I was very hesitant to try, but the uni here changed my viewpoint.
Although it says 11 courses, within each course were more plates.
In the end, we had at least 17 plates of food.
We were beyond full and could barely finish our dessert.
However if you're still hungry, they do offer a la carte items!
Since we came here to celebrate my birthday, they gave a free dessert
so I chose the tofu tiramisu!
This was fantastic because it was light and not too sweet.
uni.author: Jennie Q.
uni.review:
First time doing an omakase and I must say it was beyond my expectation! 

Each guest must order the omakase, whether it's the 8 or 11 course. My friend and I decided to go all out and did the 11 course. On top of that we each ordered sake. We're not to familiar with sake, so we asked our waitress. All she asked was what type of alcohol do we usually drink and she knew exactly what we'd like! I don't quite remember the name of the sake we had, but the one that I chose had a fruity after taste. It matched my taste bud and went well with the meal!

We had the pleasure of meeting Chef Kusakabe and we were lucky enough to have a seat in the center of the bar, so we got to see each chef prepare each dish.  It takes teamwork to shape the perfect experience for the customers and the staff here were definitely well trained. They're also really friendly; my friend and I had a nice chat with the chefs and got to learn about how they ended up at Kuskabe. Each plate was phenomenal and perfectly executed in a timely manner. The fish was very fresh, especially the uni. I've had bad experiences with uni so I was very hesitant to try, but the uni here changed my viewpoint. Although it says 11 courses, within each course were more plates. In the end, we had at least 17 plates of food. We were beyond full and could barely finish our dessert. However if you're still hungry, they do offer a la carte items! Since we came here to celebrate my birthday, they gave a free dessert so I chose the tofu tiramisu! This was fantastic because it was light and not too sweet. It was the perfect way to top off a wonderful meal.

OVERALL: Was very satisfied with my experience here and would highly recommend their omakase here to anyone! Just expect to spend at least $130!

excerpts: Highlights of the meal was definitely the scallop with Santa Barbara Uni, the deep sea Uni and the O-Toro.
I feel like that is standard on what's good in all Omakase spots.
uni.author: Ada H.
uni.review:
Was able to snag reservations for a Wednesday night the morning of. I was pretty surprised since I heard it takes months to get reservations here. The reservations were for 8:15 but that was fine with me. 

My boyfriend and I were lucky enough to snag a parking spot right away and we arrived 15 minutes early. We were promptly seated. I love how kusakabe isn't too compact and cramped. 

The sushi chef asked us if we had any allergies and also asked for our preferences. I told him we liked fish on the buttery side. It's nice to know that the chefs can alter dishes.

We opted for the $98 Omakase. It was very filling but I felt like the selection in fishes lacked. Maybe we came during a season where the fish did not fit our taste buds. I was not fond of the halibut, mackerel nor the fresh water fish we had. Highlights of the meal was definitely the scallop with Santa Barbara Uni, the deep sea Uni and the O-Toro. I feel like that is standard on what's good in all Omakase spots. I was sad to learn that they ran out of akumutsu that night (my favorite white fish).

Service was friendly and we had some small talk with the chef. Overall this place is a 3.5 for me but since there is no in between I will have to give it a three.

excerpts: Chef Kusakabe asked us what we like and we mentioned that we liked Toro and Uni
and he kept that in mind.
Oh my god.
I don't know where to start, but EVERYTHING WAS SO GOOD.
He remembered what we said about the Tori and Uni because we finished our night with those two.
I just wanted to cry eating those two.
T_T Seriously, I can only say everything is good, but if you are reading this, you have to try everything for yourself to know!
uni.author: Gabriel N.
uni.review:
My stomach and my heart are both crying tears of joy, but my wallet...not so much. Still, this place was worth every.single.penny.

Amy T. and I made a reservation for 8:30pm on a Friday. We arrived at ~8:10 and was seated promptly. We were served by none other than the head chef and owner himself, Chef Kusakabe. 

We decided to go with the Grand Omakase because go big and then go home right? The Grand Omakase ($165) comes with 10 courses which ends up being quite a bit. Chef Kusakabe asked us what we like and we mentioned that we liked Toro and Uni and he kept that in mind. Oh my god. I don't know where to start, but EVERYTHING WAS SO GOOD. The starting Zuke Chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce) was absolutely divine. We were like damn if this is the starter nigiri, what the hell can be better than this? The answer was nothing because everything was delicious. We devoured everything so fast that I was sad when he told us we're at the last few dishes. He remembered what we said about the Tori and Uni because we finished our night with those two. I just wanted to cry eating those two. T_T Seriously, I can only say everything is good, but if you are reading this, you have to try everything for yourself to know! We were a good level full by the end of the meal, and they also give you a menu to order a la carte if you want more.

We also got two orders of Sake to go with our food as well. I totally don't remember what it was but they were both good! They offer a wide selection of sake ranging from cheap stuff to things I would never buy unless I was driving a Lambo or something.

Everyone here is a master at what they do. The knife skills, the plating skills, etc. It's really a wonder to watch them do their work so naturally. 

Kusakabe deserves its Michelin star and so much more. This is an insane omakase experience. They serve only the best sushi, sashimi and kaiseki. You will not be disappointed!!

excerpts: The scallop was so fresh along with the uni.
This was good, but i think i liked the uni more.
I will really want to come back again, but next time i'll try the 10 course menu and try all their uni selections!
So in comparison to wako and wakuriya, I liked this place more than wakuriya,  but about the same as wako.
uni.author: Belinda C.
uni.review:
My friend took me here for my belated bday dinner.  I've been waiting all week to try this place.  I wasn't sure if i could do the 10 course or the 7 course.  But i knew i wanted to order a few items a la carte, so i went with the 7 course menu.  When they seated us, they sat us at the bar! I love sitting at the bar because that's where you get to watch all the action.  My chef's name was Patrick and he was a great host and chef the whole evening.  The way this place works, is that you are supposed to use your hands to eat the sushi.  There will be some dishes that will require chopsticks.

To start off the night, we got the sake flight.  It's 3 different types of sake- Junmai, Ginjo, and Daiginjo.  The Junami sake we got was the Heart and soul- this was my 2nd favorite of the three.  The Ginjo sake was the Flying dragon- this was my least favorite.   The Daiginjo sake was the Sophisticated Mind- this was my favorite and by far the strongest among the three.  

And now the begin the 7 course menu

The ichiban Dashi was like soup.  This soup had a very refreshing taste to it. 

Sushi Prelude- Zuke Chutoro and halibut was fresh and sweet.  The smoked tuna was ok, but i'm biased, i never liked anything smoked

Sashimi-Also fresh and felt like it melted in your mouth

Hassan- 6 kinds of chef's assorted les petit.  This dish included a clam in a creamy corn sauce, which i loved.   The soft shell crab was really good.  The beef tartar was on a rice cracker which made it the perfect combo.  Jellyfish and the asparagus with shrimp was my least favorite because i normally don't like jellyfish and asparagus.  The oyster was sweet and super fresh.  There was no particular way to eat this, so i did it from least to favorite.  Save the best for last right?

Soup- This fish soup was sweet and you can tell the spent time making this to get it to have this flavor, because i know that fish soup isn't easy to make.  A bonus to this soup is that it came with noodles. 

Seasonal Sushi- Yellowtail- really good,  Mackerel with egg yolk - this one was my favorite.  I love egg, so i loved how this was topped with egg yolk.  The first fish was a fish from a salmon family- this was ok, but it was really hard to top the Mackerel one! 

Finale- Scallop with Santa barbara Uni-  This one was tasty.  The scallop was so fresh along with the uni.  

A la Carte-  Bafun Uni- This was like a party in your mouth.  Yes, it did give you the melt in your mouth taste and i wished i had more. I wanted more, but i was starting to get full

Wagyu-  This was good, but i think i liked the uni more. 

For dessert I got the Cream Brulee- by far the best creme brulee i've ever had. It was perfect and not too sweet. 

Yuzu sorbet-  this was very refreshing and perfect if you're a yuzu lover.  

The service was great and attentive.  They comp. my bday dessert which i didn't expect.  I will really want to come back again, but next time i'll try the 10 course menu and try all their uni selections! So in comparison to wako and wakuriya, I liked this place more than wakuriya,  but about the same as wako.

excerpts: And while you are at it, at the end go crazy and get things like toro with uni, gold flakes and caviar (if available).
uni.author: Mario B.
uni.review:
Kusakabe is the place to go for a special occasion! It's some of the best sushi not just in SF but period. I've tried numerous Michelin Star Sushi places in the city and the best Sushi spots in So Cal and this is by far my favorite.  Yes, it's better than even the sushi at the Tokyo fish market (albeit more expensive; but so is a flight to Japan).

Kusakabe blends traditional and modern perfectly. It provides multiple complex flavors with each bite. It's made to please everyone and it's quite different than Omakase's edomae style, for example. It's very San Francisco's and it incorporates things like avocado. That being said it still keeps the tradition of sushi and respectfully modernizes it and elevates the flavor profiles. Nothing quite like it.

Make sure to ask to be seated at the bar so you can converse with your chef and make it a personal experience (bonus points: ask for the main Chef, Mitsunori). Ask them about why they are there and how hard they had to work to get where they are. Trust me, it will change your perspective on sushi and you'll find a new appreciation for the art (oh and if you don't know proper etiquette, they'll teach you that, too). Already experienced at fine dining and sushi? You can have more complex conversations about the specific sushi, techniques, ask for the Wagyu Beef's certificate, etc. 

I've done table seating, too, and it's a completely different experience. That being said, if you want to minimize the interactions with chefs, the staff, and want to just eat your food in peace and privacy, you can go the table route.

The food is amazing, the pairings fit well, and the staff is perfect. 

So what should you get? I'd say if you are going, might as well get the grand omakase! And while you are at it, at the end go crazy and get things like toro with uni, gold flakes and caviar (if available). Their wagyu is also A5 Grade 12! Make sure to enjoy every bite. If you are more of an expert with a developed and specific taste, you can go with the regular omakase and get exactly what you want a la carte after to maximize the customization of your meal and have more of exactly what you want.

excerpts: The only thing he liked was the uni.
uni.author: Lisa M.
uni.review:
3.5 stars
I made a reservation for my boyfriend's birthday online three weeks ago. Online reservation is very convenient, unlike some other restaurants calling them is the only way to make reservation. We were very excited for this meal because it was both of our first time having omakase. Seeing all the great reviews and mouthwatering photos of the sushi gave us really high expectation for this place. We were 30 minutes early(we though there would be traffic but there was none) but was seated promptly. We were given three menus: omakase/petite omakase menu, sake/wine pairing menu, regular sake/wine menu. The server didn't tell us there was an a la carte menu but I heard the server at the next table told his customers and explained the difference between the two omakase menu. I wanted to do the petite omakase and ordered from a la carte menu afterwards, but my boyfriend wanted to try the full omakase. It was his birthday so I let him pick whatever. We didn't do the pairing because we tried wine pairing at another restaurant on my birthday and I was buzzed half way through and couldn't enjoy the rest of the meal. However we did ordered an 8oz sake to drink slowly throughout the course. The first half of the menu was AMAZING. The fish were very fresh and flavorful. The second half of the menu was not as amazing as the first half. Maybe because I was getting full since I ate a lot in the morning. I should have thought it through. For the last 4-5 courses I was shoveling food down my throat without really spent time tasting them in my mouth. I was so full I had to give a few pieces of my sushi to my boyfriend. I am sure the sushi courses would taste a lot better if I had the appetite. However I didn't really enjoy the petit plates and the wagyu tongue stew no matter if I was full or not. Reading the reviews I know most people love these two courses, but maybe I have a different palate. I liked the fish a lot more. Honestly I don't think we would have missed out if we had picked the petite omakase. Frankly speaking Im not being entirely fair to the restaurant since I got full half way. So I asked my boyfriend if he enjoyed it and he said not really. The only thing he liked was the uni. But I will definitely bookmark this restaurant and come back here again with a very empty stomach so I can update a fairer review next time!

I totally forgot to take pictures of the second half courses. I was so full and just wanted to get them over with.

excerpts: Highlights were the A5 Wagyu, the Uni, and this fish (I forgot) topped with Uni.
uni.author: Catherine T.
uni.review:
Trying to not be biased.
Trying to not be biased.
Trying to not be biased.

I had the best omakase meal (BEST MEAL OF MY LIFE) in Japan. Knowing that anywhere else would never compare I was excited to try Kusakabe with a grain of salt. 

We did the Grand Omakase ($165) and I had the Sake Flight ($50). It was a mixture of sushi and special Kaiseki dishes. Highlights were the A5 Wagyu, the Uni, and this fish (I forgot) topped with Uni. While the meals were of high quality and delicious, we were still hungry after our meal. 

Service was excellent. Chef Ngai made sure to note allergies and was fun to watch and interact with as he prepared our courses. Service given by other staff made sure our dinner was enjoyable. 

I don't mind paying for a great meal, but something about this experience did not WOW me. Maybe my omakase experience in Japan did alter my expectations, so maybe my review is unfair. But eat sushi in Japan and come back and tell me you don't feel the same.

excerpts: uni ever haha he must have heard the longing in my voice when I was talking about how much I love uni, because for our last course, he subbed out the fish and gave me uni!!!
They recommend you eat all the nigiri with your hands so that was super fun.
We didn't take too many pictures because we couldn't help ourselves from devouring everything right when it was placed on our plate....
uni.author: Jennifer T.
uni.review:
My BF took me here for my birthday and I have heard mixed things, so I was not sure what to expect, but Kusakabe was a treat - a damn good treat. We enjoyed the entire experience and so did everyone around us. We had a couple next to us visiting from NY, which has TONS of food, but they still thought Kusakabe was good.

They do a 7 course omakase for $98 or a 12 for $165. Near the end of your omakase, they give you an a la carte menu, so you can always order more! We did the 7 course and both got a  wagyu nigiri from a la carte and that was such a good amount. GET THE WAGYU NIGIRI!!! This was mind-blowingly good. We still talk about it and we regret not getting another 1....or 2...or 7 lol the sake creme brulee was so good as well.

I really liked our sushi chef, who took time to answer any questions and who gave me the best dang uni ever haha he must have heard the longing in my voice when I was talking about how much I love uni, because for our last course, he subbed out the fish and gave me uni!!! They recommend you eat all the nigiri with your hands so that was super fun. We didn't take too many pictures because we couldn't help ourselves from devouring everything right when it was placed on our plate....hey.....don't let the freshness go to waste!!!

Yes, Kusakabe is $$$, so it's not a place I can eat every month, but it is a nice place to go and celebrate something. TREAT YO' SELF!!!!

Disclaimer: Kusakabe does change their menu and I have heard of folks getting some MEH menus!

excerpts: My favorite sushi would definitely be the Oshinogi with Scallop+Uni sushi, Nata with poached egg on spoon, the uni sushi and surprisingly the Shima Aji (stripe jack) which is the chef's choice of sushi.
uni.author: Gloria C.
uni.review:
Since Kusabake is an omakase restaurant, I was hoping we can sit in front of the sushi bar to see how they prepare the sushi and serve it right in front of us. However, it was disappointing to find out party of two or more were not able to sit by the sushi bar and we had 4 people. I feel like that is part of the experience if I was to dish out $200 bucks for a meal. 

We were seated promptly by our reservation time at 8:15 and we chose the Grand Omakase because of the delicacy menu options (Truffle, A5 Wagyu beef, Hokkaido Sea Urchin, Eel from Tsukiji Market and Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly). An important thing to point out is we were NEVER served the Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly like the menu stated. Instead we were served Negitoro, which is minced fatty tuna with micro onion on a roasted seaweed. Those are two very different things, I wanted to ask why we were served the negitoro instead of the fatty tuna belly, but since my friends didn't mention I didn't want to be particular. Now that I think about it, I am quite angry that the manager didn't mention anything at all about switching our menu. 

Anyways, a review on the food that we DID have. It was a 10 course menu (with 2 soups) and it was more than enough. A tip for everyone, if you want to do a la carte towards the end, I suggest you choose the regular Omakase with less courses. Actually with the Grand Omakase, there is a course with non-sashimi/sushi dish. So if you here for the sushi/sashimi definitely choose the regular Omakase then do a la carte at the end. 

One thing to note about the sushi here is that they seasoned all their rice. At first it looked like brown rice, then we realized every piece of rice has soy sauce seasoned so the flavor is even throughout. My favorite sushi would definitely be the Oshinogi with Scallop+Uni sushi, Nata with poached egg on spoon, the uni sushi and surprisingly the Shima Aji (stripe jack) which is the chef's choice of sushi. The Hassun which included 6 small plates was also very tasty, I love how the food is like art. The wagyu beef tartare was one of the most delicious tartare that I ever had. The most disappointing course would definitely be the seared A5 Wagyu sushi, they over-seasoned it with too much pepper and salt overpowering the taste of the wagyu. It felt like they wasted a perfectly fine piece of meat, except the meat itself had a bit too much lines in it. 

Overall, I highly recommend Kusakabe for Omakase on a special occasion or if you are visiting from out of town. It seems like a popular date place, you can impress somebody by bringing them here and eating in front of the sushi bar. It's a shame we didn't get to sit there to watch as the sushi chef prepare our dishes. There might have been 1 or 2 disappointment, nevertheless it was a good experience. And I figured out why they lost their star; it was not perfect like it should be.

excerpts: Plus: all their uni was from Hokkaido (I personally did not like Uni from the west coast - it was big in size yet less flavorful), so made it a great combo with either the scallop or the vinegar rice itself.
uni.author: Elaine H.
uni.review:
Grand Omakase is certainly the legit way to open up this great Japanese gem, as one gets to experience the carefully made sushi pieces, but also have an opportunity to try some of the kitchen made dishes. Michelin one star for the past two years, yet was taken away the star this year, unfortunately.

Plus: all their uni was from Hokkaido (I personally did not like Uni from the west coast - it was big in size yet less flavorful), so made it a great combo with either the scallop or the vinegar rice itself. Also, the wagyu beef was seared just to the right level of tenderness, and carried a little smooth texture on top, very unique taste!

Minus: the cooked sweet fish was a bit bitter that I did not find myself quite fond of. 

This is my first Kaiseki in the west coast and pros certainly overweighted cons. Kusakabe definitely worth a star in my opinion, compared with some of the east coast sushi places. 

Last piece of advice - don't miss the dessert part, as it was not included in the Kaiseki fixed menu.

excerpts: - Ika and uni with rice and sandwiches in between some seaweed.
uni.author: Joanna C.
uni.review:
This was my third omakase in SF, the one with the middle price range ($95, 7 courses) but I must say it was hands down the best, and I was thoroughly impressed. 

We began with a fish broth - clear but flavourful. Not super light, but not heavy either. 
Next was the sushi starter, brimming with rich, citrusy, and smokey flavours.

--- Chef's assorted "les petit plats" ----
The following act was an assortment of 5 dishes. I loved how each element brought something a little different to the table. 

- Mackerel: I felt like it may have been a touch dry (not sure if that was the intention or not, but I think if I had to say anything about the whole experience, this was the only thing that wasn't super amazing, though it was still tasty). 
- Oyster with caviar is definitely the best oyster I've ever had. Of course, no unwanted particles (no sand whoot), and the oyster was not super briney, but rather smooth and citrusy. 
- Croquette was interesting. Sweet miso on top.
- Baby eel bowl: the flavours was very clean, crisp, and clear. The eel itself was like noodles, and it was kind of cute being able to see the little eyes as I munched away haha. 
- Barracuda sushi was the first (and last) roll sushi of the day. It was good, no complaints here. 

--- Soup and Sushi ---
- Red miso was rich but not heavy, and the duck meatball with foie gras in the centre was interesting. 
- Ika and uni with rice and sandwiches in between some seaweed. 
- Fatty toro was the finale. 

--- Condiments ---
- House made soy sauce: made with shiitake mushrooms!
- Japanese seaweed salt
- Citrus juice: lemon, line, and yuzu.

Everything presented at Kusakabe was such an experience: beautifully presented and exploding with flavours - worth every penny. I would definitely come back again!

excerpts: The toro was probably one of my favorites and of course the uni, which our chef put into at least three of the courses since we told him that was our favorite, and the eel was so good!
They get the eel fresh from the Tsukiji market in Japan which is really awesome.
The whole dining experience probably took close to two hours.
It's expensive but probably worth it.
uni.author: Jeana Y.
uni.review: This was such a great omakase experience and we were lucky to be served by chef Kusakabe himself! It's kaiseki style so some of the courses are actual plates and prepared in the kitchen. Everything was amazing and so fresh. Sitting at the bar is the best way to go if possible, because you can see everything the chef does to create your next course and realize just how many different things go into that one beautiful delicious piece of sushi. The toro was probably one of my favorites and of course the uni, which our chef put into at least three of the courses since we told him that was our favorite, and the eel was so good! They get the eel fresh from the Tsukiji market in Japan which is really awesome. The whole dining experience probably took close to two hours. It's expensive but probably worth it.

excerpts:
Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). 
The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.
uni.author: David K.
uni.review:
Kusakabe is an experience. You go for the chef-led omakase and are presented with course after course of beautifully-formed, high-quality dishes that take your palate on a little tour of Japanese flavors and techniques. The dining room is small and reservations are required, but I got to come with a group of seven friends, and it was a great experience trying and discussing all the different courses together. This is not your typical, run-of-the-mill sushi, so be prepared to splurge (the base menu comes at a hefty $98/head), and come with an appreciation for the quality and cost of purveyance of the ingredients. 

Course #1: a subtly-flavored dashi broth. Nothing unusual (after all, there are only three ingredients in this fish-based broth), but very clean tasting and a nice way to start the meal.

Course #2: The zuku chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna) was seared on one side, giving the fish a great texture to complement its flavors. The hirame halibut with its own liver had a slightly spicy kick, and the cold-smoked bonito (katsuo) resounded with the flavors of the wood smoke.

Course #3: Bluefin sashimi and poached amberjack (a surprising favorite of mine). These pieces were served simply with soy and yuzu onion sauces, and came with little slices of fuji apple and radish. You had some of every flavor here--sweet from the apple, bitter from the radish, salty/umami from the soy, and tart from the yuzu. 

Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle. But my favorite dish was definitely the soft-shell crab, which was so creamy on the inside and delicately crunchy on the inside!

Course 5: Red miso soup with a duck and lotus root meatball, layered with soy cream foam. Delicious, umami soup with layers of flavor that change as you sip, and the lotus root adds an unexpected, pleasant chewiness to the meatball.

Course 6: My favorite sushi of the meal was the shima aji, the stripe jack with daikon radish, which was so buttery in texture and had a scallop-like flavor. The cherry salmon and the kasugodai (red snapper with crystallized egg yolk) both melted in your mouth as well. Unbelievable!

Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

Course by course, everyone is served at the same time, and the staff explain each and every component--the work that goes behind each of these dishes/components is indeed immense! After the omakase meal, we were given an a la carte menu, from which we could order even more sushi or sashimi. I got the aori ika (big fin reef squid), which was extremely creamy in texture, though not particularly vibrant in flavor. 

And then we went for dessert! We ordered one of each item to share, and each of the desserts was so unique. The yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet was nice and refreshing (slightly acidic and herbal flavors), the (unsweetened kome koji) ice cream had sweetness imparted to it from the same fermented flavors that you find in sake, and the Daiginjo sake kasu crème brulee had the same fermented flavors as the ice cream, but was much sweeter and decadent.

Overall, a great meal and definitely something to experience! The restaurant itself is small but homey and authentic (the bathroom even features an automated Japanese toilet). The service is the epitome of Japanese hospitality and the prices are exorbitant, so make sure to come with an appreciation of the work, care, and quality that goes behind each bite of food.

excerpts: uni on top.
OMG, it is really amazing.
The portion of the rice is not a lot which is really what I like and should be what an authentic nigiri be like.
uni.author: Tina H.
uni.review:
reservation time: 5:30pm on Saturday. We sat at the sushi bar. 

Food: we ordered the $98 Omakase. It is really awesome. I think there are 7 pieces of nigiri and 1 nori roll. The condiment of each nigiri is so well-matched. My favorite one is the Scallop with Santa Barbara uni on top. OMG, it is really amazing. The portion of the rice is not a lot which is really what I like and should be what an authentic nigiri be like.  
For other places i've been to like Hinata, they put too much rice for nigiri. 

The environment is comfortable but the table is kind of too high. 

Reason why I gave 3 star even though the food is really good is below. 
I got there at around 535 and my friend hasn't got there yet. I explained to the staff saying that my friend will be late for maybe at least 30 mins because of the traffic. And she looked unhappy. I told her that I could just sit down and order for my friend. I said the chef could just make two portion of the sushi and put my friend's portion in a plate or something. After my friend comes, he could just enjoy it. 

She was like, there's "no place" to put the nigiri. we don't do to-go box. And then she kept suggesting me that my friend has to be here before 6 otherwise, they can't serve us. I was like.. THIS IS CRAZY. I already got here and do i have to just waste money and eat nothing? She explained to me that the second-seating guests will come at 8pm so there is no enough time for the chef to serve us if my friend comes after 6. I told her that we eat very fast. But then she pushed back again saying that even if you guys eat fast and chef can't make the food fast. It still has to depend on the chef. She even said that if my friend comes after 6, then the chef won't have enough time to serve all the food ( even if we paid the same price as others....

At the end, my friend came at around 5:50PM. And then she took us to our seats. We finished at around "7PM". ( i was like.. how come there won't be enough time if my friend come after 6..) Also, there's a small plate in front of everyone. But she said that there's no PLACE to put nigiri if I sit in and order for my friend first.

I totally understand that she wanted us to enjoy an authentic and comfortable eating environment for omakase. But i feel the way she communicated to me is like.. "YOU can't eat until your friend comes and you are going to just throw your money to trash can WITHOUT eating anything if your friend doesn't come before 6 even if I AM already here" 

Also,The bathroom is broken and the staff told me that she will have people take me to another bathroom. 

Based on the experience with the front staff, suggest people have to be arriving at exactly the time you reserve and no one in your group could be late. 
For me, I will not come again even the food is REALLY awesome.

excerpts: The ONLY reason why it may not be number 1 was because the bafun uni had a slight ammonia flavor which I couldn't get past.
I have an EXTREMELY sensitive sense of smell so
uni.author: Sarah A.
uni.review:
One of the best sushi experiences I've had in the US. We opted for the regular Omakase course and almost every single piece of sushi we had was as amazing as the next. The flavor and texture of each nigiri was exactly the way I like it, and I really enjoyed the rice which was more tart than some sushi places. The ginger also tasted less sweet and more sour which I enjoyed as well.

The stand outs for me were the Shima Aji (stripe jack) and the Katsuo (bonito) which was lightly smoked with cherry wood. The subtle smoky flavor was aromatic and complemented the perfectly fatty fish topped with the momiji oroshi (grated daikon radish with chili peppers) which added a hint of spice. My mouth is watering just thinking about it! 

We were lucky enough to score a reservation at 5:30pm but arrived a bit early and were seated at the sushi bar. I don't think I would want to dine here unless I was guaranteed the sushi bar. It really makes a HUGE difference in both the service and the taste and flavor of the sushi and when you're paying the same amount, why not opt for the option that's twice as better? 

The excellent service, GREAT sushi, and the glass of rosé I had puts Kusakabe in the top 3 best sushi experiences I've had in the US! The ONLY reason why it may not be number 1 was because the bafun uni had a slight ammonia flavor which I couldn't get past. I have an EXTREMELY sensitive sense of smell so to others it may taste perfectly fine! 

Overall I highly recommend this restaurant for any special
occasion or if you're in town looking for great sushi. It is on the pricy side but much more affordable compared to high-end sushi places in Manhattan or LA.

excerpts: AND the UNI!
I can tell you that their uni here is to die for!!
Specifically their deep sea hokkaido uni - it literally melts in your mouth and taste like heaven for a few seconds.
uni.author: Sherry L.
uni.review:
Kusakabe definitely delivers a fine dining experience. Just the quality of the food and service should automatically give this place more than 5 stars. Reservations must be made in advance and I believe there are 2 seatings - one at 5 and another at 8. I made my reservation months in advance.  This place is very small and a little hidden but has a cute entrance through a curtain. The inside had a very nice ambiance going on and was very intimate. There was bar seating and a few table seating on the side but I suggest you choose the bar seating (or hopefully you get lucky enough to get bar seating) because you get the watch the sushi chefs make your omakase and have them explain each and every piece to you.

Their omakase menu changes from time to time but their dinner is priced at either $95pp or $150 pp for their grand omakase. I say you should get the grand omakase because it's so much more worth it if you're already going to spend $$$$ - might as well go all out! I also recommend that you try both the a5 wagyu and the toro... AND the UNI!! I can tell you that their uni here is to die for!! Specifically their deep sea hokkaido uni - it literally melts in your mouth and taste like heaven for a few seconds. (It is also their most expensive item on their ala carte menu) everything on their menu was just mouthwatering.

The service here is incomparable to other places - they treat you like a king and queen from seating you and even putting your coats on. They are also quick to refill your drinks/clean your tables and all other manners they are quick to address. Please do make some time if you come to the later seating. We sat down at 8pm and probably did not leave the restaurant till 11pm. Also if it's your birthday - tell them in advance!  They will comp you a item from their dessert menu. :)

excerpts: Then... A really soft textured jellyfish unlike any I've had before topped with uni.
It was delicious.
A few seared items came next, the golden eye...
We even had our nigiri topped with crystallized egg yolk.
The bafun uni was one of my favorite uni...
We ended the omakase a bit differently, as one of our options.
uni.author: Lyra C.
uni.review:
Wow the food here is amazing!! Everything is well thought out and I literally disliked NOTHING. All of the dishes were unique and crafted so nicely.

I celebrated Valentine's day here with my boyfriend and we went all out and ordered the grand omakase. The omakase started out with a bang. First, we got the chu toro... It was the best I've had. Then... A really soft textured jellyfish unlike any I've had before topped with uni. It was delicious. A few seared items came next, the golden eye... We even had our nigiri topped with crystallized egg yolk. One of our boxed presentations had eels that tasted like noodles and toro in croquette form! The bafun uni was one of my favorite uni... We ended the omakase a bit differently, as one of our options. I ordered toro to end my meal... My boyfriend ordered the a5 Miyazaki wagyu beef. Although his last choice was good I preferred the lighter taste of fish. 

The chef's were a lot of fun to talk to as well. I had a great time here. Would definitely recommend :)

excerpts: Super excited that there was some uni involved as well.
Chef's assorted Les petit plats was just so pretty to look at and even better to eat.
uni.author: Monica V.
uni.review:
What can I say about Kusakabe that hasn't already been said before? Nonetheless, I want to share my thoughts on my experience on one of the best meals I've had.

With a part of three, we made reservations a couple months in advanced to sit at the bar for the full omakase experience. Doors don't open until exactly 5:00PM. Through the curtains is a narrow hall and doorway. Upon entering, the host will ask for your reservation and you will be seated in your designated spots. The space is narrow, with not very many seats, hence the limited reservations each night and it usually doesn't get too loud. 

You'll get a chance to look over their two menus: the first for omakase ($95 or $150) and the other for drinks. We opted for the $95 and some sake, of course. They started us off with some dashi broth, which was really nice on a cold, rainy evening. Then came the sushi. While there are chopsticks provided, we used our fingers for the most part. There's a bit of cloth for you to wipe your fingers on between pieces and some food items are much easier to handle with chopsticks, so there's no pressure. Each piece of sushi was so special and the taste so unique. The Zuke Toro was the most unforgettable one, so much that later on, we ordered another round a la carte. Super excited that there was some uni involved as well. Chef's assorted Les petit plats was just so pretty to look at and even better to eat.  We finished off with some tea and creme brulee. 

Our Chef Matt was very willing to answer our questions about sushi, the restaurant, his experience as a chef, etc. and interacted with us. Definitely added to our experience and understanding of what we were eating, so I would recommend sitting at the bar. 

If this is what heaven tastes like, just kill me now. Definitely worth every damn dollar and definitely will make a point to come often.

excerpts: The stars for me was the Kegani which was Hokkaido crab with quail egg (this is usually served with shrimp but since I don't like shrimp, they substituted with crab), Hotate (Hokkaido scallop topped with uni) and Zuke Chutoro (bluefin tuna).
uni.author: Joan S.
uni.review:
4.5 stars. My friend and I came here last night for the 8:00 p.m. seating and got the Grand Omakase menu for $165. The sushi was probably some of the best sushi I have ever had in my life. The fish was really the star and all the additions added did not overwhelm what you are ultimately here for, which is the fish. Kusakabe did a brilliant job of elevating high-quality fish through the use of umami soy sauce, shiso leaves, yuzu etc. These ingredients brought out the flavor of the fish and gave it something extra.

The stars for me was the Kegani which was Hokkaido crab with quail egg (this is usually served with shrimp but since I don't like shrimp, they substituted with crab), Hotate (Hokkaido scallop topped with uni) and Zuke Chutoro (bluefin tuna).

Dishes that I was not too crazy about were les petit plats and the wagyu rib cap (tasted too fatty and oily...yes, I like marbled meats but this was too much). The Miyazaki wagyu they served later nigiri-style was much better in my opinion. 

We definitely felt full afterwards and felt that we had a very enjoyable and special experience. We have both lived in Japan and been to various kaiseki/omakase places and we agreed that this was pretty top-notch.

excerpts: The second to last piece was scallop uni, followed by otoro.
My favorite sushi is always uni but that scallop was so sweet I didn't even taste the uni.
Wow.
On their menu they had 3 types of Hokkaido uni, so we asked our chef which one was on the scallop, and that we each ordered the 2 other to try.
One of them, bafun uni, BLEW.
MY.
MIND.
We ordered another round lol All in all, great experience, good service.
If you know what you like, go with the omakase and get extra pieces at the end.
If not, the grand omakase works too.
Side note,
all the chefs and everyone behind the sushi bar is relatively young, ranging from 25-35?
Not to say they are not skilled, but I'd prefer an older chef for a more expensive menu.
Side side note
