, our chef was very very cute, which added to our experience =)
uni.author: Crystal Y.
uni.review:
I did the $98 omakase menu and I found it worth it. However with what I saw around me, I wouldn't have thought the $165 is worth it.
We started with the soup, and had a piece of chutoro, medium fatty tuna. The sashimi and the non sushi courses weren't too memorable. We definitely ended with a bang. The second to last piece was scallop uni, followed by otoro. My favorite sushi is always uni but that scallop was so sweet I didn't even taste the uni. Wow. On their menu they had 3 types of Hokkaido uni, so we asked our chef which one was on the scallop, and that we each ordered the 2 other to try. One of them, bafun uni, BLEW. MY. MIND. We ordered another round lol All in all, great experience, good service. If you know what you like, go with the omakase and get extra pieces at the end. If not, the grand omakase works too. 
Side note, all the chefs and everyone behind the sushi bar is relatively young, ranging from 25-35? Not to say they are not skilled, but I'd prefer an older chef for a more expensive menu.
Side side note, our chef was very very cute, which added to our experience =)

excerpts:
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef.
uni.author: Danny L.
uni.review:
Instead of going to our Company holiday dinner this year, Lily T. & I decided to skip that and go here instead. It took us 1.5 months to find a decent reservation and the wait was so worth it. This restaurant is amazing- definitely worth the Michelin star. Reservations are super competitive though, so don't expect to last minute plan it but keep hopes!

We had the opportunity to seat right in front of Chef Kusakabe which was amazing because he explained every little detail about each fish and we saw all the finishing touch. Lily T. & I opted in for the $150 grand omakase which included 25 items. Each piece of nigiri was a die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and also added with some citrus and wasabi depending on the nigiri. I love for a fact the Chef also asks you if you're allergic to anything and if you had any favorite fish so they can do a little remix. 

Metered street parking was easily found before 6 pm. The nearest garage is 2 blocks away at the Embarcadero Garage ($3/hour after 5 pm).

Some of our highlights were:
Fatty Tuna
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef. (OMG, melt in your mouth....) 

Nice interior, excellent food, and above & beyond customer service. Not once did I need to flag down a waiter down for tea. Everyone had a smile on their face.  Major props! Kusakabe was my first Michelin star restaurant and I definitely felt the "VIP" treatment.

Thanks, Kusakabe! I'll be back.

excerpts: I had the A5 Wagyu at the end and my boyfriend had the Kaisui uni and both were very delicious.
uni.author: Janice L.
uni.review:
My boyfriend and I decided to come here to celebrate his early birthday and our anniversary because we both love sushi. We never had an omakase experience before so we were very excited to try it out. Made reservations online and thankfully they had it on the day we wanted to go. 

Our reservations wasn't until 8:15 but when we got there at 8, they seated us right away at the bar. We ordered the regular omakase thinking that we can just add more at the end if we're still hungry. We ended up being super full and only ordered 1 extra each. I had the A5 Wagyu at the end and my boyfriend had the Kaisui uni and both were very delicious. At the end, they gave us a yuzu dessert to celebrate our anniversary and that was very thoughtful of them. 

Definitely a great experience and the fish were fresh and delish! I had a great time and enjoyed everything that was served. I personally never liked oysters, so I was scared to try the Japanese raw oyster, but it was so good and ended up being one of my favorites. Definitely recommended and will be coming back!

excerpts:
- Scallop with Uni was the best scallop I ever had.
- Bonito was the best I ever had.
uni.author: Electric E.
uni.review:
Hands down top 2 omakase spots I've ever had.
Did the sake pairing and I would definitely recommend if you are into Sake.  

All the dishes were fantastic:
- intro dish was amazing.  The halibut with liver was out of this world.
- Jellyfish was wow.
- Scallop with Uni was the best scallop I ever had.
- Bonito was the best I ever had.
- After the 11 course omakase, I ordered a few of the favorites to enjoy even more

- Didn't get to try their sweet shrimp, maybe next time.

Truly an experience.  I will try to get a bar seat next time.

excerpts: apparently didn't like uni, and the chef was mindful of that through the entire meal and substituted other fish for her.
uni.author: Tiffany T.
uni.review:
Before I start - definitely sit at the bar. It's such a delight to watch everything being prepared.

I went to Kusakabe with the boyfriend a few weeks ago for an anniversary dinner and it was just fantastic. It was the first time either of us had omakase and went with the Grand Omakase menu. Definitely come with an empty stomach because we were just STUFFED by the end of it.

We were seated at the sushi bar and our chef asked us for any favorites/dislikes/allergies. We personally didn't have any dislikes, but one person seated next to us apparently didn't like uni, and the chef was mindful of that through the entire meal and substituted other fish for her.

Every piece of fish is thoughtfully prepared and oh so tender. It's awesome to hear about each piece, what fish it is, and what preparation had gone into it.

The only thing that I was a little less impressed with was the A5 Wagyu beef with a poached egg; it came out on a hot, mini-cast iron skillet, and had a sauce poured over that was supposed to sizzle and help cook the meat. Unfortunately, we were the last of three couples who were being served at the same time and our skillets had cooled down where it barely sizzled and all the ingredients were a little more under cooked than I think it was intended to be. It was still pretty tasty and honestly a fairly minor thing.

If you're looking to step up your sushi game, I highly recommend it. It is 300% for sure worth the higher price tag and I'm already trying to think of the next special occasion to have an excuse to go back.

excerpts: If I had to chose my most favorite was the scallops topped with uni nigiri and A5 wagyu beef nigiri.
We also ordered a dessert at the end and got the creme brûlée, OMG it was so good.
All desserts are homemade and the creme brûlée was so unique, it had a hint of sake flavor.
The whole restaurant and the chef sang happy birthday to my mom, it was very thoughtful and sweet :)
They also told me at the end that the dessert was on the house!
uni.author: Natalie L.
uni.review:
One of the most amazing dining experience ever! I must say I was impressed. I booked a month in advance for my mom's birthday dinner, we sat at the bar and Chef Kusakabe was the one serving us (super awesome!). 

We ordered the Grand Omakese and I highly recommend getting that one since there is more to try (25 items). Chef Kusakabe asked us what kind of fishes or nigiri that we like and he will customize it with the meal. Each nigiri was mouth watering, fresh and tasted very authentic with it's own style. I honestly couldn't think of ONE thing I DIDN'T like at all. If I had to chose my most favorite was the scallops topped with uni nigiri and A5 wagyu beef nigiri. We also ordered a dessert at the end and got the creme brûlée, OMG it was so good. All desserts are homemade and the creme brûlée was so unique, it had a hint of sake flavor. The whole restaurant and the chef sang happy birthday to my mom, it was very thoughtful and sweet :) They also told me at the end that the dessert was on the house! :D

Thank you so much Kusakabe for making my mom's birthday so special and memorable! We definitely will be coming back again!

excerpts: We ended the meal with more fresh and melt-in-your-mouth sushi: a fun and delicious DIY hand roll served with scallop sushi topped with uni.
They brought out an add-ons menu if we wanted to order anything a la carte.
We were pretty satisfied, so we didn't add get anything else.
After that, they came out with what I think was a yuzu sorbet, with a candle, on the house!
I had forgot that they called ahead about a week before to ask if we were coming for any special reason.
I had mentioned to them on the phone that it was my boyfriend's birthday.
It was a nice surprise.
uni.author: Christine L.
uni.review:
Got here about 10-15 minutes before our reservation at 8:15pm on a Friday (made a month in advance). They were able to seat us promptly even though we were early.
We sat at the table right next to the door partition. It was a smallish place, so it was a bit tight for the servers to get past me. I felt bad since I didn't realize this until we left. They were all nice enough not to say anything! 

They had two choices: the regular omakase (8 courses) or the grand omakase (11 courses). We opted for the regular $98 omakase menu. After we ordered, they gave us the dashi broth, along with warm towels and other eating utensils. We had more than one server bring us our food, and each one explained what they had placed on the table. I got too excited when they brought the sushi out so I didn't get to take pictures of the first sushi course. It was a piece of cured bluefin chutoro sushi that had a wonderful smoky flavor, paired with a piece of fresh fish served as is (not cured, marinated, etc.). You have one piece that was heavily flavored with soy sauce contrasting with another that was light and fresh, no frills. It was a very thoughtful pairing that not only didn't overwhelm my palate, but brought out the flavor of each piece of sushi. This theme continued throughout the meal with the sushi plates. 

Eventually, after a few rounds of sushi and sashimi, they brought out the Hassun, which consisted of 6 tiny dishes, and was the most beautifully plated out of all the courses. I loved that you got a tiny bite of everything, rather than one entree. I won't go over everything, but wasn't blown away by the taste of the overall dish. I'm sure people who love clams would like the cold clam soup. I felt like it really brought out the flavor of the clams. I didn't particularly like it, but that's because I'm not a huge fan of clams. There was a lightly fried shrimp and taro, like shrimp and taro karage. Tasted like what you would expect. It also came with something that tasted like wagyu croquette, covered in crispy rice. It was quite small, so it was difficult to taste the wagyu. 

We ended the meal with more fresh and melt-in-your-mouth sushi: a fun and delicious DIY hand roll served with scallop sushi topped with uni. They brought out an add-ons menu if we wanted to order anything a la carte. We were pretty satisfied, so we didn't add get anything else. After that, they came out with what I think was a yuzu sorbet, with a candle, on the house! I had forgot that they called ahead about a week before to ask if we were coming for any special reason. I had mentioned to them on the phone that it was my boyfriend's birthday. It was a nice surprise. The sorbet itself had a nice citrusy flavor, and came in a really cute little tea cup. 

In general, I really liked the quality of the sushi and sashimi, along with the their flavors and the little additions and sauces served with them. This was the main reason fo coming here. There warm dishes and soups weren't bad, but they definitely weren't the stars of the show. The servers were also all really nice and professional.

excerpts: Favs from the omakase were the uni, kobe, and otoro.
Service and vibe is on point as well.
uni.author: Michelle N.
uni.review:
This place is truly an experience! Get the grand omakase, your wallet will hurt after but it will be worth every penny :)

Favs from the omakase were the uni, kobe, and otoro. Service and vibe is on point as well.

excerpts:
- Toro: my favorite of the night, it was melt-in-my-mouth deliciousness
- Kaisui Uni: deep ocean Hokkaido sea urchin was my 2nd favorite..
so creamy and sweet.
- Bafun Uni:
Hokkaido short spine uni was firmer in texture, not as sweet, more ocean-y taste.
uni.author: Vera N.
uni.review:
4.5 stars because I wasn't able to get bar seating, but rounded up. We were first on waitlist and got the call 2 days before that we had gotten seats, but no guarantees are bar seating. Since we actually came at our reservation time, we were seated at the table. Found out later that a party didn't show up, but those seats were given to a walk-in an hour later. I was pretty butthurt, but it's okay, meal was worth it and I would definitely go again just so I can sit front row.

We settled with the $95 omakase and intended to order some a la carte pieces afterwards. Everything was amazing, the service, the ambience, and especially the food. The atmosphere was warm and inviting, but also exclusive and refined at the same time. The lighting focused on the chefs and the food at our table. The service was amazing, explained each course with detail. Even brought out another beer free of charge because they had brought the wrong drink the first time. 

Highlights of my meal:
- Halibut with its own liver
- Scallop sashimi with the yuzu and garlic sauce: delicate and sweet, counterbalanced with the sauces
- Snap pea soup: different textures, the fried fish added crunch and the broth was so good.
- Wagyu beef: AMAZING, beautiful marbling
- Toro: my favorite of the night, it was melt-in-my-mouth deliciousness
- Kaisui Uni: deep ocean Hokkaido sea urchin was my 2nd favorite.. so creamy and sweet.
- Bafun Uni: Hokkaido short spine uni was firmer in texture, not as sweet, more ocean-y taste.

Overall, it was a delightful dining experience. Would have been amazing tenfold if we had bar seating, but all the more reason to come back.. Also, to get the Grand Omakase next time around. Definitely worth a pretty penny.

excerpts: One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni.
uni.author: Jessica Z.
uni.review:
My bf and I celebrated our anniversary at Kusakabe! I've had this bookmarked for quite some time, just never had a reason to go.

I was pleasantly surprised as I had no clue where we were going to celebrate! 

We ordered the grand omakase with two hot sakes. The grand omakase consisted of 25 pieces, displayed on 7 "dishes". The entire dining experience was amazing from the start to finish. We first started off with the Ichiban Dashi, a small soup. Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef. 

After the omakase, there's an a la carte menu. My bf and I ordered 2 additional pieces each. One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni. 

Although we were pretty satisfied, we wanted to end the meal with dessert! They over heard that we were celebrating our anniversary so they gave us all three desserts on the house. So sweet! Love it. 

Overall, I was pretty blown away and kudos to the services as well! Can't wait to be back :)

excerpts: After adding extra Wagyu A5 and Hokkaido Uni and drinks, this place will surely make a small dent in your wallet.
Thank goodness it was my Birthday!
Great place to go for a celebration!
uni.author: Melanie N.
uni.review:
Amazing Omakase Experience!  If you can get a reservation, make sure you sit at the bar so that you can watch the chef at work- they are so meticulous with their work.  Everything was so fresh!  And it was my first time having turtle in the turtle soup.  

Dined here for my Birthday for the $95 Omakase menu- everything was so fresh and beautifully presented! After adding extra Wagyu A5 and Hokkaido Uni and drinks, this place will surely make a small dent in your wallet.  Thank goodness it was my Birthday! =)  Great place to go for a celebration!

excerpts: Favorites were the hakaido uni and baby shrimp with quail egg.
Could be top 3 sushi meals of all time
(tho I admit I have never been to Japan).
uni.author: Josh N.
uni.review: Great fresh sushi directly from Japan.  Chef only prepares 3 nights a week so book in advance. Favorites were the hakaido uni and baby shrimp with quail egg. Could be top 3 sushi meals of all time (tho I admit I have never been to Japan).

excerpts: The Otoro and uni was most disappointing.
uni.author: Expert F.
uni.review: I didn't want to give this rating but I expected so much more. The first half of the Omakase was amazing. Second half very blah almost kinda junk. The Otoro and uni was most disappointing.

excerpts:
Favorites now:
-Hotate 
-zuke chutoro, can be overseasoned
-bafun uni
-sardine 
-Hirame 
-toro
uni.author: Cynthia C.
uni.review:
Really good quality sushi, some of the intermediary courses are doused in ponzu and sauces.

Still love the welcome tea.  

Bluefin tuna, fishy.  Bonito, wish they would replace.  

Favorites now:
-Hotate 
-zuke chutoro, can be overseasoned
-bafun uni
-sardine 
-Hirame 
-toro 

The cooked items are really just an afterthought and the sushi while good, not many are wow.  Splurge on the toro and most of the time the A5 is on target.

excerpts: I was disappointed that they didn't include Hokkaido uni to their omakase set.
We had to order it as an addition.
I loved the freshness that you can taste from the uni.
uni.author: Tiffany D.
uni.review:
Michelin star means that I have high expectations of this place to be exceptional. 

I thought it was the norm of gourmet sushi, sashimi, sake and nigiri, but the proportions was a bit lacking for the price tag - I am talking about their omakase set.  

Quality was there, but it didn't stand out as spectacular to other upscale sashimi, omakase offerings that I have tried.

Their A5 Wagyu was not of the most marbleous that I have ever had.  Top notch - don't get me wrong.  However, not the best.

Their omakase nigiris were of the standard.  Again, it lacks the feeling of amazing!  Not too much creativity either.  Let me rave about it the next day, kind of feeling that I usually have on dazzling food spots!  It took me awhile to express myself about this place as you have read thus far that I left quite unimpressed. 

Sake was nicely fragrant and complimented well with the nigiri.  I was disappointed that they didn't include Hokkaido uni to their omakase set.  We had to order it as an addition.  I loved the freshness that you can taste from the uni.  Downside, it wasn't on the omakase set as it should have since it was such a delight to taste and would have been overlooked if we didn't order it.

As much as I want to really flatter this place, it didn't spark me as oh my, I have to return for their almighty sashimi, sushi and so forth.  It's a tucked away small spot and discrete.  Reservations are required and you have to tell them ahead of time that you want the chef's counter.  

I left feeling: yes, it was fine dining splurge.  Great celebratory restaurant to attend to.  Not the best sashimi ever, but you get it Michelin style.

excerpts: The kussi oysters and the croquette are my second favorites and lastly, if you didn't order the $150 omakase, I would definitely order the uni off of the regular menu.
The uni was so light and wasn't overwhelming at all (like most restaurants).
uni.author: Tram N.
uni.review:
Kusakabe definitely deserves its Michelin star because the food and the customer service here is phenomenal. My dining experience was nothing short of exceptional. 

::Food
First of all, I enjoyed the $95 Omakase course very much but if I had to do it again, I would definitely pay a bit more and go for the $150 omakase course. The additional courses that you get for the latter is definitely worth the extra $50 ! Go big or go home ! 

The dinner experience went by so fast like a blur (probably because everything was delicious and it felt like floating on clouds in heaven). My favorite is hands down the toro - you can never go wrong with toro- but every single nigiri and sashimi serving was incredibly fresh. The kussi oysters and the croquette are my second favorites and lastly, if you didn't order the $150 omakase, I would definitely order the uni off of the regular menu. The uni was so light and wasn't overwhelming at all (like most restaurants). The almond ice cream was also a great finishing touch so definitely order dessert because there should always be room for dessert. 

::Service
The servicing was incredibly. Everyone was very attentive and knowledgeable. Sadly, we didn't get a chance to sit at the bar, though the experience was just as nice to have our own table. I would definitely recommend getting a bar seating to learn more about the dishes and get a first seat experience at how the dishes are prepared. Reservations aren't that hard to get if you're booking for a party of 2 but anything more than that will take a long time. It took me about 2-3 months to get a reservation for a party of 4. Definitely worth the experience and I can definitely say that I'll be back again.

excerpts: The Kaisui Uni was literally THE best uni I've EVER eaten in my life.
uni.author: Cynthia H.
uni.review:
Had one of the most amazing dining experiences of my life here last night!!! The $150 was SO worth it. Chef Nori was so kind and willing to adjust the menu to what me and my boyfriend like and he was great at explaining each dish to us. Whenever we asked him questions, he was very willing to answer them and explain too! We learned a lot about where they source their fish and the insanely quick shipping they have from Japan to SF. 

Overall, the service was on point and the food quality was just amazing - The Kaisui Uni was literally THE best uni I've EVER eaten in my life. The finale of toro and A5 wagyu was so delicious too - seriously, melt in your mouth good! We also ordered the shrimp a la carte which was huge and you get to eat it in two ways, the body quickly poached over rice and the head deep-fried! I also really enjoyed the BBQ eel with sansho pepper, super fatty eel and no bones in it at all.

This experience was more than I could've asked for and I 100% will be back!! Deserves more than 1 michelin star for sure! Chef Nori, food quality, service - all A+++++, well worth the $400 meal.

excerpts: Then there where whoppers like A5 and uni that were total flavor bombs.
If I had to sum this place up as a band it would be Fugazi.
Slow parts that make you almost tired and question why you are there and then all of the sudden you get smacked with this wicked over the top noise and feedback.
Fugazi shows cost 5 bucks, this didn't.
uni.author: Katenryan B.
uni.review:
Kusakabe is an interesting place. You get lots of stuff you probably haven't tried ever and that's good. But the staff rushes through the description that half the time you don't really know what you just ate. I had 10 courses and I could maybe tell you about 5-6 of them. The freshness of the fish is unreal, but again, weird, as some fish had little to no taste. Then there where whoppers like A5 and uni that were total flavor bombs. If I had to sum this place up as a band it would be Fugazi. Slow parts that make you almost tired and question why you are there and then all of the sudden you get smacked with this wicked over the top noise and feedback. Fugazi shows cost 5 bucks, this didn't. Like I said in the first line, interesting place.

PS-I don't like to get dressed up, for this I did, a little. But, there is absolutely no dress code here.

excerpts: My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte).
Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch.
uni.author: Jennifer K.
uni.review:
I took my boyfriend to KUSAKABE for his birthday back in February, and it was quite the eye opening experience!

I've always been a fan of sushi, but this was our first time trying omakase. KUSAKABE took my love for sushi to the next level. Eat with your hands, and no need to dip the nigiri into soy sauce or add any extra wasabi; the chef puts it on your plate, and you stuff it into your mouth. Have a bottle of sake (or two) while you're at it!

My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte). Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch. :)

Can't wait to be back!

excerpts: The Hokkaido uni, my favorite, really transported us back to Japan.
The service is also impeccable.
They were so kind, accommodating and efficient.
There was a small hiccup during the service and they apologized immediately which I really appreciated.
They comped us some dessert which was also delicious.
They made our anniversary truly memorable.
I can't wait to return!
uni.author: Karen K.
uni.review: If you are contemplating whether or not to go, definitely go! The sushi is extremely fresh and the presentation is beautiful. The chef presents dishes that tend toward very clean flavors with touches of citrus, like yuzu and shiso leaf. Things were slightly inconsistent with a little too much wasabi here and there, but overall very enjoyable. The Hokkaido uni, my favorite, really transported us back to Japan. The service is also impeccable. They were so kind, accommodating and efficient. There was a small hiccup during the service and they apologized immediately which I really appreciated. They comped us some dessert which was also delicious. They made our anniversary truly memorable. I can't wait to return!

excerpts: My favorites being the kaisui uni (completely melt in your mouth!!) wish it was a bigger piece though,
Santa Barbara uni, bbq unagi (soft and very good), toro (amazing), chu toro (they season this extremely well, lots of flavors).
uni.author: Susan M.
uni.review:
Boyfriend took me here to celebrate our anniversary, great choice as this place has been at the top of my list for quite a while now! This was my first Michelin star dining experience and I am so glad it was as it was absolutely amazing. 

We started off with the Omakase courses which were 7 courses for $95pp. I wasn't a huge fan of the seaweed drink they give you to cleanse your palette. My favorites of the courses were the chu toro and copper salmon nigiri, although pretty much all the nigiri they served as part of the omakase were delicious. Each piece was specially seasoned and super fresh. I loved the turtle soup dish (can't believe I ate a cute little turtle), but  shockingly, it was amazing. The dish with two crispy fish in a truffle sauce and shishito pepper was another favorite of mine. Pretty much licked the dish clean because the truffle sauce was so tasty. I also really enjoyed the 5 piece le petit sampler plate of the chefs specials. Huge fan of the crispy eggplant and the tuna over rice piece. 

For the last piece,we chose the a5 wagyu sushi. I gotta say that I was not completely blown away with this piece. I actually think that Sushi Sams in San Mateo has a better A5. I mean it was definitely good, but not as amazing as I was hoping for. 

We ordered a bunch of sushi al a carte. My favorites being the kaisui uni (completely melt in your mouth!!) wish it was a bigger piece though, Santa Barbara uni, bbq unagi (soft and very good), toro (amazing), chu toro (they season this extremely well, lots of flavors). Each bite was complete heaven for me. 

This was my boyfriends first time trying Omakase and he normally doesn't like to eat raw fish other than salmon and hamachi, however, he loved every single bite of their omakase and is now addicted! Uh oh..

Their sake is also very good. I had a glass of reisling, but next time I'd probably refrain from getting this just so I could order more sushi! 

Service was wonderful. The only suggestion that I have is to be more careful and remember if people have specific food restrictions. I asked for no wasabi in all the dishes, however, we had to remind our waitress at least 3 times and there was still some wasabi in my sushi :( which took away from some of the taste for me. They made it up by giving us free dessert for our anniversary. Desserts were delicious, I would highly recommend the pancetta and I'd probably skip out on the corn ice cream next time. 

Make sure you make reservations months in advance if you want to sit at the bar and you can probably get in a months in advance if just for a table. Place is tiny and they have 2 groups for seating, one at 5pm and another at 8pm.

Would I come back? Absolutely! This place is definitely not cheap, but it's worth it to splurge for a special occasion or if you want to take yourself out for some high quality japanese food/sushi. The omakase itself is actually a good amount. It won't get you buffet full, but it's definitely enough and if you order a few pieces al a carte, you should be good to go!

excerpts: The uni was also delicious.
I enjoyed every minute of it.
uni.author: Alice Z.
uni.review: My boyfriend took me here as a surprise birthday celebration after an afternoon from MOIC close by. We had the Grand Omakase and everything was very yummy, also had a great time with the chef. He introduced us to "cod fish roe" aka cod sperm and it was special because they're only able to serve this during the winter. It was so good we asked for seconds! And of course we got seconds of o-toro, our favorite. The uni was also delicious. I enjoyed every minute of it.

excerpts: I mentioned that I liked uni and aji the best and we ended up with an amazing nigiri omakase selection.
I gotta say, the japanese uni was definitely my favorite out of the three.
uni.author: Crystal Z.
uni.review:
TL;DR - Great omakase, stella sake menu, fun sushi chefs!

I've been to a couple omakase places in SF and I gotta say, Kusakabe is definitely my favorite so far.

The atmosphere is warm and inviting as the chefs are all so friendly (but each with their own fun personalities)

The sake menu is also pretty varied and between the five or six sakes that we ordered, we were not disappointed by any of the pairings. 

Onto the food. We opted for the $95 omakase as we wanted to add more nigiri a la carte. Our chef was so funny and very considerate of what we liked and didn't like. I mentioned that I liked uni and aji the best and we ended up with an amazing nigiri omakase selection.

I gotta say, the japanese uni was definitely my favorite out of the three. If you are between unis and wan to try one, get that one.

OH and desserts. DO NOT PASS UP ON DESSERTS.

Yuzu sorbet and sake creme brulee. Get it. You're welcome.

excerpts: My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro.
uni.author: Daniel L.
uni.review:
Would love to thank Joe, Christina, and Albert for our wonderful experience at Kusakabe. This was our second time here, this time at a table instead of the bar. Food was splendid, better than anything you can get out of a plastic box or local sushi joint. I absolutely love how they carefully explained everything as it came out, and was very mindful of any allergies or dislikes in terms of food. 

They also give you an A La Carte option at the end of your omakase. My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro. My girlfriend told me the only time I make the face I made while eating those is in the bedroom. 

Service is usually something I pay close attention to, and they were very courteous and cheerful in their delivery. Sincere thanks again to Joe, Christina, and Albert.

excerpts: Some of my favorites of the night were the Zuke Chutoro, Hokkaido Scallop and Uni, Cured King Salmon Roe, Ayu, Shirayaki and the Toro finale.
The ingredients they use are super fresh (they even fly in eel from Tokyo) and of the highest quality, and it really came through during the meal.
uni.author: Jessica Z.
uni.review:
I'm usually not one to drop more than $40 per person on dinner, so coming to Kusukabe was really a special occasion. I took my boyfriend here to celebrate his birthday (and as a treat for myself), and can honestly say that it was worth every penny. At $95 per person for the Omakase and $150 for the Grand Omakase, this place will definitely make a dent in your wallet, but it really is worth it.

We made reservations three weeks in advance for a Thursday night. There are only two seatings: one at 5PM and another at 8PM. We chose the later time so there would be no rush. While they can't guarantee that you will be seated at the sushi bar, you can request when you make the reservation and if you arrive early you have a pretty good chance!

We were lucky enough to have Chef Kusakabe himself prepare our meal and opted for the Grand Omakase ($150 with 15 courses and 25 pieces total). Overall, the pace of the meal was great - being able to watch Kusakabe prepare each piece was a total treat and he explained each piece to us as he was making them. Some of my favorites of the night were the Zuke Chutoro, Hokkaido Scallop and Uni, Cured King Salmon Roe, Ayu, Shirayaki and the Toro finale. The ingredients they use are super fresh (they even fly in eel from Tokyo) and of the highest quality, and it really came through during the meal. We finished the meal with a creme brûlée, and the entire restaurant sang happy birthday to my boyfriend.

Overall, the dining experience at Kusakabe was nothing short of exceptional. From the ambience and customer service to the food, this was one of the most memorable evenings I've had and I hope to be back!

excerpts: Kaisui Uni
uni.author: Tinah Y.
uni.review:
In the last 3 months I went to three different Japanese restaurants that served an Omakase style menu. Omakase stands for a meal consisting of dishes selected by the Chef. I highly recommend this because you get to taste a wide variety of fresh fish and flavors that you may not normally would order. You will likely try something that you have never tried before and be pleasantly surprised. 

Out of the three Omakases that I tried, Kusakabe, by far, was my favorite. (The other two places I went to was Kabuto in Las Vegas & Kru in Sacramento, feel free to check out my reviews for them.)

Kusakabe stood out above the other two primarily because of their flavors. It's been a long time that I tasted something and was wowed over and over again. Servings come in bite sizes so it's okay to eat the whole thing in one bite and wait for it.... ah... foodgasm!!!!  No exaggeration, the food was so good that we kept ordering more and more from the "second menu"; we couldn't get enough.

The second reason why this was better than the other two was the friendliness and professionalism of the staff. From the Hostess, Grace, to all the waiter, waitresses and of course, the Chefs, my cousin and I really enjoyed ourselves. We sat at the bar and everyone was very attentive and was more than happy to explain and answer any questions that we had. The Omakase in Vegas was so rigid that you almost didn't want to ask anything or even speak. I like to learn about what I'm eating and have fun while I'm eating. The Staff at Kusakabe, definitely provided that atmosphere. 

There are approximately 15 seats at the bar, a large table for 8 or so, and three small tables for parties of two. If you go, try and get a seating at the bar; you'll have the most interaction with the Chefs and you get to see how everything is prepared; it's a real treat! 

Our meal started with a Welcome tea made of Konbu cha or kelp tea; it tastes much better than it sounds... drink up!

Our first bite was Zuke Chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce), maaaaaaaaaaaan.... ah...sorry... another foodgasm just thinking back... this had such a powerful flavor; you'll be very surprised. And the rest of the meal continued on with every bite just as good as the first.

The most surprising dish was the Suppon umami soup with Domyo-ji Manjyu (Soft shell turtle soup with sticky rice). I know, it's hard to comprehend that you are eating a sweet innocent turtle but you just have to have an open mind and try it. YOU WILL WANT MORE!

In addition to the Omakase menu, we also ordered: 

Ayu (Japanese Sweet fish with grated Japanese cucumbers)
Ji Kinmedai (Lightly cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper)
Umimasu (Tasmanian ocean trout lightly poached)
Kohada (Gizzard shad with crystallized egg yolk)
Kaisui Uni (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin)

I would eat each and every one of those over and over again. 

Hot tea came with the meal but we also ordered Yuki no Bosha "Cabin in the Snow" Junmai Ginjo sake which was light and fruity, went well with the meal. 

For dessert we had the vanilla panna cotta with Ume caramel and Fresh corn and white miso ice cream parfait... go for the fresh corn and white miso ice cream parfait... delicious!  

The grand total for our meal was $351.26 (tips not included) but it was worth every penny and I would go back again and again... pocket book permitted, that is!

excerpts: Highlights for me were the Uni (Hokkaido)
- what can I say, Uni is just the best,  the Chutoro - which I prefer over the otoro, the Shima Aji - love my white jacks, and the Alaskan King Salmon - such perfect fat content .
Was lucky enough to be served by Chef Kasakube which made the experience all the more enjoyable.
uni.author: Wooju C.
uni.review: From the minute you walk in you can tell why they are Michelin rated.  The service is refined and the pace felt just right.  All the fine cuts and variety of fish you'd expect in a high end omakase experience.  Highlights for me were the Uni (Hokkaido) - what can I say, Uni is just the best,  the Chutoro - which I prefer over the otoro, the Shima Aji - love my white jacks, and the Alaskan King Salmon - such perfect fat content .  Was lucky enough to be served by Chef Kasakube which made the experience all the more enjoyable.

excerpts: Highlights - Kuisui Uni, Golden Eye Snapper, BBQ White Eel
uni.author: Eddie W.
uni.review:
#875 =) 

For my best friends birthday we decided to go to Kusakabe to celebrate. 

Ambiance - charming, intimate, welcoming 
Quality- superb 
Service - efficient, friendly, accommodating 
Value - omakase at $95 a person is well worth it when you see the quality and variety of dishes that you get 

Sit at the sushi bar if you can, it's a far better experience! 

Highlights - Kuisui Uni, Golden Eye Snapper, BBQ White Eel, Lobster covered in rice popcorn, Copper King Salmon just to name a few! 

Overall Thoughts

One of the best sushi experiences I have had in SF to date

excerpts: We love Uni
Kaisun and bafun Uni were the two Uni that we ordered and both were creamy with a good texture.
It was melt in your mouth good and they did not have a weird fishy taste like some other units we have had in the past.
uni.author: Stella J.
uni.review:
By far one of my favorite omakase experiences behind Maruya(before the chef change, don't know how it is now). My boyfriend and I decided to celebrate our 3 year anniversary here last week and it was a good choice. Getting reservations weeknights was easy but seemed more difficult for a weekend. 

We had reservations at 8, we arrived a little early and were seated at the bar, which is definitely the way to go for any omakase. I forget which chef we had but he was pretty cool to chat with. The omakase had 7 courses which was more than enough. The starting toro was a great way to start the meal. I really loved how they really took into consideration what fish you like and gave you fresh nigiri within the fish groups you like. I can't say that I didn't like anything in the omakase cause I liked everything. Well the only exception would be the ice fish in the chefs petite plate , it tasted ok but not my favorite fish but everything else was exceptional. 

The toro at the end was mouth watering and good! Definitely a great way to end the meal. When the omakase is over they hand you a a la carte menu to order anything extra. We love Uni so we ended with ordering that and extra toro, a5 waygu beef nigiri. A5 waygu was also great, it was fatty and slightly torched but it was so good! I would definitely get this again but I still love toro more! Kaisun and bafun Uni were the two Uni that we ordered and both were creamy with a good texture. It was melt in your mouth good and they did not have a weird fishy taste like some other units we have had in the past. They tasted super fresh especially since they were both imported from Japan. 

Overall, we really liked the omakase, but anything from the a la carte menu really racks up the tab. A
Great place for special occasions and for sushi purists. Definitely a place to try at least once! 

Total for 2 w/ tax & tip: $314

excerpts: the kaisuke uni.
uni.author: Annie L.
uni.review:
I really approve of this place! I had to make reservations a month in advance, but it was well worth the wait. 

I ended up taking my mom and we were seated at the sushi bar, pretty much immediately when we walked in. There was a bit of a wait before our waiter approached us, but the service was pretty good after that. Everything on the omakase menu for surprised us pleasantly dish after dish, but I think my favorite was the bonito, finale (got both wagyu beef and toro), and the kaisuke uni. 

Can't wait til my next visit :) really good price for omakase and the unique fish!

excerpts: Get the extended omakase menu and get extra uni at the end.
The menu changes seasonally as well
so I will have to return.
It's a splurge, but one you will remember.
uni.author: Sarah J.
uni.review: This review is late as I went in February. But I feel compelled to say dinner here is worth every penny. Try to get seated at the top of the sushi bar towards the door so you have the owner making your sushi, not the underlings. The fish is amazing but what really stands out are the cooked dishes. Gorgeous and delicious all of them! Interesting things like little itty bitty squid and tiny baby translucent eels. The only dish I didn't care for was the turtle soup. It has a sharp flavor and I felt guilty about the turtle I had as a pet growing up. All the sushi pieces have been elaborately prepared with complex sauces or smoking. A lot of time and effort goes into these. Get the extended omakase menu and get extra uni at the end. The menu changes seasonally as well so I will have to return. It's a splurge, but one you will remember.

excerpts:
Next time I will add:
-KAISUI UNI (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin):
If you're looking for a different type of uni this is an interesting bite.
Creamier texture, lighter flavor, more sweet.
We watched the guy next to us eat it jealously.
-JI
KINMEDAI (Cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper): I didn't over this because I had it at Akiko's before but
the guy next to us, again, said it was the best.
Dammit.
uni.author: Christina L.
uni.review:
This place is OUT OF CONTROL. How much so? My fiance and I are currently trying to buy a house yet Kusakabe let us to a real discussion of whether it would be better to put our money into a mortgage or maybe just eating at Kusakabe a couple times every week. I mean, seriously, I'm sure owning your own home is overrated.

Kusakabe operates under a omakase menu style with a $95 or $150 option. We opted for the $95 option and it is pretty much set although the sushi chef has a little bit of wiggle room with 5 different seasonal sushis of the day. He will also ask you at the beginning what type of fish you usually like! Pro tip: MUST sit at the bar. After your omakase is done you can opt to go a la carte to try other types of fish. Spoiler alert: You will likely feel compelled to continue after your omakase is done, there is just so much good stuff to try!

Here's an overview of our meal. Standouts will be emphasized with CAPITAL LETTERS!
1. First brewed dashi: A light broth with tons of umami, good to kick off your appetite
2. Sushi Prelude: 
-SEARED CHUTORO comes standard and was amazing!
Two kinds of seasonal sushi of the day: 
-Hirame (Halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf) - I'm not usually a fan of halibut but this was really good quality and the shiso leaf added freshness while the liver added creaminess
-Katsuo (Lightly cherry wood smoked bonito) - Smokey flavor added a lot to this one and the smooth tuna texture had a great mouth feel
3. Sashimi course: Maguro and Hokkaido Scallop with fresh wasabe & yuzu onion sauce. Both really good quality, the scallop was sweet and delicious with a good portion and the yuzu onion sauce was intriguing.
4. Hassun: This was 7 bites served together and you are free to eat it in any order. I chose to try and eat it in order of lighter to heavier -
-Baby Eel: This was something new, not too much flavor but the broth it came in was delicious
-DUCK BREAST: refreshing to get a bite of meat and it was well cooked and served over broccolini
-Salmon wrapped in daikon: Good salmon flavor, tastes more refreshing with the daikon
-Kusshi oyster: Fresh oyster, yum
-Rice octopus: Good texture and flavor
-Tamago with snapper: This egg was super fluffy and sweet tasting, not like your usual tamago
-TORO ON BOX RICE: The toro was amazing and the rice perfectly seasoned
5. SOUP: Spring hamaguri soup with fresh bamboo shoot, wakame & shiitake mushrooms - perfect to have something warm. The clams were perfectly cooked, broth filled with umami.
6. Sushi Chic:
-BURI (Wild Yellowtail): Basically the best yellowtail ever. It had more fattiness like chutoro but tons of that delicious yellowtail flavor. See picture for amazing fattiness!
-Kuromutsu (Japanese blue fish): Very light flavor but nice bite and texture
-COPPER RIVER KING (Wild Alaskan king salmon with Oboro Konbu): Best salmon ever, so much flavor and the bit of seaweed on top gives it a touch of earthiness. 
7. Sushi Finale:
-WAGYU (A5 grade Miyazaki Wagyu strip loin): Lightly seared and salted, it's definitely the best wagyu sushi I've had. The sear is key!
-TORO (Bluefin fatty tuna belly): Ridiculous. Watching Chef Kusakabe cut this fish and then watching the chefs gingerly pass the pieces down the line and then watching your chef assemble the sushi is a ridiculous level of anticipation. And it was worth it.

At this point you're essentially devastated that your meal is over and it's time to make some tough decisions. We added:
-KAMASU: Lightly seared Japanese Barracuda - great sear flavor on a slightly fishier taking fish. Definitely a good add.
-TORO: What, again?? We needed to have another bite but this time our sushi chef seared the toro gently and added all sorts of other goodies. It completely changed up the flavor of the toro and was so worth it. MUST do again.

Next time I will add:
-KAISUI UNI (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin): If you're looking for a different type of uni this is an interesting bite. Creamier texture, lighter flavor, more sweet. We watched the guy next to us eat it jealously.
-JI KINMEDAI (Cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper): I didn't over this because I had it at Akiko's before but the guy next to us, again, said it was the best. Dammit. Next time.

All in all it was an amazing dining experience and I can't wait to go again! It is a SAN FRANCISCO MUST.

excerpts: Of course, we couldn't resist tacking on a-la-carte items such as the life changing bafun uni, but we did bring our own sake and paid a modest $25 corkage fee (vs. $85 sake pairing per person).
uni.author: Khanh T.
uni.review:
Honestly the toro nigiri and wagyu A5 nigiri will be the best things to ever enter your mouth.

Seriously though, this hands down was the best meal of my life. Every single detail of our meal here was perfection. The $95 omakase menu is a great value, considering you'd spend more per head at any other michelin star restaurant in SF. Of course, we couldn't resist tacking on a-la-carte items such as the life changing bafun uni, but we did bring our own sake and paid a modest $25 corkage fee (vs. $85 sake pairing per person).

Tip - Most of the seats here are at the sushi bar, so you have direct interaction with your sushi chef - a memorable experience that is unmatched by any other restaurant. However, if you're the last ones in for your seating time, you will be seated at the tables, so arrive on time if not early! There are two seatings per night - 5pm or 8pm.

excerpts: He also had 3 types of uni that night: regular uni from Hokkaido, short spine uni from Hokkaido, and regular uni from Santa Barbara.
We got to do a side-by-side taste test.
uni.author: Lily L.
uni.review:
My dining companion and I came to Kusakabe  for dinner.  We called to say we were running 10 minutes late and the hostess was very understanding and thanked us for calling and told us not to worry.  We were seated at the sushi bar in Chef Nori's section.  What a treat.

The sushi is absolutely fresh and wonderful.  I loved his technique of smoking fish.  He placed the sliced fish on a cherry board and used a torch to burn the surrounding wood which gave the fish a slight hint of smokiness.  Delish!

We did the grand Omakase tasting menu with the sake pairing.  It was very good.  The portions were not enough so we ordered a few more items.  The wagyu beef was so good we got seconds of that.  He also had 3 types of uni that night: regular uni from Hokkaido, short spine uni from Hokkaido, and regular uni from Santa Barbara.  We got to do a side-by-side taste test.  We loved the two from Hokkaido the best.

I would go back in a heart beat...after I break the piggy bank.

excerpts: I normally don't like uni but the uni scallop sushi flavors blended together well.
uni.author: Kevin B.
uni.review:
Perfectly seasoned and fresh sushi that came at a good pace. Thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish. I normally don't like uni but the uni scallop sushi flavors blended together well.

I enjoyed the non-sushi dishes. The Les petit plats was fun to explore and a good variety between sushi pieces. The snap pea soup with crispy fish was surprisingly flavorful.

The finishing A5 Miyazaki wagyu beef and otoro sushi melted like butter in my mouth and ended the meal on a high. One of my all time favorite sushi experiences with excellent service.

excerpts: - Sushi Chic - more nigiri sushi including uni (sea urchin) from Santa Barbara!
I'm not a big uni fan
but oh boy this one was so buttery and creamy and slightly sweet.
Definitely can taste the quality and freshness!
uni.author: Jingxi Z.
uni.review:
Best omakase by far in SF! My lovely BF surprised me with reservations here for our anniversary and oh my god it was such a beautiful and creative dining experience.

Reservations become available online 2 months in advance and for the true omakase experience you gotta sit at the sushi bar so you can watch your chef can personalize each part of the meal to your liking :) 

They only serve omakase, a $150 grand set or the $95 set, with options for add-ons at the end of the meal. Feeling fancy, we opted for the grand set and if you're looking for a time to splurge, this would be it!

The omakase experience is unique to each restaurant but the creativity and care that goes into each piece is where Kusakabe really shines. Each dish was well-thought out and went beyond just the typical nigiri. Before our meal our sushi chef asked us if there was anything we didn't like or really liked. I really dislike wasabi and usually for omakase they add it to every piece of sushi. However our chef made sure to only put a small amount for all my pieces and I couldn't even taste it!

I believe the menu changes seasonally, but here's what we had:
- Ichiban Dashi - first up was soup, like a fancier version of miso soup, probably the best soup I've had using dashi broth!
- Sushi prelude - next we were served 5 pieces of nigiri sushi, one was the king of all sushi - the toro tuna! So soft and buttery, each and every piece. The other 4 pieces were seasonal and the chef makes sure to tell you where each fish comes from :) I believe we had scallop from Santa Barbara!
- Sashimi - next we were given four different types of sashimi paired with 4 different unique types of sauce/toppings. One included truffle shavings and another was mussels. The flavor combos were so good, although some I liked more than others but definitely all flavors I had never tried before.
- Hassun - the creativity continues with a box of a random assortment of seafood in all shapes and forms. But presentation on point for errything. Honestly some weren't that tasty (there was a weird seafood cracker that I didn't like) but again, just so unique and such detailed preparation.
- Soup - this was a creamy cauliflower soup with abalone and abalone mushrooms. Tasted like a lighter version of clam chowder but seriously soo delicious!
- Sushi Chic - more nigiri sushi including uni (sea urchin) from Santa Barbara! I'm not a big uni fan but oh boy this one was so buttery and creamy and slightly sweet. Definitely can taste the quality and freshness!
- Sushi Finale - ended with Unagi (BBQ eel) and a choice of toro or wagyu beef. I'd recommend the wagyu beef since it is so tender and they sear it right in front of you with a touch of pepper. It just melted in my mouth like butter. How is this possible?! 

On top of the amazing food was amazing service. They surprised us at the end with sorbet at the end to celebrate our anniversary! If you want a perfect dining experience this is it.

excerpts: I was in love with the Kasai Uni!
Had 1 spoonful, then I ordered 3 more for myself.
My second favorite would be the baracuda.
uni.author: Sylvia C.
uni.review:
One Word: Delicious! Came here for valentine's day, so we ordered the grand omakase. The nigiri was amazing. Every sauce or pairing enhanced the flavor of the fish so well, I would have stayed there all night. After the omakase, you are free to order whatever you like. I was in love with the Kasai Uni! Had 1 spoonful, then I ordered 3 more for myself. My second favorite would be the baracuda. Although the fish was only seared, the crisp on top and the sweet taste was perfect.

The wagyu was mediocre probably because they added too much salt. The yuzu sorbet wasn't that great either as the shiso leaf taste too strong. But on the bright side, they creme Brulee was good. 

Service was great. The waiters were quite attentive and our glass was always full.

excerpts: The sushi and sashimi courses were flawless - standouts were the white eel (OMG so good, with a slight crispiness on top ahh), uni (melts in your mouth delicious), chutoro, wagyu.
uni.author: Christine Y.
uni.review:
4.5 stars!!!! We got the grand omakase for $150 pp - each party gets their own chef if you sit at the sushi bar; however, your chef will take breaks to prepare sushi for those sitting at the tables. This was my second time doing a bougie omakase, my first was Sushi Nakazawa in NYC. Your experience will differ based on how talkative your chef is - ours was a little too reserved for my preference.

The sushi and sashimi courses were flawless - standouts were the white eel (OMG so good, with a slight crispiness on top ahh), uni (melts in your mouth delicious), chutoro, wagyu. However I didn't enjoy the kaiseki dishes as much, but that is true in general, not due to any fault of Kusakabe.

While I liked the omakase at Nakazawa better (there was no yellowtail in this omakase, and I wish the fatty tuna at Kusakabe was fattier!), but you definitely get more food at Kusakabe. After the omakase, you have the option to order from the a la carte menu if any of your favorites didn't make it into the omakase. Wish we'd had the time/room for a la carte and dessert. Overall no regrets! But with all the amazing sushi places in SF I probably won't be making a return visit, at least for a long time.

excerpts: I selected the Grand-Omakase-Style, each dish looks gorgeous and tastes scrumptious, the food is made of the very fresh halibut, sorts of blue fin tuna, the best one is the Uni from Hokkaido-Japan, way better than the typical Santa Babara Uni, however, this type of Uni is NOT part of the tasting menu, you might have to order from the La Carte Menu after after-meal..... if you still would like to enjoy more.
uni.author: Tengjiao W.
uni.review: I should say: every dollar really worth it! I selected the Grand-Omakase-Style, each dish looks gorgeous and tastes scrumptious, the food is made of the very fresh halibut, sorts of blue fin tuna, the best one is the Uni from Hokkaido-Japan, way better than the typical Santa Babara Uni, however, this type of Uni is NOT part of the tasting menu, you might have to order from the La Carte Menu after after-meal..... if you still would like to enjoy more.

excerpts: Also, Bafun Uni, always bafun uni.
It's sweeter
and I much prefer it over Kaisen Uni.
Be warned if you tell them you are celebrating a birthday and order dessert, they (as in the whole restaurant) will sing to you.
uni.author: Stephanie L.
uni.review: Back here for the third time and am now addicted. I am so happy there is finally a great omakase option in SF other than Akiko's. Sushi is amazing and ambiance is fantastic. Always make sure you sit at the sushi counter and if possible, ask to sit closer to Chef Kusakabe himself. Order the Grand Omakase because it's worth the splurge. Also, Bafun Uni, always bafun uni. It's sweeter and I much prefer it over Kaisen Uni. Be warned if you tell them you are celebrating a birthday and order dessert, they (as in the whole restaurant) will sing to you.

excerpts: Get the Kaisui uni because it's really one of the best.
uni.author: Irene C.
uni.review:
Don't get me wrong, the food is 5 stars. Everything was really good. The fish was fresh, sauce and rice were made just right... But everything was miniature size and lasted 1-2 bites. I have no idea how the couple next to us can take so long to eat 3 small pieces of nigiri. And the le petit four.. How much more petit can you go? Like another poster said.. I kept waiting for one dish that can fill me up. But I got nothing.There was a risotto dish and they put the food inside a clam shell.. Which is then set on a big plate. Yes.. Presentation is quite nice.. But I didn't spend $300 looking at my food. Also ... Risotto was not fully cooked but overall taste was fine. Get the Kaisui uni because it's really one of the best. 

Tip: don't talk while eating the delicious sushi here because 1) you should be enjoying each bite 2) you talk too much you might end up swallowing your food without ever touching your taste buds cux the portion is so small. It can sneak right through the tongue and straight to your stomach.

excerpts: Uni from Japan and Santa Barbra were great.
uni.author: Elaine L.
uni.review:
One of the better omakase menus I have had. The chef was really receptive in that he asked  which types of fish we liked and disliked. Waiters and waitresses are really nice. 
Omakase always takes about 2 hours and this place is not an exception. We did have room after for some a la carte pieces. Uni from Japan and Santa Barbra were great.

excerpts: - UNI !!!
I am an uni lover, so I ordered all three types (Kaisui, Bafun, and Santa Barbara) from the a la carte menu.
uni.author: Kiana S.
uni.review:
After perusing a few prior reviews and photos, I had to see if Kusakabe lived up to the hype...and it did not disappoint! Apparently the place is completely booked for months; my date and I snagged a reservation for 5:15 on a Monday (maybe not an "ideal" time for most, but hey, I honestly don't mind; I'm down for sushi any time of the day or night!) 

I won't bore you with a detailed description of every single item because the menu is not secret; pretty much stays the same between weeks and months except for the seasonal fish of the day. We also shared wine pairing, which was solid. It all was fantastic, and I left very satisfied. 

The only thing that was less than fantastic, for me, was: 
- Umami soup with angel prawn and cod: I'm not a huge fan of cooked prawn, and I didn't like the texture of the condensed block of rice/fish in the middle.

**Favorite pieces**
- Zuke chutoro (melt-in-your mouth, perfectly seasoned and seared!)
- Chef's sashimi, Maguro and Hokkaido scallop (so fresh~)
- Copper river king salmon (with oboro konbu)
- Toro (can't go wrong here)
- UNI !!! I am an uni lover, so I ordered all three types (Kaisui, Bafun, and Santa Barbara) from the a la carte menu. Kaisui was definitely the winner, but they were all delectable. 

Dessert:
- Chestnut ice cream parfait (was delicious, the ice cream was very rich and highlighted the chestnut perfectly)
- Kabocha squash pudding (had an Okinawan black sugar glaze that made it perfect)

Overall, definitely the best omakase & meal I've had in SF thus far.

excerpts: /uni, Toro, Wagyu beef, Medium blue fin tuna, white eel, and homemade sesame ice cream with hot sauce (additional fee for dessert).
uni.author: Gina T.
uni.review:
Wanted to hit the three SF Michelin sushi/omakase restaurants, and Kusakabe was our final stop after Omakase and Wako.  At each restaurant, we had the full omakase menu.  

Overall, Kusakabe's quality of fish is on par with both Omakase and Wako.  However, we felt that the execution of many items was subpar.  Several nigiri and kitchen items were overpowered by some component of the dish, whether it be too much cucumber rolled within trout, too much acid (lemon) on the oyster,  or beans that dominated the crab salad.  We just want the fish to shine.

On the plus side, Kusakabe's rice was well cooked and seasoned.  We liked that, proportionally, the balance of fish to rice was just right.  Wako, on the other hand, served too much rice and it was not as well flavored.  The items that really stood out for us at Kusakabe:  Cauliflower/abalone soup, Bonito, Scallop w/uni, Toro, Wagyu beef, Medium blue fin tuna, white eel, and homemade sesame ice cream with hot sauce (additional fee for dessert).

Ambiance wise, Kusakabe is much more casual, loud and impersonal than Omakase and Wako.  The kitchen is busy, busy, busy, and there is much more limited chef interaction at the bar as compared to Omakase and Wako, both of which are quiet, subdued, and intimate.  It really depends on what you prefer.  If you're on a casual friend's night out, go to Kusakabe so you can talk and laugh as loud as you like.  If you're in the mood for ambiance and peace, both Omakase (especially) and Wako should fit the bill.

Speaking of bills, they're all priced the same, but we felt that Omakase served larger pieces of fish.

excerpts: I got the $95 omakase, deep sea uni and the creme brulee dessert.
Each dish was served one after another, and our waitress talked a bit too fast for me to know what fish we were having at times.
The fish all tasted great and fresh like expected from a Michelin restaurant.
Let's just say.. there wasn't anything I didn't like or enjoy.
I have been to higher end sushi restaurants in Tokyo before, and this place is definitely close to what I had experienced.
The dessert was on the house because of my birthday.
I'd return in the future for sure.
Almost $300 for two people isn't bad and considering the quality of the food.
uni.author: Kosmo Z.
uni.review: My brother is a huge fan of Kusakabe, so I decided to come here for my birthday. You might not spot the sign until you are standing right ouside of the restaurant. I got the $95 omakase, deep sea uni and the creme brulee dessert. Each dish was served one after another, and our waitress talked a bit too fast for me to know what fish we were having at times. The fish all tasted great and fresh like expected from a Michelin restaurant. Let's just say.. there wasn't anything I didn't like or enjoy. I have been to higher end sushi restaurants in Tokyo before, and this place is definitely close to what I had experienced. The dessert was on the house because of my birthday. I'd return in the future for sure. Almost $300 for two people isn't bad and considering the quality of the food.

excerpts: My friend got the Hokkaido uni and seasonal white cod "male caviar," which was a hilarious topic of conversation.
uni.author: Kelly L.
uni.review:
After hearing my friends rave about this place, I finally had the chance to experience it for myself. This was one of the best omakase I've ever had (and at such a reasonable price, too!).

Chef Ngai was so friendly and skillful. He was happy to explain where the fish came from, how the taste and texture could differ based on location, and gave us some great recommendations for a la carte dishes at the end. My friend got the Hokkaido uni and seasonal white cod "male caviar," which was a hilarious topic of conversation. I was very impressed by every single dish, and I think that Kusakabe has the best sushi rice in SF.

Incredibly fresh sushi and playful banter made for a fantastic dinner after a long day at work. We'll definitely be back for more!

excerpts: We also ordered sushi ala carte - zuke chutoro, uni, and wagyu.
All the fishes were "melt in your mouth" like butta!!!
Make sure to reserve in advance.
uni.author: Vangie D.
uni.review:
Such a lovely experience with divine omakase! We were lucky enough to be seated at the bar and were able to watch them make our food. The staff was attentive and very friendly. 

We went with the Grand Omakase, $165 per person. Hubby had the sake pairing, while I opted out of the wine pairing. Maybe next time! We also ordered sushi ala carte - zuke chutoro, uni, and wagyu. All the fishes were "melt in your mouth" like butta!!! Make sure to reserve in advance.

excerpts: The uni was melting in the mouth.
They have a great wine and sake list.
Great atmosphere and the chef who took care of us,  was very friendly and he  explained every course carefully.
Great service.
Highly recommend.
uni.author: sladana v.
uni.review: Loved the sushi! Very fresh and traditional. The uni was melting in the mouth. They have a great wine and sake list. Great atmosphere and the chef who took care of us,  was very friendly and he  explained every course carefully. Great service. Highly recommend.

excerpts:
it tasted almost like bbq  
  - Hotate: super sweet and tender, topped with uni 
  - Baby snapper topped with crystallized egg

Sushi Chic and Sushi Finale 
  - Shima aji: topped with daikon and yuzu
  - Arctic char: with sea salt and yuzu 
  - Sanma: with grated ginger lime zest, and chives
  - Uni, but I opted for non uni, and it was a torched oily snapper cured in kombu, which was really good
Extras: prices range from $6-15 per piece (tamago vs uni)
- Jin kinmedai: golden eye snapper smoked in cherry wood
uni.author: Marilyn H.
uni.review:
I've been back quite a few times since the first review, and I think it's gotten better in the last year as they re-structured and changed up the menu. 

We started with a sake flight - three 4 oz pours that were all quite different ($50.) We ended up getting two more 8 oz sakes, and in the end, the sake and food cost about the same. Sake definitely complements the sushi, though.  I love their glassware (design, thinness). Sadly, it's pretty much all from a special source in Japan and is not easy to get

We did the grand tasting ($150/person) and some add ons.
1. Dashi to start: served warm in a small cup

2. Sushi: I love their rice, and I liked each piece of the sushi to the point that there was no clear cut favorite
  - Seared chutoro: nice and fatty, cured with soy sauce, love the sear 
  - Hirame: wild halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf
  - Katsuo: smoked in cherry wood, topped with garlic, chives, radish, and it tasted almost like bbq  
  - Hotate: super sweet and tender, topped with uni 
  - Baby snapper topped with crystallized egg yolk 

3. Sashimi: the maguro and barracuda were meant to be dipped with either house grated onion with yuzu, chive, and salt or traditional soy sauce + wasabi
  - Thinly sliced salmon wrapped around cucumber with a bamboo charcoal miso: the miso was very unique 
  - Red snapper: wrapped with ankimo, topped with Italian summer truffle and sitting on a ponzu truffle gelee.  I couldn't taste the truffle much, but the gelee was good 
  - Kamazu: barracuda with micro onion
  - Maguro

4. Hassun: this was a beautifully arranged platter with lots of flavors and textures
  - Oyster with caviar
  - Tempura crab: coated in rice crackers
  - Shrimp cake with sweet corn: best eaten warm; good with dipping salt 
  - Nasu agedashi: served in a little glass bowl with kani and ikura; this dish is very light
  - Squid: very thinly sliced, with baby kiwi, toasted pine nuts, and wakame. The wakame was my favorite part of the dish
  - Box sushi: tuna topped with bonito flakes
  - Box sushi: tamago with a layer of crab underneath, topped with a goji berry 
  - Fried fish with red onion and a vinegar dashi

5. Soup: Puree of cauliflower, which was very rich tasting. It came with a sweet potato paste in the center for more sweetness and thickness, abalone, trumpet mushrooms, abalone mushrooms

6. Sushi Chic and Sushi Finale 
  - Shima aji: topped with daikon and yuzu
  - Arctic char: with sea salt and yuzu 
  - Sanma: with grated ginger lime zest, and chives
  - Uni, but I opted for non uni, and it was a torched oily snapper cured in kombu, which was really good 
  - Shirayaki: BBQ white eel, finished with a light drizzle of sauce and sansho pepper. I like that the sauce doesn't obscure the fish
  - Wagyu (you could also choose toro): A5, super smooth and buttery

Extras: prices range from $6-15 per piece (tamago vs uni)
  - Jin kinmedai: golden eye snapper smoked in cherry wood
  - Kisu: whiting cured with bonito and konbu

We were too full for dessert by the end.  It ends up being a lot of food.  My only complaint is that there's only one bathroom, so there can sometimes be a wait. 

Service is always impeccable, and Chef Ngai did a great job of educating us on the dishes. Definitely get a seat at the sushi bar. I've done a table once, and it was NOT the same.  I think it's a party of 3 or so max for the sushi bar; otherwise, you get seated at the table.

excerpts:
My favorites from the night are listed below:
- Zuke Chutoro Nigiri
- A egg sponge cake with lobster paste (I think)
- Beef croquet in dashi sauce
- Uni Nigiri (perfect balance of rice and Uni)
- Wagyu Nigiri (lightly seared and drizzled with lemon to bring out the full flavor of this amazing cut of beef)
uni.author: Jeff M.
uni.review:
I was very fortunate enough to be served by Chef Nori when I paid a visit to Kusakabe. Chef Nori does not speak as much as his fellow chefs, but his cooking is an art. I enjoyed every moment of watching the omakase dishes being prepared!

My favorites from the night are listed below:
- Zuke Chutoro Nigiri
- A egg sponge cake with lobster paste (I think)
- Beef croquet in dashi sauce
- Uni Nigiri (perfect balance of rice and Uni)
- Wagyu Nigiri (lightly seared and drizzled with lemon to bring out the full flavor of this amazing cut of beef)
- Ankimo Nigiri

There were some interesting dishes such as a tuna bone marrow gelatin that I had never tried before.

In my visit, I learned that the menu doesn't change too often, but items do get substituted out based on what is fresh. Will definitely have to visit again in the future!

excerpts: My favorites are the toro (fatty tuna) and uni (sea urchin).
Usually the omakase is enough to fill a person, but you may also order sushi a la carte afterwards.
I've been there a few times, and the quality has been consistent.
I was served by Kusakabe himself the first time I went.
Kusakabe's staff are all extremely meticulous and professional.
I can't wait to come here again!
uni.author: Michelle C.
uni.review: One of my favorite Japanese restaurants in SF Bay Area. You are required to select the Omakase option, in which you are presented with many kinds of sushi. My favorites are the toro (fatty tuna) and uni (sea urchin). Usually the omakase is enough to fill a person, but you may also order sushi a la carte afterwards. I've been there a few times, and the quality has been consistent. I was served by Kusakabe himself the first time I went. Kusakabe's staff are all extremely meticulous and professional. I can't wait to come here again!

excerpts:
Lightly fried abalone with uni soba risotto
9.

Stripe jack nigiri
10.

Barracuda nigiri
11.
In addition to these I also ordered bufan and kaisui uni.
Though a bit pricey I highly recommended the try both because they are both awesome but do taste different.
Kaisui being more sweet and softer than bafun.
They deserve their michelin star.
uni.author: Richard M.
uni.review:
This place sits about 4.5 stars. This is kaiseki style sushi, So its has some cooked dishes as well as nigiri.  This place is was very good in both terms of its sushi and cooked food. The omakase contained
1.  Kelp tea
2. Zuke chu toro
3.  Hirame nigiri
4. Boniton nigiri
5.  Sashimi akami and hotate
6.  Soft shell turtle in riceball soup
7. Platter with raw baby sardine and daikon, deep fried sweet fish, chu toro pressed sushi,  shigoku topped with caviar
8. Lightly fried abalone with uni soba risotto
9. Stripe jack nigiri
10. Barracuda nigiri
11. king salmon nigiri 
12. Otoro nirigi

In addition to these I also ordered bufan and kaisui uni.  Though a bit pricey I highly recommended the try both because they are both awesome but do taste different.  Kaisui being more sweet and softer than bafun.  They deserve their michelin star.

excerpts: For the uni lovers, one MUST try the Kaisui uni (14.50 a piece- hokkaido sea urchin) and Bafun Uni (13 a piece, Hokkaido short spine sea urchin).
I can honestly say that each bite was simply heavenly & worth every darn dollar.
Hands down the best uni I've had in my life thus far.
uni.author: Ada C.
uni.review:
Around this time last year I booked (far in advance) via OpenTable seating for 2 at the bar for my boyfriend's birthday. Being an avid sushi lover, I knew he would be thrilled to be treated to one of the town's boasted Michelin star Japanese restaurant. Not only did I note on the reservation, but also called & left a voicemail to confirm that this was a birthday celebration. Sadly, there was no mention or even the slightest acknowledgement of my requests. Call me naive, but I was hoping/ expecting better service at a Michelin star restaurant- $400 meal.
 
Any ways, whomp whomp- at $95 per person, you'll get an omakase (set prix fix menu). No doubt, it's some of the freshest sushi I've had in SF. However, there were also items I didn't thoroughly enjoy, such as the kelp tea (known to help cleanse palate- left a weird after taste) and the soup (which I found rather on the saltier end). 
As for the grand finale of the omakase, I'd highly recommend the A5 wagyu beef nigiri, from the texture to taste, it was utterly orgasmic (this means a lot coming from a person who doesn't even like beef).
For the uni lovers, one MUST try the Kaisui uni (14.50 a piece- hokkaido sea urchin) and Bafun Uni (13 a piece, Hokkaido short spine sea urchin). I can honestly say that each bite was simply heavenly & worth every darn dollar. Hands down the best uni I've had in my life thus far. 

Verdict: avid sushi lovers should come try out this place. it's by no means a place to regularly frequent for date night, but it's totally worth a try. (Just make sure you're not coming to celebrate a birthday. HAHA- guess I'm still not over the mishap a year later).

excerpts: You may want to add a few à la carte items; for instance, the best uni is not included in the oma.
The food is quite good, but far below the stuff you'll get at the top sushi restaurants around the world - in terms of creativity (no 'wow' dish here!)
or freshness.
Pretty long sake list, although the waitress is not helpful in advising.
uni.author: Lam N.
uni.review: Go for the Grand Omakase as it has more and better pieces. You may want to add a few à la carte items; for instance, the best uni is not included in the oma. The food is quite good, but far below the stuff you'll get at the top sushi restaurants around the world - in terms of creativity (no 'wow' dish here!) or freshness. Pretty long sake list, although the waitress is not helpful in advising.

excerpts:
Bafun Uni
-  Lobster Tomago
uni.author: David C.
uni.review:
Most innovative Omakase that SF has to offer.

PROTIP:  
Don't forget to tack on extras that aren't included in the Omakase.  We tried pretty much everything but what left a mark in our memory was:
-  Bafun Uni
-  Lobster Tomago

excerpts: toro, bonito, buri and Santa Barbara uni.
Didn't realize how sweet Santa Barbara uni is, and the bonito, OMG, delicious.
Bonito usually have  a fishy after taste, but this was an exception.
The cauliflower soup was delicious; the mushroom and the abalone was so meaty, and all the flavors of the soup combined, it was amazing.
uni.author: Toni Rose M.
uni.review:
Finally I got a chance to try this place out.

Dined in with James M. (check out her ratings ya'll) on Thursday and we both got the $95 omakase, a few more from the a la carte menu and sake (Yuki no Bosha).
The meal was beautifully presented and it was delicious. Our favorite from the omakase menu are: toro, bonito, buri and Santa Barbara uni. Didn't realize how sweet Santa Barbara uni is, and the bonito, OMG, delicious. Bonito usually have  a fishy after taste, but this was an exception. The cauliflower soup was delicious; the mushroom and the abalone was so meaty, and all the flavors of the soup combined, it was amazing. And the oyster with caviar in the Hassun, flavor explosion. Delicate simple flavors brought everything together. The ankimo from the a la carte menu, delicious. 

Will definitely come back here again to try the grand omakase. I think getting the omakase then order more from the a la carte works better, since that's what we did. We were stuffed after the meal. Do not believe the reviews where they say it's okay sushi, or there's nothing special about it, try it yourself and judge. Because I think this is one of the decent sushi I've had in the Bay Area compared to sushi from the fish market in Japan.

excerpts: and I told him "uni" although I don't know why he asked me that (uni was not served in the omakase to me).
The best item is probably the kaisui uni which is a hokkaido uni brought in from Japan.
The uni is caught in Japan and rather than take out the uni and put it into a wooden box, they put ocean water with the uni and transport it that way to the US.
I have had this before
so I didn't order it
but if you haven't tried it and you like uni, I recommend giving it a try.
It is served on a spoon with sushi rice and uni on top.
uni.author: Dan P.
uni.review:
THE REAL DEAL!

Yup, this place is the real deal.  I got a seat right smack in the middle of the sushi bar and right in front of Chef Kusakabe himself.  Omakase is the only option ($95).  At the start of the meal you will get a menu for sake and drinks as well as the option for a sake pairing ($75).  The chef will also ask you if there is any foods that you are allergic to or don't like to eat (e.g. shellfish, etc.).  I like everything.  He also asked me what my favorite fish is and I told him "uni" although I don't know why he asked me that (uni was not served in the omakase to me).  He also asked what I wanted for my finale (toro or a5 wagyu beef - you can read my choice below).
